key_points: STANDARD OPERATING PROCEDURES (SOPs) Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs) in a multi-crew environment are essential for consistent and predictable responses to routine and emergency situations
They also provide for enhanced morale (meaning less friction) between cre members that is often caused by doing things differently
For pilots who are in training, or new to the company, they will help to ensure faster integration
learning.explanation: STANDARD OPERATING PROCEDURES (SOPs) Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs) in a multi-crew environment are essential for consistent and predictable responses to routine and emergency situations. They also provide for enhanced morale (meaning less friction) between cre members that is often caused by doing things differently. For pilots who are in training, or new to the company, they will help to ensure faster integration. Standardization brings quality and healthy environments to achieve the highest level of safety. In fact, there are many reasons for SOPs, including: A logical order of events; Improvement in communication; Better error management; Better workload management and prioritisation; Improvements in cross-checking. The development of procedures makes pilots more effective and reliable in their activities - a process called - procedural consistency. SOP can develop over time, as the result of accidents or incidents from either the own or another company, after an airline has been taken over by another one with different SOP, or because SOP are frequently violated. Therefore, it is crucial that SOP are updated to maintain synergy and shared by every crew member.

content.question:
A modern airliner aircraft is descending; however it cannot maintain the desired flight path with the selected cost index. Without any pilot input, the aircraft automatically changes from VNAV Path Mode to VNAV Speed Mode. The pilots noticed the mode changed but did not understand what it meant.
Which one of the following terms is used to describe the crew’s lack of understanding?

options.A: Mode Confusion.
options.B: Spatial awareness.
options.C: Automation complacency.
options.D: Blinkered concentration.

key_points: Mode Awareness is used to describe a situation where the pilots are aware of the active mode(s) and understand the corresponding actions and responses which are necessary for proper use of the automated system
It consists of the awareness of the existence of different automation levels and the awareness of the currently active mode

Similar to situational awareness, mode awareness is established by the perception and correct interpretation of system information, the build-up of knowledge and finally the prediction of future system behavior
learning.explanation: Mode Awareness is used to describe a situation where the pilots are aware of the active mode(s) and understand the corresponding actions and responses which are necessary for proper use of the automated system. It consists of the awareness of the existence of different automation levels and the awareness of the currently active mode. Similar to situational awareness, mode awareness is established by the perception and correct interpretation of system information, the build-up of knowledge and finally the prediction of future system behavior. Mode confusion occurs when the flight crew believes the automation is in a mode different than the one it is actually in and consequently make inappropriate requests or responses to the automation. It can be described as a kind of automation surprise, where the system does not behave according to the user’s expectations. In the case of mode confusion, the user loses track of which system is currently active or what kind of behavior is appropriate for which mode. Mode confusion can also occur when the flight crew does not fully understand the behavior of the automation in certain modes or how different modes interact, i.e., when the crew have a poor “mental model” of the automation. Mode confusion is what happened in this situation. The mode automatically changed from LNAV to VNAV but the pilots did not understand the implications of this and that the aircraft will no longer follow the desired flight path.

content.question: What is "automation complacency"?

options.A: No over-ride facility is available on auto-flight selection as there are enough levels of redundancy to cope with any system failure.
options.B: The circumstance where monitoring and cross-checking is reduced because of the belief in the infallibility of the automatic systems.
options.C: The circumstance where the pilot flies the aircraft manually because he is unable to rely on the automatic systems flying the aircraft safely.
options.D: Automation is now so reliable that the human input is no longer necessary.

key_points: AUTOMATION Cockpit automation has the potential to increase or decrease the flight safety, depending on how well you use the equipment
Automation can conserve resources and attention, relieving pilot workload and giving time for supervision
However, if given too much control, the cockpit becomes boring, and errors can go unnoticed amongst the monotony
learning.explanation: AUTOMATION Cockpit automation has the potential to increase or decrease the flight safety, depending on how well you use the equipment. Automation can conserve resources and attention, relieving pilot workload and giving time for supervision. However, if given too much control, the cockpit becomes boring, and errors can go unnoticed amongst the monotony. Pilots can also become less confident in their basic airmanship and flying skills. Whereas machines can wait for infrequent information without getting bored, can perform long-term control and set values, again, without getting bored; people can exercise judgement, make better decisions, and detect unusual conditions (smells, noises), while getting easily bored. So, on the one hand, automation is good, because it can take a lot of routine work away from you. On the other hand, automation can induce a feeling of automation complacency – too much reliance on the machine, and lead you not to check things as often as you should. A high degree of automation may alter traditional tasks so much that your attention and competence is reduced once you are out of the loop. Thus, communication and coordination call for a greater effort from the crew. You can avoid automation complacency by regarding systems as one more crewmember that needs to be cross-checked – that is, you have to make sure that the autopilot is actually taking you in the right direction. You can cope with low error tolerant situations by constantly complying with cross-over verification procedures.

content.question:
An aircraft departs for a VFR flight. The route involves a descent into mountainous terrain.
En-route an instrument fails, which makes it more difficult to fly without visual reference, and the weather deteriorates to IMC.
The pilot continues to attempt to fly under VFR but crashes into the mountains.

What type of error best characterizes this accident scenario?

options.A: Isolated error.
options.B: Lapse.
options.C: Design-induced error.
options.D: Error chain.

key_points: Accidents in aviation are usually not the result of one single catastrophic error
Instead, it requires several individual errors, both latent and active, for an accident to occur
The undesired outcome could have been prevented if any of these errors had either not happened or had been detected and corrected
learning.explanation: Accidents in aviation are usually not the result of one single catastrophic error. Instead, it requires several individual errors, both latent and active, for an accident to occur. The undesired outcome could have been prevented if any of these errors had either not happened or had been detected and corrected. A sequence of errors leading to an accident or other undesired outcome is referred to as an error chain.

content.question: The steps of the "decision-making" process in the correct sequence are...

options.A: perception, action, detection, feedback, decision.
options.B: detection, perception, decision, action, feedback.
options.C: detection, action, perception, decision, feedback.
options.D: detection, perception, decision, feedback, action.

key_points: The decision making process includes the following steps: 1
Detection: The process of decision making begins with the detection or recognition of a problem or opportunity
It involves identifying the need for a decision and being aware of the relevant information
learning.explanation: The decision making process includes the following steps: 1. Detection: The process of decision making begins with the detection or recognition of a problem or opportunity. It involves identifying the need for a decision and being aware of the relevant information. 2. Perception: Once the problem or opportunity is detected, the decision maker engages in perception. This stage involves gathering and interpreting information, assessing the potential outcomes and consequences of different alternatives, and developing an understanding of the situation. 3. Decision: After perceiving and evaluating the available information, the decision maker proceeds to make a decision. This involves selecting the most appropriate course of action or solution from the alternatives considered. 4. Action: Once the decision is made, action is taken to implement the chosen course of action. This stage involves putting the decision into practice and carrying out the necessary steps to execute the chosen option. 5. Feedback: After the decision has been implemented, the decision maker receives feedback on the outcomes and results of the chosen action. Feedback provides valuable information that can be used to evaluate the decision's effectiveness, learn from the experience, and make improvements in future decision-making processes. The correct sequence emphasizes the importance of detecting a problem or opportunity, perceiving and evaluating the available alternatives, making a decision, taking action to implement the decision and then receiving feedback to learn from the outcomes.

content.question:
Learning to fly naturally induces stress in a student pilot because he is lacking experience. What are the manifestations of this type of stress?
1. Nervousness and channelised attention.
2. Being rough at the controls.
3. Drink much more alcohol and smoke more than usual.
4. Airsickness, lack of sleep.

options.C: 1 and 2.
options.D: 3 and 4.

key_points: (1) "Nervousness and channelised attention" Correct
Any pilot, irrespective of age, may experience mental blocks, confusion, nervousness and channelised attention when under stress
(2) "Being rough at the controls" Correct
learning.explanation: (1) "Nervousness and channelised attention" Correct. Any pilot, irrespective of age, may experience mental blocks, confusion, nervousness and channelised attention when under stress. (2) "Being rough at the controls" Correct. When a student begins flight training, they often struggle to emotionally and physically relax, one of the reasons behind this is the lack of confidence. Some common student pilot errors include holding the controls too firmly. Too tight of a grip on the controls prevents the pilot from feeling the airplane, shifting winds and the necessary control inputs required to obtain a certain attitude. (3) "Smoke and Drink much more alcohol than usual" Incorrect. This is a manifestation of excessive stress => typically not the case of a student pilot. (4) "Airsickness, lack of sleep." Incorrect. In this case, we are asked about naturally induced stress, and not extreme cases. Excessive stress may lead to sickness but usually student pilots get airsick because their body is not used to the aircraft's movements during flight, which is more a physiological problem rather than a psychological one. Lack of sleep can be correct. For example, if the student is nervous because of a demanding flight/exam flight the following day, she/he may not sleep well the night before.

content.question: Resignation is a dangerous attitude because it:

options.A: Makes the affected flight crew member feel more hopeful of a positive outcome.
options.B: Lowers the self-confidence of the affected flight crew member.
options.C: Makes the non-affected flight crew member spend less time anticipating future actions.
options.D: Makes the affected flight crew member more likely to show impulsive behaviour.

key_points: HAZARDOUS ATTITUDES Studies have identified five hazardous attitudes among pilots that can interfere with a pilot’s ability to make effective decisions
ANTI-AUTHORITY (“don’t tell me”) – You display this attitude if you resent having someone tell you what to do, or you regard rules and procedures as unnecessary
Antidote – Follow the rules
learning.explanation: HAZARDOUS ATTITUDES Studies have identified five hazardous attitudes among pilots that can interfere with a pilot’s ability to make effective decisions. ANTI-AUTHORITY (“don’t tell me”) – You display this attitude if you resent having someone tell you what to do, or you regard rules and procedures as unnecessary. Antidote – Follow the rules. They are usually right. IMPULSIVITY (“do it quickly”) – If you feel the need to act immediately and do the first thing that comes to mind without considering the best solution to a problem, then you are exhibiting impulsivity. Antidote – Not so fast. Think first. INVULNERABILITY (“It won’t happen to me”) – You are more likely to take chances and increase risk if you think accidents will not happen to you. Antidote – It could happen to me. MACHO (“I can do it”) – If you have this attitude, you might take risks trying to prove that you are better than anyone else. Women are just as likely to have this characteristic as men. Antidote – Taking chances is foolish. RESIGNATION (“What’s the use?”) – You are experiencing resignation if you feel that no matter what you do, it will have little effect on what happens to you. You may feel that when things go well, it is just good luck and when things go poorly, it is bad luck or someone else is responsible. This feeling can cause you to leave the action to others – for better or worse. Antidote – I am not helpless. I can make a difference.

content.question: A good way of dealing with long-term and chronic stress is to...

options.A: take care of the physical causes of stress.
options.B: cut down on social interactions.
options.C: enforce a rigorous, reactive approach to time management.
options.D: postpone professional training to free up time.

key_points: Fatigue is a feeling of constant tiredness or weakness and can be physical, mental or a combination of both
The two types of fatigue are acute and chronic
Acute fatigue – short-term, more intense which usually affects the body, and just needs a good nights’ sleep to sort things out
learning.explanation: Fatigue is a feeling of constant tiredness or weakness and can be physical, mental or a combination of both. The two types of fatigue are acute and chronic. Acute fatigue – short-term, more intense which usually affects the body, and just needs a good nights’ sleep to sort things out. Chronic fatigue – arises from more long-term effects, like many episodes of acute fatigue. Chronic fatigue typically happens after you’ve had no rest for some time and the body’s energy level cannot be restored after normal or increased periods of sleep. Coping with the impact of chronic stress can be challenging. Because the source of long-term stress is more constant than acute stress, the body never receives a clear signal to return to normal functioning. To prevent chronic stress, one must deal with the stressors (in order to avoid them) and use relaxation techniques to minimize the stress effects.

content.question: The correct statement about different learning techniques is...

options.A: Operant conditioning requires reinforcement.
options.B: Repetition is required for learning by insight.
options.C: Classical conditioning requires reinforcement.
options.D: Operant conditioning does NOT require reinforcement.

key_points: Classical conditioning: It is a type of learning that involves associating a neutral stimulus with a stimulus that naturally elicits a response
In other words, it is based on the association between stimuli and physiological responses
An example of classical conditioning is an experienced pilot's automatic response to a fire warning signal, which is a learned physiological reaction
learning.explanation: Classical conditioning: It is a type of learning that involves associating a neutral stimulus with a stimulus that naturally elicits a response. In other words, it is based on the association between stimuli and physiological responses. An example of classical conditioning is an experienced pilot's automatic response to a fire warning signal, which is a learned physiological reaction. Operant conditioning: type of learning that involves changing behavior through the use of consequences. It was developed by psychologist B. F. Skinner and is based on the concept that behavior is influenced by its consequences. In operant conditioning, behavior is shaped by the consequences that follow it, such as reinforcement or punishment. Repetition: a learning technique that involves repeated exposure to information or the practice of a specific skill. This process of repeating helps strengthen learning and improve the ability to retain the knowledge or perform the skill effectively. Operant conditioning needs reinforcement as it is a part of the learning process, so the correct statement is "Operant conditioning requires reinforcement."

content.question:
On a night flight, you are about to fall asleep. What can help you stay awake?
1. Isometric exercises
2. Have a meal.
3. Reduce the intensity of cockpit lighting.
4. Maintain active communication, human-machine interface.

options.A: 1 and 2.
options.B: 1 and 4.
options.C: 2 and 3.
options.D: 3 and 4.

key_points: Hypovigilance is a lack of attention to detail, it is akin to a microsleep which can occur at any time during the flight, especially during periods of monotony, reduction of workload, during simple and repetitive tasks, low lightning, high temperature and constant and monotonous noise
During long-haul flights, hypovigilance is often unavoidable
To help prevent hypovigilance during flight especially at night, in a multi-crew operation, it is possible for crew-members to take planned naps (controlled rest) - these should be short, approx
learning.explanation: Hypovigilance is a lack of attention to detail, it is akin to a microsleep which can occur at any time during the flight, especially during periods of monotony, reduction of workload, during simple and repetitive tasks, low lightning, high temperature and constant and monotonous noise. During long-haul flights, hypovigilance is often unavoidable. To help prevent hypovigilance during flight especially at night, in a multi-crew operation, it is possible for crew-members to take planned naps (controlled rest) - these should be short, approx. 20min. It is also helpful to engage in social conversation and physical activity such as arm and leg stretching may also assist in maintaining wakefulness. Since physical activity is very difficult in the cockpit, isometric exercises can be done instead. Isometric exercises are contractions of a particular muscle or group of muscles. During isometric exercises, the muscle doesn't noticeably change length and the affected joint doesn't move. During the night, turning up the cockpit lights will also help. However, this deteriorates night vision.

content.question: The acquisition of a motor programme (skill) will mean that the..

options.A: more behaviour is automated, the less it requires conscious attention and thus the more it frees mental resources.
options.B: more behaviour is automated, the more it requires conscious attention and the thus less it frees mental resources.
options.C: less behaviour is automated, the less it requires conscious attention and thus the more it frees mental resources.
options.D: more behaviour is automated, the more it requires conscious attention and thus the more it frees mental resources.

key_points: Motor programmes are stored routines that enable patterns of behaviour to be executed without continuous conscious control
Motor programmes are stored in the procedural part of long-term memory and are retrieved when a skill shall be performed

Motor programmes enables an individual to perform more than one task at the same time by freeing mental resources – this way, one task can be performed requiring conscious attention, while performing another one at an unconscious level (motor programme)
learning.explanation: Motor programmes are stored routines that enable patterns of behaviour to be executed without continuous conscious control. Motor programmes are stored in the procedural part of long-term memory and are retrieved when a skill shall be performed. Motor programmes enables an individual to perform more than one task at the same time by freeing mental resources – this way, one task can be performed requiring conscious attention, while performing another one at an unconscious level (motor programme). According to J. R. Anderson, the acquisition of such expertise involves three stages, namely: Cognitive, Associative and Autonomous. Cognitive phase – the learner thinks consciously about each individual action. In this phase, movements are slow, inconsistent, and inefficient. The learner might need to recite mentally or aloud the steps which need to be taken. Associative phase – the separate components of the overall action become integrated. Movements become more fluid, reliable, and some parts of the action are controlled automatically. Automatic phase – the total manoeuvre can be executed smoothly without conscious control. At this stage, trying to consciously monitor its execution will slow it down and increase rate of error.

content.question: What can the crew do during a long-haul flight to ensure they remain vigilant?

options.A: Turn up the cockpit lighting.
options.B: Remain seated and do not exercise to reserve energy.
options.C: Communicate with each other and take it in turns to have periods of relaxation.
options.D: Have a meal.

key_points: HYPOVIGILANCE Hypo vigilance is a state of reduced vigilance and attention, which reduces, among other, the abilities to direct attention to perform multiple tasks at the same time
Hypovigilance is characterized by a decrease in sensory perception

Hypovigilance is a lack of attention to detail, it is akin to a microsleep which can occur at any time during the flight, especially during periods of monotony, reduction of workload, during simple and repetitive tasks
learning.explanation: HYPOVIGILANCE Hypo vigilance is a state of reduced vigilance and attention, which reduces, among other, the abilities to direct attention to perform multiple tasks at the same time. Hypovigilance is characterized by a decrease in sensory perception. Hypovigilance is a lack of attention to detail, it is akin to a microsleep which can occur at any time during the flight, especially during periods of monotony, reduction of workload, during simple and repetitive tasks. Techniques to avoid the state of hypovigilance can be exercised during long-haul flights, since monotony in the cockpit may create such circumstances. In a multi-crew operation, it is advisable to engage in communication with the other crew member to remain active. It is also possible for crew-members to take planned naps (controlled rest) - these should be short, approx. 20min. Controlled rest will help the crew maintain effectiveness. Turning on the lights may also help during night flights, but the crew should keep in mind that their night vision will be affected. Since the question does not mention anything about night flying, we consider the answer "Communicate with each other and take it in turns to have periods of relaxation" to be the correct one.

content.question: An ATO which is rather relaxed when it comes to complying with rules and regulations forms a young pilot. After his/her graduation, the pilot gets hired by an airline which strictly complies with all legal requirements. Which kind of behaviour can we expect from the young pilot?

options.A: At first, he will stick to the behavioural patterns he has learned in his flight school and will then adapt to the more restrictive behaviour of his company’s pilots.
options.B: The pilot will be overly correct when starting his new job and then gradually return to the attitude he obtained in flight training.
options.C: He will likely never begin to strictly observe rules and procedures and develop a laissez-faire attitude.
options.D: He will carefully make sure to comply with all legal requirements from his first day.

key_points: As many others, this question is quite debatable as it really depends on the personality of the individual
Generally speaking, young pilots will tend to learn by imitation (modelling) which means that their change in behaviour is triggered by observing that behaviour and its consequences in others
Therefore, if the young pilot’s school is quite relaxed when it comes to following rules and complying with regulations, this is the sort of behaviour that we can expect from the student pilot
learning.explanation: As many others, this question is quite debatable as it really depends on the personality of the individual. Generally speaking, young pilots will tend to learn by imitation (modelling) which means that their change in behaviour is triggered by observing that behaviour and its consequences in others. Therefore, if the young pilot’s school is quite relaxed when it comes to following rules and complying with regulations, this is the sort of behaviour that we can expect from the student pilot. We can predict that, initially, the young pilot will display the behaviour adopted at the ATO. However, he/she will soon realise that that is now not desirable behaviour. It is then expected that he/she will gradually adjust his/her attitudes to that of his/her new role models (captains/colleagues).

content.question: Physical stress takes place when..

options.A: the perceived demand is greater than the perceived ability.
options.B: the neurones in the nervous system are overloaded.
options.C: the brain can no longer cope, due to either quantitative or qualitative overload.
options.D: outside conditions put a strain upon the homeostatic mechanisms of the body.

key_points: When homeostasis is disturbed, a person experiences stress
The term stress means physical and psychological reactions which are caused by specific external or internal stimuli (stressors) and enable a person to cope with special challenges
learning.explanation: When homeostasis is disturbed, a person experiences stress. The term stress means physical and psychological reactions which are caused by specific external or internal stimuli (stressors) and enable a person to cope with special challenges.

content.question: Which of the following could be typical effects of human underload on a flight deck?

options.A: During the cruise phase of a flight in good weather repeatedly failing to pay attention to ATC clearances.
options.B: During an emergency procedure forgetting to perform all required memory items.
options.C: Incorrectly switching off the centre tank fuel pumps due to an incorrect understanding of the fuel system operation.
options.D: Better than normal manual flying performance.

key_points: Arousal and Performance Arousal is the measure of the human being's readiness to respond
The relationship between arousal and performance is a symmetrical inverted U (performance being on the vertical axis and arousal on the horizontal axis)
Increases in arousal will result in the increase of performance, up to a point, called the break point, beyond which further arousal is dysfunctional to the outcome of performance
learning.explanation: Arousal and Performance Arousal is the measure of the human being's readiness to respond. The relationship between arousal and performance is a symmetrical inverted U (performance being on the vertical axis and arousal on the horizontal axis). Increases in arousal will result in the increase of performance, up to a point, called the break point, beyond which further arousal is dysfunctional to the outcome of performance. At the optimum arousal level, we are at our most efficient - optimum arousal happens just below the breakpoint. Regarding this question: When referring to human underload, EASA means a workload below optimum, where arousal is low and the pilot is hypovigilant (because of boredom). In this state, it is likely that he/she will not be able to react quickly to slight deviations or his actions will be late in general.

content.question: The individual’s perception of stress depends on the..

options.A: conditions of the current situation only.
options.B: objective evaluation of the situation and one’s abilities to cope with it.
options.C: subjective evaluation of the situation and one’s abilities to cope with it.
options.D: pilot’s increasing level of arousal.

key_points: STRESS Stress disturbs the body’s homeostasis and enables you to adapt to encountered situations
It is the body’s response to a stressor, which is an internal or external stimulus that is interpreted as a threat to the body’s equilibrium, and prepares it for action

Stress is a natural human reaction and it is not always negative! A certain moderate amount of stress is beneficial to human performance - it stops you slowing down and keeps you on your toes – this is the sort associated with success
learning.explanation: STRESS Stress disturbs the body’s homeostasis and enables you to adapt to encountered situations. It is the body’s response to a stressor, which is an internal or external stimulus that is interpreted as a threat to the body’s equilibrium, and prepares it for action. Stress is a natural human reaction and it is not always negative! A certain moderate amount of stress is beneficial to human performance - it stops you slowing down and keeps you on your toes – this is the sort associated with success. Stress is a very subjective matter – every individual is different and stress reactions as well as their magnitudes differ from person to person. The individual level of stress depends on the individual’s subjective perception of available abilities and comparing them to the situational demands. In humans, the physiological reaction to stress is the non-specific “fight or flight” response. This natural reaction prepares you to either flee or protect yourself in dangerous situations.

content.question:
The pilots are performing their pre-flight checks. As they approach the runway intersection B2, ATC clears them for an immediate take-off. However, the pilot replies “unable”, since he/she has not yet completed the pre-departure checks.
Which kind of behaviour has the pilot shown?

options.A: Unprofessionalism
options.B: Overconfidence
options.C: Self discipline
options.D: Anti-authority

key_points: SELF-DISCIPLINE The term self-discipline means the ability to counteract any distractions from a self-imposed or given objective
This requires the capacity of delayed gratification, which refers to the power to reject immediate pleasant consequences in order to achieve the greater future reward
In this case, the pilot shows self-discipline
learning.explanation: SELF-DISCIPLINE The term self-discipline means the ability to counteract any distractions from a self-imposed or given objective. This requires the capacity of delayed gratification, which refers to the power to reject immediate pleasant consequences in order to achieve the greater future reward. In this case, the pilot shows self-discipline. It is definitely tempting to accept an immediate take-off, however it is important that pilots remain goal and safety oriented. Good airmanship is demonstrated by the pilot when he/she chooses to finish the pre-departure checks. Accepting the early clearance would mean accepting that something might have been overlooked. That, on the other hand, would be unprofessional behaviour and could be said to be a consequence of overconfident behaviour.

content.question: What are examples of psychological stress factors?

options.A: Low humidity, lack of information, lack of exercise, and competitive pressure.
options.B: Fear of failure, discrimination, lack of illumination, and low humidity.
options.C: Competitive pressure, lack of illumination, lack of exercise, and discrimination.
options.D: Discrimination, lack of information, competitive pressure, and fear of failure.

key_points: STRESS Stress disturbs the body’s homeostasis and enables you to adapt to encountered situations
It is the body’s response to a stressor, which is an internal or external stimulus that is interpreted as a threat to the body’s equilibrium, and prepares it for action
There are three types of stressors: Environmental Stressors – environmental conditions, noise, vibrations, cosmic radiation, accelerations
learning.explanation: STRESS Stress disturbs the body’s homeostasis and enables you to adapt to encountered situations. It is the body’s response to a stressor, which is an internal or external stimulus that is interpreted as a threat to the body’s equilibrium, and prepares it for action. There are three types of stressors: Environmental Stressors – environmental conditions, noise, vibrations, cosmic radiation, accelerations. Physiological Stressors – fatigue, lack of physical fitness, improper eating habits, hunger, thirst, cold/too hot, humidity, dehydration. Psychological/emotional stress – inter-personal conflicts, discrimination, fear of failure, death of a relative, divorce, financial problems, job insecurity.

content.question: What is a disadvantage of using mental schema when performing a familiar, but rather complex task?

options.A: The tendency to base current actions on past experience.
options.B: Reduced flexibility in case of any malfunctions.
options.C: They may encourage rigid ways of thinking.
options.D: Sensual illusions may arise from them.

key_points: Mental Schema are mental structures that an individual uses to organize knowledge and guide cognitive processes and behaviour
People use schemata (the plural of schema) to categorize objects and events based on common elements and characteristics and thus interpret and predict the world
It enables the individual to expect future events and plan actions based on previous experiences of sequenced events
learning.explanation: Mental Schema are mental structures that an individual uses to organize knowledge and guide cognitive processes and behaviour. People use schemata (the plural of schema) to categorize objects and events based on common elements and characteristics and thus interpret and predict the world. It enables the individual to expect future events and plan actions based on previous experiences of sequenced events. Mental Schema makes it possible to complete repetitive tasks (skills) without conscious control, once they have been automated. This frees mental capacity to perform other tasks requiring attention. However, there is a problem with mental schemata and automated actions - they can be transferred to situations where they do not fit and they may encourage rigid ways of thinking.

content.question: What is correct about Pre-flight briefings? They should:

options.A: Contain very little information to avoid confusing the operating crew.
options.B: Be adapted to the specific flight, for the crew to operate effectively.
options.C: Cover activities only during and after the flight.
options.D: Cover all possible events.

key_points: BRIEFINGS The main objective of crew briefings is that all crew members understand the desired sequence of events and actions, the condition of the aircraft, any special circumstances affecting the planned flight
At the end of a briefing, all crew members should share a common mental model of the situation
Briefings can be a powerful means of transferring information; if properly given they can be extremely effective
learning.explanation: BRIEFINGS The main objective of crew briefings is that all crew members understand the desired sequence of events and actions, the condition of the aircraft, any special circumstances affecting the planned flight. At the end of a briefing, all crew members should share a common mental model of the situation. Briefings can be a powerful means of transferring information; if properly given they can be extremely effective. Effective briefings are: Short. A briefing is designed to provide information quickly and effectively. Of standard type/standard sequence of briefing items. Elements always appear in the same sequence, and meet the expectations of the receiver who is used to that sequence making it easy to spot an omission. Understood by all crew members. A simple but well-understood plan of action, supported by all is preferable to a possibly brilliant but misunderstood plan. All in-flight briefings should be conducted by the pilot flying to inform the pilot monitoring of the planned course of action. The optimum time for an in-flight briefing is a period of low workload shortly before the briefed event occurs.

content.question: What is the personality attribute that can contribute to an individual experiencing higher levels of stress?

options.A: An extraverted personality.
options.B: Having low ambitions.
options.C: Having self control.
options.D: An anxious personality.

key_points: Personality can be categorized into several dimensions, with extraversion and anxiety being considered major traits
However, other significant traits such as warmth, sociability, impulsiveness, tough-mindedness, dominance, stability, and boldness also contribute to an individual's overall personality
At a fundamental level, extraversion is associated with boldness, impulsive behavior, and sociability
learning.explanation: Personality can be categorized into several dimensions, with extraversion and anxiety being considered major traits. However, other significant traits such as warmth, sociability, impulsiveness, tough-mindedness, dominance, stability, and boldness also contribute to an individual's overall personality. At a fundamental level, extraversion is associated with boldness, impulsive behavior, and sociability. Anxiety, on the other hand, is typically linked to emotional instability, tension, and suspiciousness. It's important to note that extraversion and anxiety are not directly related to each other, meaning that some individuals may be both anxious and extroverted, while others may be anxious and introverted. Individuals with an anxious personality are more likely to experience stress as they tend to worry and anticipate negative outcomes. Which of the following statements regarding interpersonal interactions are correct?

2 -If the receiver is of non-native tongue, the sender will reinforce what he is saying by using more complicated words so as to optimize understanding
3- If the sender considers there is doubt that the message has been correctly understood, he/she must seek clarification.
4 -It is much safer to fly with a crew who know each other well because communication will always be excellent.

options.A: 2 and 3 are correct
options.B: 1 and 2 are correct
options.C: 1 and 3 are correct
options.D: 3 and 4 are correct

key_points: The communication process typically starts with the sender who initiates the message
Before the sender releases the message, they have to generate the idea and then encode it reasonably so that the receiver can easily understand it
The process of encoding is modulated by the sender's idea of the receiver's competence to decode it
learning.explanation: The communication process typically starts with the sender who initiates the message. Before the sender releases the message, they have to generate the idea and then encode it reasonably so that the receiver can easily understand it. The process of encoding is modulated by the sender's idea of the receiver's competence to decode it. If the sender believes the receiver to be incompetent, he/she will usually use a simpler wording, while redundancy in formulation will be reduced when addressing a receiver perceived as being competent. If the sender knows that he/she and the receiver do not share the same native language, complicated terms should be avoided. Instead, he/she should opt to use simple words, speak slowly and repeat important terms to optimize understanding. Unless the receiver responds to the message, communication process is incomplete. Feedback helps the sender transform his message, if needed. It also allows the receiver to clear doubts on the message, ask questions to build his confidence and enables the sender to know efficiency of the message. Feedback of information makes the communication process complete.

content.question: An aeroplane is flying at 2 500 ft. The SPEED mode is active on the autothrottle. The first radio altimeter starts to display a non-correct value (-8 ft). This behaviour of the radio altimeter will automatically cancel the SPEED mode of the auto-throttle. The pilots noticed the malfunction of the first radio altimeter but didn't notice the deactivation of the SPEED mode and, as the second radio altimeter was acting well, they continued on, using the second rad-alt. When intercepting the ILS Glide Slope, both crew believe that the autothrottle is still in SPEED mode and therefore, they do not understand why the speed is not being actively managed by the aircraft. Which of the following terms describes the crew’s lack of understanding in this situation?

options.A: High situational awareness.
options.B: Automation complacency.
options.C: Mode confusion.
options.D: Blinkered concentration.

key_points: Learning Objective 040
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 040.03.07.02.02: Explain some basic flight crew errors and terms that arise with the introduction of automation: passive monitoring; blinkered concentration; confusion; mode awareness. Mode Awareness is used to describe a situation where the pilots are aware of the active mode(s) and understand the corresponding actions and responses which are necessary for proper use of the automated system. It consists of the awareness of the existence of different automation levels and the awareness of the currently active mode. Similar to situational awareness, mode awareness is established by the perception and correct interpretation of system information, the build-up of knowledge and finally, the prediction of future system behaviour. The opposite of mode awareness is mode confusion. Mode confusion occurs when the flight crew believes the automation is in a mode different than the one it is actually in and consequently make inappropriate requests or responses to the automation. It can be described as a kind of automation surprise, where the system does not behave according to the user’s expectations. In the case of mode confusion, the user loses track of which system is currently active or what kind of behaviour is appropriate for which mode. Mode confusion can also occur when the flight crew does not fully understand the behaviour of the automation in certain modes or how different modes interact, i.e., when the crew have a poor “mental model” of the automation. Mode confusion is what happened in this situation. The SPEED mode "dropped out" and the pilots were not aware, they now had an incorrect mental model of the automation, and were therefore incorrect in how they expected the aircraft to act. In a broader sense, it could also be classed as a lack of situational awareness.

it is the body’s response to a stressor, which is an internal or external stimulus that is interpreted as a threat to the body’s equilibrium, and prepares it for action

Stress is a natural human reaction and it is not always negative! A certain moderate amount of stress is beneficial to human performance - it stops you slowing down and keeps you on your toes – this is the sort associated with success

How good do we think we are versus how good we think we need to be. In this case, the question is asking about the different types of stressors/stress factors. content.question: How can you describe the top down process?

options.A: Comparing data stored in the brain with the new precepted information, critically disguising inconsistent details.
options.B: Comparing data stored in the brain with the new precepted information, possibly adding missing data.
options.C: A data controlling process for protecting the brain from adding and saving irrelevant data.
options.D: A process for gathering data and distributing it to the different parts of the brain.

key_points: Top-down perception comes into play when you make a scene fit what you expect it to be, rather than perceive reality
These perceptions are heavily influenced by our expectations, prior knowledge and past experiences in particular
For example, when two similar objects (of different sizes) are viewed from the same distance away, our brain has prior knowledge that those objects should be the same size, giving us that expectation
learning.explanation: Top-down perception comes into play when you make a scene fit what you expect it to be, rather than perceive reality. These perceptions are heavily influenced by our expectations, prior knowledge and past experiences in particular. For example, when two similar objects (of different sizes) are viewed from the same distance away, our brain has prior knowledge that those objects should be the same size, giving us that expectation. This influences our mind very heavily in top-down processing, and makes us perceive that the smaller object is actually the same size, but further away from us. Top-down processing therefore can cover up inconsistencies in our perception of things, and whilst it is fast, it is not always the most accurate. There are two answers here which look very similar, the first is the correct answer; Comparing data stored in the brain with the new precepted information, critically disguising inconsistent details, and the second is; Comparing data stored in the brain with the new precepted information, possibly adding missing data. We have already discussed why the first answer is correct, however, the second answer looks very similar, but is subtly different. The way we read the second answer, we believe it to be saying that missing data is added to the data that is already stored in the brain, and this would be the wrong way round. What actually happens is that sometimes, extra data is added from the memory to "fill in the gaps" of our perception, and that is what can create mistakes. Of course, with a different interpretation, it could be considered right, but we would still mark the first answer as correct, as there is no need for interpretation, therefore making it more correct.

options.B: 1, 2, and 4 only
options.C: 1, 3, and 4 only
options.D: 1, 2, and 3 only

key_points: Arousal and Performance Arousal is the measure of the human being's readiness to respond
The relationship between arousal and performance is a symmetrical inverted U (performance being on the vertical axis and arousal on the horizontal axis)

Increases in arousal will result in the increase of performance, up to a point, called the break point, beyond which further arousal is dysfunctional to the outcome of performance and will dramatically narrow the span of attention
learning.explanation: Arousal and Performance Arousal is the measure of the human being's readiness to respond. The relationship between arousal and performance is a symmetrical inverted U (performance being on the vertical axis and arousal on the horizontal axis). Increases in arousal will result in the increase of performance, up to a point, called the break point, beyond which further arousal is dysfunctional to the outcome of performance and will dramatically narrow the span of attention. At the optimum arousal level, we are at our most efficient - optimum arousal happens just below the breakpoint. Stress increases along with arousal. Initially, we experience eustress (positive stress) and then distress (negative stress). As previously mentioned, the point of highest performance (optimum arousal or stress) is just below the breakpoint. After this breakpoint, performance decreases as stress becomes overwhelming. However, arousal and stress will still increase.

content.question: The use of check lists should be carried out in such a way that:

options.A: their execution may be done simultaneously with other actions
options.B: their execution should not be done simultaneously with other actions
options.C: they should only be carried out when time is available
options.D: their execution should be combined with other important tasks

key_points: CHECKLISTS Studies of human error rates during simple repetitive tasks have shown that errors can normally be expected on about 1 to 10 occasions
After methodical training, a rate of 1 to 100 is considered to be realistic and pretty good
A checklist can be used to reduce the effects of human memory and attention limitations by ensuring consistency and completeness
learning.explanation: CHECKLISTS Studies of human error rates during simple repetitive tasks have shown that errors can normally be expected on about 1 to 10 occasions. After methodical training, a rate of 1 to 100 is considered to be realistic and pretty good. A checklist can be used to reduce the effects of human memory and attention limitations by ensuring consistency and completeness. In order for a checklist to provide valuable assistance for crew members, certain design criteria should be observed: The most critical items on the task-checklist should be listed as close as possible to the beginning of the task-checklist, in order to increase the likelihood of completing the item before interruptions may occur. The more items a checklist has, the more likely one of them is forgotten. A long checklist should be subdivided to smaller task-checklists or chunks that can be associated with systems and functions within the cockpit. Division of pages should be obtained with protruding thumb locators. Sequencing of checklist items should follow the “geographical” organization of the items in the cockpit, and be performed in a logical flow (panel scan sequence). We note that this guideline could conflict with Nos. 1 above. In most cases where this occurs, this guideline (No. 3) should take precedence. The most critical items should be emphasized by use of colour, bold, italics or upper case. Checklists should be designed in such a way that their execution will not be tightly coupled with other tasks - to ensure maximum attention is devoted to the checklist execution. Check lists should be unambiguous and easy to read, presented in easily understood language.

learning.explanation: Decision-making is a cognitive procedure that leads to the selection of a specific course of action among various potential alternatives. Deciding, in contrast, represents a non-systematic approach to selection, often driven by emotions or personal preferences rather than in-depth understanding. key_points: ICAO defines a Fatigue Risk Management System (FRMS) as: A data-driven means of continuously monitoring and managing fatigue-related safety risks, based upon scientific principles and knowledge as well as operational experience that aims to ensure relevant personnel are performing at adequate levels of alertness
learning.explanation: ICAO defines a Fatigue Risk Management System (FRMS) as: A data-driven means of continuously monitoring and managing fatigue-related safety risks, based upon scientific principles and knowledge as well as operational experience that aims to ensure relevant personnel are performing at adequate levels of alertness.

content.question: A pilot on approach attempts to extend the landing gear, but accidentally extends the flaps instead. What type of error occurred?

options.A: A mistake.
options.B: An action slip.
options.C: A violation.
options.D: Environmental capture.

key_points: TYPES OF HUMAN ERRORS Violations
They are deliberate illegal actions
They are conscious actions in violation of the rules/regulations/procedures
learning.explanation: TYPES OF HUMAN ERRORS Violations. They are deliberate illegal actions. They are conscious actions in violation of the rules/regulations/procedures. Omissions. It is missing out a process or step that should have been included - reading checklists would be one example. Faults. The action meets the operator’s intent, however the intent itself was incorrect. The execution of a drill was 100% accurate but it was the incorrect drill for the task. Slips. These do not meet the operator’s intent, however the intent itself was correct. The correct drill for the task was carried out but wrongly. ⇒ In this case, the pilot committed a slip as their intention to put the landing gear down was correct, however, they instead operated the flap lever.

content.question: A long-term method of stress management must take into consideration:

options.A: Personal stressors, and should remove these stressors.
options.B: Professional and personal stressors, and should address each stressor individually.
options.C: The fact that stress is cumulative and it is difficult to recognise.
options.D: Professional stressors, and should result in major changes to the working conditions.

key_points: According to Lazarus and Folkman, two methods exist to cope with stress
While problem-focused coping aims at targeting the cause of stress, emotion-focused coping relies on reducing the negative emotional responses to stress
The objective of long-term stress management is to reduce the basic level of stress, in order to free more resources to cope with newly occurring acute stressors
learning.explanation: According to Lazarus and Folkman, two methods exist to cope with stress. While problem-focused coping aims at targeting the cause of stress, emotion-focused coping relies on reducing the negative emotional responses to stress. The objective of long-term stress management is to reduce the basic level of stress, in order to free more resources to cope with newly occurring acute stressors. It is important to note that stress is cumulative. Cumulative stress is the sum of the total amount of stressors including their severity and how long they persist for. Anyone experiencing long-term stress can become emotionally exhausted and overwhelmed. Recognising stress can be difficult because it often sneaks up on us. Although there are many symptoms of stress, how it manifests is individual.

content.question: What human attitudes have been found to be particularly hazardous to aviation?

options.A: Anti-authority, macho, invulnerability, complacency, co-operative, impulsivity.
options.B: Anti-authority, impulsivity, invulnerability, macho, resignation, complacency.
options.C: Resignation, shyness, impulsivity, complacency, invulnerability.
options.D: Impulsivity, irascibility, complacency, anti-authority, resignation, invulnerability.

key_points: Learning Objective 040
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 040.03.05.03.01: Explain dangerous attitudes in aviation: anti-authority; macho; impulsivity; invulnerability; complacency; resignation. HAZARDOUS ATTITUDES Studies have identified five hazardous attitudes among pilots that can interfere with a pilot’s ability to make effective decisions. ANTI-AUTHORITY (“don’t tell me”) – You display this attitude if you resent having someone tell you what to do, or you regard rules and procedures as unnecessary. Antidote – Follow the rules. They are usually right. IMPULSIVITY (“do it quickly”) – If you feel the need to act immediately and do the first thing that comes to mind without considering the best solution to a problem, then you are exhibiting impulsivity. Antidote – Not so fast. Think first. INVULNERABILITY (“It won’t happen to me”) – You are more likely to take chances and increase risk if you think accidents will not happen to you. Antidote – It could happen to me. MACHO (“I can do it”) – If you have this attitude, you might take risks trying to prove that you are better than anyone else. Women are just as likely to have this characteristic as men, contrary to some misconceptions. Antidote – Taking chances is foolish. RESIGNATION (“What’s the use?”) – You are experiencing resignation if you feel that no matter what you do, it will have little effect on what happens to you. You may feel that when things go well, it is just good luck and when things go poorly, it is bad luck or someone else is responsible. This feeling can cause you to leave the action to others – for better or worse. Antidote – I am not helpless. I can make a difference. COMPLACENCY ("It's never happened to me before") - The gradual reduction in safety standards, due to the increased experience of the pilot, leading to a lack of awareness of safety risks. Antidote – It hasn't happened to me yet, but it still could.

content.question: Which statement is most important for ensuring good communication?

options.A: The sender should make sure that their message is transported effectively.
options.B: The crew must speak loudly to each other.
options.C: Implicit communication always has to be used to support explicit communication.
options.D: The information must always be coded within professional language.

key_points: This is one of those slightly subjective questions that aren't always easy to answer
You rather have to get in the mindset of the examiner and look for what they want
The feedback we have agrees with our current answer
learning.explanation: This is one of those slightly subjective questions that aren't always easy to answer. You rather have to get in the mindset of the examiner and look for what they want. The feedback we have agrees with our current answer. The communication process typically starts with the sender who initiates the message. Before the sender releases the message, they have to generate the idea and then encode it reasonably so that the receiver can easily understand it. The process of encoding is modulated by the sender's idea of the receiver's competence to decode it. The sender then sends the message, using both verbal and non-verbal communication to transmit more information that the receiver can decode. One of the most important parts about communication is after the message has been sent and received. This is the time at which the receiver will give feedback, either by words, or an expression, gesture, etc. to tell you that the message has been received, and often their understanding of it, which the sender can check. Particularly on the flight deck, where miscommunications can have drastic effects, it is very important for the sender to check for this feedback, to see if the message has been fully transported to the receiver, and if they have understood it correctly. The other options are incorrect, as; Speaking louder is not a good method of communication. Implicit communication our face, body language, tone of voice (non-verbal communications) can be used without the need for explicit communications. Professional language has its place, but sometimes, informal language can be better used to convey a message in a particular way.

content.question: What are the two inputs to a simple model of stress?

options.A: The ease of achieving the task and its usefulness in the scheme of things.
options.B: The value of the task to the pilot and what the pilot can get out of it.
options.C: The value of the task overall and its usefulness in the scheme of things.
options.D: The perceived demand of the task to the pilot and the pilot’s perceived ability to complete the task.

key_points: STRESS Stress disturbs the body’s homeostasis and enables you to adapt to encountered situations
It is the body’s response to a stressor, which is an internal or external stimulus that is interpreted as a threat to the body’s equilibrium, and prepares it for action

Stress is a natural human reaction and it is not always negative! A certain moderate amount of stress is beneficial to human performance - it stops you slowing down and keeps you on your toes – this is the sort associated with success
learning.explanation: STRESS Stress disturbs the body’s homeostasis and enables you to adapt to encountered situations. It is the body’s response to a stressor, which is an internal or external stimulus that is interpreted as a threat to the body’s equilibrium, and prepares it for action. Stress is a natural human reaction and it is not always negative! A certain moderate amount of stress is beneficial to human performance - it stops you slowing down and keeps you on your toes – this is the sort associated with success. Stress is a very subjective matter – every individual is different and stress reactions as well as their magnitudes differ from person to person. The individual level of stress depends on the individual’s subjective perception of available abilities and comparing them to the situational demands. In humans, the physiological reaction to stress is the non-specific “fight or flight” response. This natural reaction prepares you to either flee or protect yourself in dangerous situations.

content.question: What is the correct statement about two-way communication, when compared with one-way communication?

options.A: It is a clear indication of an inappropriate authority gradient between the Commander and Co-Pilot.
options.B: It supports clarity of information transfer and a better social climate among crew members.
options.C: During flight operations it is advised to take place only if time permits or when in cruise flight.
options.D: During flight operations it is limited to the exchange of information with ATC (read-back).

key_points: One-way communication: One-way communication refers to a communication process in which information flows in a single direction, from the sender to the receiver, without any feedback or response from the receiver
It is a linear form of communication where the sender shares information, and the receiver acts as a passive recipient
Two-way communication: Two-way communication, on the other hand, involves an interactive exchange of information between the sender and the receiver
learning.explanation: One-way communication: One-way communication refers to a communication process in which information flows in a single direction, from the sender to the receiver, without any feedback or response from the receiver. It is a linear form of communication where the sender shares information, and the receiver acts as a passive recipient. Two-way communication: Two-way communication, on the other hand, involves an interactive exchange of information between the sender and the receiver. It allows for feedback, questions, and responses from the receiver, creating a dialogue or conversation. Effective communication must be two-way. This enables the transmitter's intentions to be clarified as needed. It is why reading back information on the radio, asking questions when uncertain, and fostering an environment that encourages questioning and critical thinking are essential. Two-way communication ensures that information is effectively conveyed and understood by both the transmitter and the receiver. It allows for clarification and confirmation of messages, reducing the chances of miscommunication or misunderstanding. Two-way communication promotes an atmosphere where all individuals involved in the communication process feel comfortable expressing their thoughts, asking questions, and seeking clarification. This open environment encourages active participation and engagement, leading to better teamwork, cooperation, and mutual understanding among crew members.

content.question: CRM and MCC training are designed to improve:

options.A: The quality of crew performance
options.B: Individual efficiency and contribution
options.C: Individual achievement
options.D: The quality and a number of individuals’ performance

key_points: Crew Resource Management (CRM) will teach techniques for sharing and allocating tasks to prevent any one individual becoming overloaded and will highlight the effective use of all members’ knowledge to increase the range of possible responses
It should improve everyone’s awareness of the situation, and, by combined efforts, allow for the creation of new ideas
Multi-crew Cooperation (MCC) training focus is on learning and showing skills in leadership, teamwork, decision-making and communication
learning.explanation: Crew Resource Management (CRM) will teach techniques for sharing and allocating tasks to prevent any one individual becoming overloaded and will highlight the effective use of all members’ knowledge to increase the range of possible responses. It should improve everyone’s awareness of the situation, and, by combined efforts, allow for the creation of new ideas. Multi-crew Cooperation (MCC) training focus is on learning and showing skills in leadership, teamwork, decision-making and communication. Its aim is to teach novice pilots how to effectively work together in a multi-pilot crew environment and how to adopt synergistic behaviour when on the flight deck. CRM is not so much concerned with the technical knowledge and skills required to fly and operate an aircraft but rather with the cognitive and interpersonal skills needed to manage the flight within an organised aviation system. The relevant aspects of this concept include efficient and effective communication, cross-checking and monitoring procedures, good leadership and knowledge on the concept of pilot flying (PF) and pilot monitoring (PM) as well as associated distribution of tasks => CRM and MCC training are designed to improve the quality of crew performance.
