content.question: Stress Exposure Training (SET) is a method to help pilots manage stress in flight. Pilots are first trained on stress control techniques, then during subsequent flight simulator sessions, the pilot must cope with an external, harmless source of stress while learning a particular skill. Which of the following statements is correct? This type of training:

options.A: Is a short-term stress management method that can improve tolerance to stress in flight operations, if integrated in a continuous professional training programme.
options.B: Programme is a strategy for managing chronic stress, and it can help pilots to cope with all potential stressors in flight in an effective manner and in the long term.
options.C: Is a symptom-directed coping strategy for reducing stress in the long term, improving the capacity of the pilot to modify how he/she reacts to stressors in flight.
options.D: Is a long-term stress management method that can improve performance in flight operations, if integrated in a continuous professional training programme.

key_points: STRESS EXPOSURE TRAINING (SET) In brief, the primary purpose of training is to ensure the acquisition of required knowledge, skills, and abilities
The primary purpose of stress training is to prepare the individual to maintain effective performance in a high-stress environment

Therefore, stress training is defined as an intervention to enhance familiarity with the criterion environment and teach the skills necessary to maintain effective task performance under stress conditions
learning.explanation: STRESS EXPOSURE TRAINING (SET) In brief, the primary purpose of training is to ensure the acquisition of required knowledge, skills, and abilities. The primary purpose of stress training is to prepare the individual to maintain effective performance in a high-stress environment. Therefore, stress training is defined as an intervention to enhance familiarity with the criterion environment and teach the skills necessary to maintain effective task performance under stress conditions. This newly implemented "stress exposure training" shall confront pilots with surprising failures or external developments at some point throughout the simulator session instead of briefing them exactly at which point to expect which particular issue. Stress exposure training is seen as a long-term, problem-focused coping. This form of coping can attenuate the stress a person may experience in a situation, improving his/her ability to act confidently and reasonable.

content.question: What is the phenomenon that occurs within a group of people in which individual members display extreme conformity with the group, resulting in a false agreement, called?

options.A: Group compliance.
options.B: Group conformity.
options.C: Groupfalse.
options.D: Groupthink.

key_points: Groupthink is a phenomenon that occurs when a group of individuals reaches a consensus without critical reasoning or evaluation of the consequences or alternatives
Groupthink is based on a common desire not to upset the balance of a group of people
In many cases, people will set aside their own personal beliefs or adopt the opinion of the rest of the group
learning.explanation: Groupthink is a phenomenon that occurs when a group of individuals reaches a consensus without critical reasoning or evaluation of the consequences or alternatives. Groupthink is based on a common desire not to upset the balance of a group of people. In many cases, people will set aside their own personal beliefs or adopt the opinion of the rest of the group. People who are opposed to the decisions or overriding opinion of the group as a whole frequently remain quiet, preferring to keep the peace rather than disrupt the uniformity of the crowd. Groupthink can cause people to ignore important information and can ultimately lead to poor decisions. This can be damaging even in minor situations but can have much more dire consequences in certain settings.

content.question: Programming of autoflight systems can add to the pilot's workload, and slips can easily occur during such programming. Which of the following methods is the safest to use?

options.A: Rely on the autoflight systems, which identify errors as a result of slips and bring them to the attention of the crew.
options.B: Frequently update the programming to ensure the correct flight path is followed. Cross-checking of programming should be completed after acceptance.
options.C: Avoid programming during critical stages of flight. Cross checking of programming should be completed prior to acceptance.
options.D: Actively monitor the displays throughout the flight and monitor the flight. Slips within the system CANNOT be identified as they are latent in nature.

key_points: The process of programming autoflight systems can be very prone to slips, especially when the pilots are highly mentally loaded during a critical stage of flight
This is why it is recommended that such tasks which increase the workload - like programming automation - are done outside of critical stages of flight whenever possible, to avoid such errors

The other pilot should always cross-check all programming/changes to the automation system prior to acceptance to add a second protective layer against these errors, which can go on unnoticed for a while (latent errors) or could be instantly recognised as a mistake by the crew (e
learning.explanation: The process of programming autoflight systems can be very prone to slips, especially when the pilots are highly mentally loaded during a critical stage of flight. This is why it is recommended that such tasks which increase the workload - like programming automation - are done outside of critical stages of flight whenever possible, to avoid such errors. The other pilot should always cross-check all programming/changes to the automation system prior to acceptance to add a second protective layer against these errors, which can go on unnoticed for a while (latent errors) or could be instantly recognised as a mistake by the crew (e.g. the aircraft starts decending instead of climbing). Another layer of protection against autoflight errors is to constantly monitor the aircraft state through the various displays, as these give an indication of how the automation is programmed (through the Flight Mode Annunciator) and how it is actually behaving (through the standard flying displays, PFD, ND, etc.).

content.question: Which of the scenarios below most clearly describes a situation of one or both pilots being in a state of reduced vigilance?

options.A: During the cruise, the Pilot Monitoring stays silent for several minutes, staring at the instrument panel without moving.
options.B: In heavy turbulence, both pilots are engaged in maintaining flight parameters, and cockpit communications are reduced.
options.C: Just after take-off, the Pilot Flying omits to give the "gear-up" command; the Pilot Monitoring calls out, and then he/she selects the landing gear up.
options.D: Cockpit communications are brief and concise during the cruise on a long-haul flight with good visibility and no turbulence.

key_points: HYPOVIGILANCE Hypo vigilance is a state of reduced vigilance and attention, which reduces, among other, the abilities to direct attention to perform multiple tasks at the same time
Hypovigilance is characterized by a decrease in sensory perception, therefore a higher level of sensory stimulation will be required to get a person’s attention and a sensation of muscular heaviness
Visible signs of reduced vigilance include reduced movements and low muscular tension, which can se seen, for instance, in the fact that the person’s mouth is slightly open
learning.explanation: HYPOVIGILANCE Hypo vigilance is a state of reduced vigilance and attention, which reduces, among other, the abilities to direct attention to perform multiple tasks at the same time. Hypovigilance is characterized by a decrease in sensory perception, therefore a higher level of sensory stimulation will be required to get a person’s attention and a sensation of muscular heaviness. Visible signs of reduced vigilance include reduced movements and low muscular tension, which can se seen, for instance, in the fact that the person’s mouth is slightly open. One can usually observe an increase in time between tow blinks of the eyes (staring). The upper eyelid may be lowered slowly and the person may experience microsleep.

content.question: Stimuli must be of a certain strength for the receptors to pick them up. This is called the sensory..

options.A: threshold.
options.B: volume.
options.C: strength.
options.D: filter.

key_points: SENSORY THRESHOLD The senses, sight, hearing, taste, smell and touch provide inputs (stimuli) to our brain
Stimuli must be of a certain strength for the sensory receptors to pick them up
In psychophysics, sensory threshold is the weakest stimulus that an organism can detect
learning.explanation: SENSORY THRESHOLD The senses, sight, hearing, taste, smell and touch provide inputs (stimuli) to our brain. Stimuli must be of a certain strength for the sensory receptors to pick them up. In psychophysics, sensory threshold is the weakest stimulus that an organism can detect. The point at which a stimulus causes a sensation within an individual; below the sensory threshold, there will be no sensation. Raising the perceptual threshold of a particular sensory organ will lead to a lower sensitivity. Thus, higher intensity of stimulation will be required to detect the stimulation

content.question: What is an advantage of standard operating procedures (SOPs)?

options.A: SOPs reduce the required amount of crew training by providing inexperienced pilots with an action plan.
options.B: SOPs provide a shared reference framework for all crew members and promote crew synergy.
options.C: SOPs ensure that the best suitable solution for a task at hand is always found.
options.D: SOPs can make it easier for pilots to change employers or aircraft types.

key_points: STANDARD OPERATING PROCEDURES (SOPs) Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs) fall into two categories, the first of which identifies a core of mandatory actions or procedures that must always be performed because the failure to do so has a direct adverse impact on the safety of operation
These SOPs include formal items such as Standard Call-outs, altimeter setting and checking procedures, emergency drills, and non-exceedance of limitations

The second category of standard operating procedure has the purpose of standardising procedures to make it possible to crew any two Flight Crew members together on a non-regular basis without lowering safety standards
learning.explanation: STANDARD OPERATING PROCEDURES (SOPs) Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs) fall into two categories, the first of which identifies a core of mandatory actions or procedures that must always be performed because the failure to do so has a direct adverse impact on the safety of operation. These SOPs include formal items such as Standard Call-outs, altimeter setting and checking procedures, emergency drills, and non-exceedance of limitations. The second category of standard operating procedure has the purpose of standardising procedures to make it possible to crew any two Flight Crew members together on a non-regular basis without lowering safety standards. The consequential requirement is that personal methods or practices shall not be introduced. The bottom line is: SOPs provide for enhanced morale between crew members that is often caused by doing things differently. For pilots who are in training, or new to the company, they will help to ensure faster integration. SOPs provide a shared reference framework for all crew members and promote crew synergy.

content.question: How would you describe the leadership style of a captain who primarily is interested in a friendly atmosphere within his crew, who is always constructive and encouraging, who usually compromises in interpersonal conflicts, who trusts in the capabilities of his crew-members, and who leaves the crew freedom for own decisions?

options.A: High task-orientation and low relationship-orientation
options.B: Low task-orientation and high relationship-orientation
options.C: High task-orientation and high relationship-orientation
options.D: Low task-orientation and low relationship-orientation

key_points: According to a study conducted at Ohio State University by Robert R
Blake and Jane Mouton, leadership styles can be characterized by two dimensions; Task-orientation and Relationship-orientation
Relationship-orientation: Relationship-oriented leaders are primarily focused on supporting, motivating and developing individuals and teams through collaborative working
learning.explanation: According to a study conducted at Ohio State University by Robert R. Blake and Jane Mouton, leadership styles can be characterized by two dimensions; Task-orientation and Relationship-orientation. Relationship-orientation: Relationship-oriented leaders are primarily focused on supporting, motivating and developing individuals and teams through collaborative working. Relationship-oriented leaders seek to establish meaningful relationships with their staff. He/she tends to first consider how others will feel and only then he will consider getting the task done. Task-orientation: Perhaps the most concise definition of task-oriented leadership is “doing whatever it takes to get the job done.” The first consideration is given to the task or goal in the decision-making process. The approach tends to be autocratic and emphasizes completing tasks required to meet organizational goals. An ideal professional pilot should be able to move between task and relationship depending on the situation and person involved. An effective leader must have the ability and willingness to switch between task behaviour and relationship behaviour when the situation calls for it. He/she will therefore find the appropriate and correct balance between relationship and task orientation style. In this case, the question clearly states that he is "primarily interested in a friendly atmosphere within his crew". This should tell us that, in doubt, he will pay more attention to happiness of his crew members than to the quick completion of tasks => Relationship-oriented.

content.question: Which of the following is an example of the disadvantage of automation on crew communication?

options.A: Both aural and visual alerts reduce the need for crew communication.
options.B: A lot of raw data are available to the pilots, which has the negative effect of reducing the need for crew to communicate.
options.C: Visual indications of systems mean that crew cannot communicate properly.
options.D: Aural indications of systems mean that crew cannot communicate properly.

key_points: Considering that automated systems greatly reduce cockpit workload, it should be assumed that they allow for better crew communication and coordination
Unfortunately, the opposite is often true

Both the aural and visual alerts can be perceived to reduce the need for crew communication, as every relevant deviation is reported by the automation and effective cross-checking and callouts are sometimes neglected
learning.explanation: Considering that automated systems greatly reduce cockpit workload, it should be assumed that they allow for better crew communication and coordination. Unfortunately, the opposite is often true. Both the aural and visual alerts can be perceived to reduce the need for crew communication, as every relevant deviation is reported by the automation and effective cross-checking and callouts are sometimes neglected. The reduced necessity for communication can make it difficult for the other pilot to detect an erraneous entry. Consequently, he or she may be surprised by aircraft performance or may be unable to detect and understand the cause of an error. In the worst case, this could probably even result in loss of situational awareness, when a pilot is not sufficiently informed about the aircraft status or position. Note: What is (presumably) meant is that pilots may FEEL that the need for communication and cross-check is reduced because the system will alert them to all undesired conditions.

content.question: In terms of decision-making, the intention to become integrated into the team, to be recognised as the leader or to avoid conflicts may lead to:

options.A: the improvement of internal risk assessment capabilities
options.B: a fast and decisive option
options.C: the attempt to agree on decisions made by other crew members
options.D: an authoritarian approach thus demonstrating ones own ability to lead

key_points: GROUPS Groups behave differently from individuals
That is to say, a person may carry out different actions in concert with others than would be done solo
The behaviour of a group can be affected by a number of factors including: Persuasion
learning.explanation: GROUPS Groups behave differently from individuals. That is to say, a person may carry out different actions in concert with others than would be done solo. The behaviour of a group can be affected by a number of factors including: Persuasion. Refers to the process of changing attitudes, opinions and behaviours of other group members. In contrast to negotiation, which implies retreating and meeting somewhere in the middle, persuasion means to make people completely abandon their point of view to accept the persuader's one. Pilots should not suppress opinions which could lead to a better outcome. Conformity. Concerns the likelihood of an individual to go along with a group decision. The idea of being integrated into the team, to be recognised as a leader, or to avoid conflicts, may lead to a disposition to agree with decisions made by others. This tendency increases when new people enter an existing group. This poses the threat for the group to lose valuable input, as it becomes difficult to voice an alternate opinion. Compliance. Compliant behaviour is shown in groups when requested by another group memeber or the leader. The aim being to be socially accepted, receive a reward or avoid punishment. Obedience. Being obedient means following the orders of someone with a higher social status just because the orders were given. Crew members should remain prepared to challenge orders if they are believed to be suboptimal.

content.question: The level of automation helps to conserve resources. On the other hand, it may result in:

options.A: routine errors (slips)
options.B: decision-making errors
options.C: behavioural errors
options.D: errors in selecting an appropriate plan of action

key_points: Cockpit automation has the potential to increase or decrease the flight safety, depending on how well you use the equipment
Automation can conserve resources and attention, relieving pilot workload and giving time for supervision

Although automation generally improves the safety record, it can result in routine errors, or slips, such as when programming waypoints into the system or keeping track of the aircraft status and position
learning.explanation: Cockpit automation has the potential to increase or decrease the flight safety, depending on how well you use the equipment. Automation can conserve resources and attention, relieving pilot workload and giving time for supervision. Although automation generally improves the safety record, it can result in routine errors, or slips, such as when programming waypoints into the system or keeping track of the aircraft status and position. If the automation systems are given too much control, the cockpit becomes boring, and errors can go unnoticed amongst the monotony.

content.question: What coping mechanism can be used to reduce both psychological and physiological stressors?

options.A: Relaxation techniques.
options.B: Emotion-focused coping.
options.C: Problem-focused coping.
options.D: Cognitive reappraisal.

key_points: Stress management techniques can fall into two categories: problem-focused coping and emotion-focused coping
Problem-focused coping strategies aim to eliminate sources of stress or work with the stressors themselves
This strategy can be used to reduce both psychological and physiological stress
learning.explanation: Stress management techniques can fall into two categories: problem-focused coping and emotion-focused coping. Problem-focused coping strategies aim to eliminate sources of stress or work with the stressors themselves. This strategy can be used to reduce both psychological and physiological stress. Emotion-focused coping focuses on regulating negative emotional reactions to stress such as anxiety, fear, sadness, and anger. This type of coping may be useful when a stressor is something that you cannot change. Effective method to reduce psychological stress, however not suitable for removing physiological stressors.

content.question: Which of the following statements fits best the concept of latent error?

options.A: Latent errors are rarely made by front-line operators, and are consequently readily identified and detected by the monitoring, detection and warning links.
options.B: Latent errors are detected rapidly.
options.C: Latent errors are mainly associated with the behaviour of front-line operators and are only detected after advanced problem-solving.
options.D: Latent errors are hard to identify because they can lie dormant for a long period of time before consequences of the errors are felt.

key_points: ACTIVE AND LATENT ERRORS An error, officially, arises when a planned sequence of activities fails to achieve the intended outcome, where random external intervention is not involved
The terms active and latent as applied to errors were coined by Reason

Latent errors have consequences that lie dormant and are difficult to recognize or foresee because of the time lag between their generation and occurrence, while active errors, which are committed at the human/system interface, have consequences that are felt almost immediately, which is how they can be detected
learning.explanation: ACTIVE AND LATENT ERRORS An error, officially, arises when a planned sequence of activities fails to achieve the intended outcome, where random external intervention is not involved. The terms active and latent as applied to errors were coined by Reason. Latent errors have consequences that lie dormant and are difficult to recognize or foresee because of the time lag between their generation and occurrence, while active errors, which are committed at the human/system interface, have consequences that are felt almost immediately, which is how they can be detected. Active errors are committed by the “sharp end”, those people who are directly involved in flight operations (pilots, ATC, etc). Latent errors are usually committed by the blunt-end, people who are not directly engaged in flight operations. However, latent errors can also be made by front-line personnel. An example of a latent error committed by a pilot would be the selection of a wrong waypoint in a GPS database.

key_points: PERCEPTION Perception is the process of giving meaning to what is sensed, or interpreting, organising and elaborating on the input, discarding anything non-relevant
Sensory stimulation is the first stage in the information process, and the basis of perception is the intensity of the stimulus

learning.explanation: PERCEPTION Perception is the process of giving meaning to what is sensed, or interpreting, organising and elaborating on the input, discarding anything non-relevant. Sensory stimulation is the first stage in the information process, and the basis of perception is the intensity of the stimulus. Perception therefore happens in the brain, after a stimulus has been detected by the sense organs. What each individual perceives results from interplays between past experiences and the interpretation of the perceived. It is important to note that perception is highly resistant to correction and can be persuasive. Once you are convinced that you have found the correct interpretation for your perceptions, your brain tends to adjust your new perceptions to your mental picture of the situation. American Airlines Flight in 1997: The aircraft was in a holding pattern. The airborne weather radar showed heavy precipitation in the vicinity of the holding point. Busy assessing the weather ahead, the crew did not notice that they had accidently pulled back the throttle levers (below the auto throttle minimum), causing the auto throttle to disengage. The airspeed decreased and, once again, the crew failed to notice this indication. Upon experiencing aerodynamic stall buffet, the crew interpreted it as turbulence. As the aircraft stalled, the crew assumed they were facing wind shear and performed the wind shear escape manoeuvre. They were able to recover and land safely. They were only made aware that the aircraft had stalled by the NTSB inspectors.

options.B: a tendency to ignore that information which indicates that a hypothesis or decision is poor

key_points: CONFIRMATION BIAS Confirmation Bias is the term used to describe the tendency to search for information to confirm a theory, while overlooking contradicting information
Thus, even if presented with facts which would allow correcting the mental model, a pilot will probably find it difficult to get out of his original interpretation
It can be likened to making the ground fit the map, rather than accepting the fact that we are lost
learning.explanation: CONFIRMATION BIAS Confirmation Bias is the term used to describe the tendency to search for information to confirm a theory, while overlooking contradicting information. Thus, even if presented with facts which would allow correcting the mental model, a pilot will probably find it difficult to get out of his original interpretation. It can be likened to making the ground fit the map, rather than accepting the fact that we are lost. You could also look upon it as a tendency to ignore information that confirms a decision is a poor one. A good strategy to avoid confirmation bias is to actively search for information that could falsify the mental model of the current situation or for different interpretations of the given information.

key_points: MEMORY Short-Term Memory (STM), also referred to as Working Memory, is a temporary storage system responsible for holding a limited amount of information for a short duration
STM allows us to retain and manipulate recently perceived or retrieved information, keeping it available for immediate use
This type of memory allows us to hold onto information for a brief period and will be forgotten within 10 to 20 seconds if not actively rehearsed and consciously transferred into our long-term memory
learning.explanation: MEMORY Short-Term Memory (STM), also referred to as Working Memory, is a temporary storage system responsible for holding a limited amount of information for a short duration. STM allows us to retain and manipulate recently perceived or retrieved information, keeping it available for immediate use. This type of memory allows us to hold onto information for a brief period and will be forgotten within 10 to 20 seconds if not actively rehearsed and consciously transferred into our long-term memory. Our STM has a limited capacity. It can typically hold a maximum of about 7 ± 2 unrelated items. Once this capacity is exceeded, it becomes likely that one or more of the items will be lost or mixed up. STM is also highly sensitive to interruptions. Long-Term Memory (LTM) is the second type of memory. When information in the short-term memory is rehearsed, it is transferred into the long-term memory. Our LTM has unlimited capacity. Information stored in LTM can be retained indefinitely, although there may be difficulties in retrieving it. One significant drawback is the time it takes to access this information, if not regurarly rehearsed. LTM consists of information that can be categorized into three distinct types: 1. Semantic memory 2. Episodic memory 3. Procedural memory

key_points: SITUATIONAL AWARENESS This is the ability to accurately perceive what is happening in- and outside the aircraft, plus the ability to understand the meaning of different elements in the environment and the projection of their status in the near future (where the aircraft is, where it has been, and where it is going)

learning.explanation: SITUATIONAL AWARENESS This is the ability to accurately perceive what is happening in- and outside the aircraft, plus the ability to understand the meaning of different elements in the environment and the projection of their status in the near future (where the aircraft is, where it has been, and where it is going). To do this successfully, you have to know how things should be to recognize what’s wrong. More simply, situational awareness means that the pilot’s idea of a situation equals reality. The process of achieving situational awareness consists of: Perceiving objects in the environment – Monitor; Understanding their meaning and impact – Evaluate; Correct prediction of changes to the environment and the future state of the objects for a sufficient period of time – Anticipate.

learning.explanation: SYNERGY Synergy describes a cooperation of creatures, matter or forces in terms of mutual support. In simple words, it is the state where the group performance exceeds the sum of the individual performances (“the whole is more than the sum of its parts”). Synergy can be expressed as a simple mathematical statement: (considering a crew of two) 1 + 1 = > 2 When the group performance is less than the sum of individual performances, synergy is said to be poor and can be mathematically expressed as follows: 1 + 1 = < 2 The most critical moment for development of synergy among the crew is the pre-flight briefing. The captain (the designated leader) should take the opportunity to emphasize that all crew members working on the aircraft form one crew. Synergy should then be maintained until the end of the duty period. A non-synergetic cockpit will most likely lead to unclear communication and crew members withdrawn.

learning.explanation: STRESS Stress disturbs the body’s homeostasis and enables you to adapt to encountered situations. It is the body’s response to a stressor, which is an internal or external stimulus that is interpreted as a threat to the body’s equilibrium, and prepares it for action. In human psychology, stress refers to the excessive amount of stress that affects attention, memory, judgement and concentration. Stress is a very subjective matter – every individual is different and stress reactions as well as their magnitudes differ from person to person. The individual level of stress depends on the individual’s subjective perception of available abilities and comparing them to the situational demands. In humans, the physiological reaction to stress is the non-specific “fight or flight” response. This natural reaction prepares you to either flee or protect yourself in dangerous situations.

learning.explanation: Stress can be overwhelming. An overstressed pilot may show mental blocks, confusion, channelized attention, resignation, frustration, rage, and deterioration in motor coordination. To avoid such situations, one should be ahead of the game by anticipating - “if this happens, I will do XX”. It is good to anticipate possible scenarios and threats that could arise during the flight. This will reduce the surprise factor if something does happen. Anticipating what might happen is not enough. It is important that once all reasonable scenarios and threats are identified, a sound plan for dealing with them is made on the ground before flight. Sometimes, even if you anticipate and plan, you may still find yourself in an overwhelming situation. To successfully manage this, you should make the best use of any resource available to you, which include your own body (physical and psychological factors), information, equipment, other people (fellow crew member, ATC) and automation. An important procedure is the careful distribution of tasks in the cockpit and other resources, such as onboard equipment and ATC, cab always help by providing information and advice that will help you deal with the situation and reduce stress levels. It is also paramount to prioritize tasks - rate tasks by how important or urgent they are and get the most critical ones done first. Emergencies must also be rehearsed because, when under stress, you may revert to former training.

key_points: Learning Objective 040
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 040.03.03.01.09: Describe the positive and negative influences exerted by other group members on an individual’s decision-making process (risky shift). Risky shift is a phenomenon in which a group of individuals tends to make riskier decisions collectively compared to the average risk preference of individual group members. In other words, when people make decisions as a group, they often lean towards adopting a riskier course of action than they would have taken individually. This shift towards greater risk-taking can occur due to several factors, such as diffusion of responsibility, social comparison, and the desire to conform to group norms or maintain harmony within the group. The group dynamic and the influence of others can amplify individual risk preferences and lead to a collective inclination towards riskier choices. Regarding this question, a group of 3 pilots will tend to make riskier decisions than the decisions the pilots would make individually if the aircraft was a single-pilot aircraft.

learning.explanation: DECISION A decision is supposed to be the end result of a chain of events involving judgement, after which you choose between alternatives. It can be defined as the conscious choice between different possible solutions for achieving a goal. Some steps involved with making a decision are to: Gather all relevant information and analyze the facts (objective criteria). Analyze alternatives, keeping situational awareness and using risk assessment. Compare the situation with previous situation encountered (subjective criteria). When in haste, correct analysis may be bypassed in favour of a decision prepared beforehand. Decide and do – make your choice and act on it, although other factors may affect the quality of your decision and your ability to implement it. Evaluate the outcome – and be prepared to start all over again. The aim of decision making is normally unambiguous however, the personal preference of options to achieve that aim will be influenced by a host of variables, such as the personality and biases of the decision maker.

content.question:
If aeronautical decision making is performed correctly, the choice of a solution will depend on which of the following?
1. The risks associated with each option.
2. The hierarchical position of the person making a suggestion.
3. The objective to be achieved.
4. The performance capability of crew members.
5. Any time constraints.
6. The interpersonal relationships among crew members.

key_points: Aeronautical decision making is a very important part of being a pilot
Decision making is often taught to follow a specific method, such as TDODAR, PIOSEE or GRADE
These methods allow for the information to be gathered (including time available to take action) and the problem to be assessed, setting an objective
learning.explanation: Aeronautical decision making is a very important part of being a pilot. Decision making is often taught to follow a specific method, such as TDODAR, PIOSEE or GRADE. These methods allow for the information to be gathered (including time available to take action) and the problem to be assessed, setting an objective. The options are then considered, with a quick analysis of each, including the associated risks, the benefits, the potential time taken, the capability of the crew and aircraft to perform the action, commercial factors, etc. Then a decision is made, actions are taken, and the decision and actions are continuously reviewed then for changes or improvements, until the issue is solved. The hierarchy of the crew should not affect the strength of a suggestion, as each suggestion is potentially valid, and should be analysed as such (of course the Commander must make the final decision in most cases). The interpersonal relationships should be a non-factor, as crew should use SOPs to dictate their actions and communications, and therefore interpersonal relationships are not important, particularly when in a bad situation. Bad relationships should be put aside, if they exist.

content.question: As a commander, which of the following attributes is most important to develop within a flight crew?

options.A: Groupthink
options.B: Cohesion
options.C: Risky Shift
options.D: Dominance

key_points: Let's go through each option: "Groupthink" Groupthink is a phenomenon that occurs when a group of individuals reaches a consensus without critical reasoning or evaluation of the consequences or alternatives
Groupthink is based on a common desire not to upset the balance of a group of people
In many cases, people will set aside their own personal beliefs or adopt the opinion of the rest of the group
learning.explanation: Let's go through each option: "Groupthink" Groupthink is a phenomenon that occurs when a group of individuals reaches a consensus without critical reasoning or evaluation of the consequences or alternatives. Groupthink is based on a common desire not to upset the balance of a group of people. In many cases, people will set aside their own personal beliefs or adopt the opinion of the rest of the group. This can have a negative impact on a group, leading to a lack of criticism of potentially bad decisions. "Cohesion" Correct. Group cohesion is the linking of group members with a common objective. It generally goes hand-in-hand with a shared attitude towards problems and is based upon the mutual motivation of the crew towards the job. It can have major advantages in difficult situations over a non-cohesive group. "Risky Shift" Risky shift is a commonly observed phenomenon that occurs when people change their decisions or opinions to become more extreme and risky when acting as part of a group, compared with acting individually. This is obviously not good for aviation. "Dominance" Whilst the commander should be the one who makes the final decisions and leads the crew, it is not good for them to assert too much dominance, as this can lead to the rest of the team feeling worried to speak up on issues, or challenge bad decisions, etc.

content.question: We generate Mental Models on..

options.A: past experience and learning.
options.B: imagination.
options.C: stereopsis.
options.D: 3-D vision.

key_points: MENTAL MODEL A mental model is an explanation of how something works
We generate a mental model on the basis of past experience and learning
Our mental models help shape our behaviour and define our approach to solving problems and carrying out tasks
learning.explanation: MENTAL MODEL A mental model is an explanation of how something works. We generate a mental model on the basis of past experience and learning. Our mental models help shape our behaviour and define our approach to solving problems and carrying out tasks. The value of these models is that they can reduce the need to attend to all inputs. For instance, the experienced aviator, with his/her mental model of the order of information in an RT message and his/her expectation of the potential content, will have far fewer problems understanding the information than a novice. However, in this lies the danger of expectation. For example, if a pilot is regularly cleared to cross a particular runway during operations at a familiar aerodrome, he/she may come to “expect” the clearance. This could cause a potentially dangerous situation if on a particular day, the pilot actually is instructed not to cross the runway in question due to another aircraft landing or taking off. An inherent danger in this system is that, having built a mental model, we will tend to seek only information that confirms our model (confirmation bias) and ignore other information that may cast doubt on its accuracy.

content.question:
The analysis of aviation accidents distinguishes between active and latent failures.
Which of the following scenarios is an example of a latent failure?

options.A: After the leading aircraft slows down more than anticipated on final approach, the air traffic controller realizes too late that minimum separation was violated.
options.B: The airline management decides to cut costs in all departments, including the flight training department, due to the global economic downturn.
options.C: The pilot correctly reads back the new altitude assignment during an en&route climb but proceeds to set it incorrectly in the autopilot’s mode control panel.
options.D: The aircraft technician fails to follow all the steps on the job card and forgets to reconnect the altimeter’s static port during a routine maintenance check.

key_points: ACTIVE AND LATENT FAILURES Typically, latent failures existed in the regulations, management, resources, policies and company culture

They are present in the system well before an accident (will have consequences in the future) and are most likely bred by decision-makers, regulators, and other people far removed in time and space from the event
Conflicting goals and bad management decisions unknowingly create the conditions under which the latentfailures can reveal themselves
learning.explanation: ACTIVE AND LATENT FAILURES Typically, latent failures existed in the regulations, management, resources, policies and company culture. They are present in the system well before an accident (will have consequences in the future) and are most likely bred by decision-makers, regulators, and other people far removed in time and space from the event. Conflicting goals and bad management decisions unknowingly create the conditions under which the latentfailures can reveal themselves. Active failures are related to direct supervision, scheduling, use of resources, time management, and communication. Active failures are errors and violations having immediate negative results and are usually caused by an individual. Active failures created by the individual include: omission of a checklist item use of wrong procedures not following procedures not completing a final system check properly not double checking lack of skill and knowledge In short, an active failure equals - human error, sometimes referred to - operator error. Whilst a latent failure is a management failure, which could be a lack of training, supervision, proper procedures, wrong or faulty equipment and so on. Note: “The aircraft technician fails to follow all the steps on the job card and forgets to reconnect the altimeter’s static port during a routine maintenance check.” INCORRECT. This is an active error which will be immediately recognized by the crew.

content.question:
An aircraft operating with the FMS in the LNAV VNAV mode is operating in a busy terminal area at the end of a flight. Bad weather in the area has resulted in ATC requiring the flight crew to make several changes to the aircraft's flight path.

In order to maintain the maximum awareness of their flight status, what is the best action for the pilots to take?

options.A: The FMS in LNAV VNAV mode is the primary, and most accurate, navigation system available to the pilots, and its use should be maintained. In order to minimise data entry errors, both pilots should check the entry of the new LNAV/VNAV parameters at the same time.
options.B: Re-programming of the FMS in the LNAV VNAV mode during periods of high workload can lead to errors and also cause a loss of situational awareness. Therefore, the pilots should downgrade to a lower, simpler level of automation such as ALT/HDG or even to manual flying.
options.C: The main risk is that the pilots become distracted while re-programming the FMS. To reduce this risk, the Pilot-in- Command should immediately request a short delay or a hold, in order to complete the entry of the new LNAV VNAV parameters, before continuing with the approach.
options.D: In order to mitigate against loss of situational awareness, and avoid the risk of errors while entering new data, the FMS should be switched off, and the pilots should respond to ATC instructions by flying the aircraft manually.

key_points: In addition to their aircraft control tasks, the Pilot Flying (PF) takes responsibility for navigation and the Pilot Monitoring (PM) takes responsibility for communication and systems operation
During normal operations, the procedures and tasks for the PF and PM in the various flight phases are well described and evenly distributed
With good use of the available automation, the level of workload is such that spare capacity to maintain situational awareness is available
learning.explanation: In addition to their aircraft control tasks, the Pilot Flying (PF) takes responsibility for navigation and the Pilot Monitoring (PM) takes responsibility for communication and systems operation. During normal operations, the procedures and tasks for the PF and PM in the various flight phases are well described and evenly distributed. With good use of the available automation, the level of workload is such that spare capacity to maintain situational awareness is available. However if an unexpected situation occurs which requires extra attention, the workload can increase considerably. When there is intense workload, instead of immediate reprogramming, pilots are advised to reduce the level of automation to a more basic mode. This way, the negative effects of automation on pilots may be alleviated by degrading to a lower level of automation to recover comprehension of the flight status from VNAV/LNAV to ALT/HDG or even to manual flying. Note: downgrading automation is a good idea, however reverting to manual flight would use up too many resources during an approach to a busy airport. However, EASA seems to include "manual flight" in their correct answer. In our opinion, flying manually would only be an option in case of a suspected malfunction of automated systems.

content.question: In case of in-flight stress, one should..

options.A: always carry out a breathing exercise.
options.B: use all available resources of the crew.
options.C: demonstrate aggressiveness to stimulate the crew.
options.D: only trust in oneself and know one’s personal limits.

key_points: Stress can be overwhelming
An overstressed pilot may show mental blocks, confusion, channelized attention, resignation, frustration, rage, and deterioration in motor coordination
To avoid such situations, one should be ahead of the game by anticipating - “if this happens, I will do XX”
learning.explanation: Stress can be overwhelming. An overstressed pilot may show mental blocks, confusion, channelized attention, resignation, frustration, rage, and deterioration in motor coordination. To avoid such situations, one should be ahead of the game by anticipating - “if this happens, I will do XX”. It is good to anticipate possible scenarios and threats that could arise during the flight. This will reduce the surprise factor if something does happen. Anticipating what might happen is not enough. It is important that once all reasonable scenarios and threats are identified, a sound plan for dealing with them is made on the ground before flight. Sometimes, even if you anticipate and plan, you may still find yourself in an overwhelming situation. To successfully manage this, you should make the best use of any resource available to you, which include your own body (physical and psychological factors), information, equipment, other people (fellow crew member, ATC) and automation. An important procedure is the careful distribution of tasks in the cockpit and other resources, such as onboard equipment and ATC, cab always help by providing information and advice that will help you deal with the situation and reduce stress levels. It is also paramount to prioritize tasks - rate tasks by how important or urgent they are and get the most critical ones done first. Emergencies must also be rehearsed because, when under stress, you may revert to former training.

content.question:
What is the purpose of multi crew training?
1. arousal control
2. situational awareness
3. crew coordination
4. cross checking
5. crew communication
6. controlling Error possibility

key_points: IMPORTANT NOTE: This question was generated based on partial feedback
The student provided statements 1, 2, 3, and 4, while 5 and 6 were introduced by us
If anyone encounters this question during their official examination, kindly inform us
learning.explanation: IMPORTANT NOTE: This question was generated based on partial feedback. The student provided statements 1, 2, 3, and 4, while 5 and 6 were introduced by us. If anyone encounters this question during their official examination, kindly inform us. We appreciate your assistance. Thank you! Multi-crew training is primarily focused on enhancing crew communication skills among flight personnel working together in the cockpit. This involves effective interaction, coordination, and communication between the pilot and co-pilot or other crew members. "Situational Awareness": This refers to the ability of the flight crew to have a clear understanding of their environment, including the aircraft's position, current situation, and potential risks. Effective multi-crew training improves the crew's ability to gather, process, and maintain situational awareness. "Crew Communication": Clear and efficient communication among the flight crew is crucial to ensure that everyone understands their roles, tasks, and the current situation. Multi-crew training focuses on developing effective communication techniques, using standardized procedures to convey information accurately and promptly. "Cross Checking": Cross checking involves verifying critical information through multiple sources. Flight crew members work together to confirm the accuracy of data, settings, and actions. Multi-crew training emphasizes the importance of cross checking to prevent errors and improve overall safety. "Crew Coordination": Crew coordination involves the harmonious interaction between various crew members, including pilots, flight engineers, and other relevant personnel. Effective coordination ensures that everyone is on the same page, contributing to smooth operations and prompt decision-making. The option "arousal control" does not directly align with the primary goals of multi-crew training. Arousal control pertains to managing stress and maintaining a focused state, this is important but is not the primary focus of multi-crew training.

content.question: The Pilot Monitoring (PM) and Pilot Flying (PF) are good friends and have worked together many times. The PF is junior to the PM and respects and trusts him/her greatly. The PF decides not to call out all the required SOPs when using the aircrafts advanced cockpit automation as the PF feels they are excessive. This can lead to:

options.A: A relaxed environment, allowing both crew to monitor more efficiently their work areas, leading to a better awareness of flight modes, the ability to detect errors more easily, and to better understand the aircraft status.
options.B: Loss of crew communication, leading to loss of awareness of flight modes, input errors NOT being detected, lack of failure detection, and comprehension of the aircraft's status.
options.C: An increase in crew communications, thanks to the high levels of automation, allowing the crew to focus their attention on other flight elements.
options.D: A more synergistic flight crew compartment, as the comfort, confidence and experience of the crew ensures safer operations.

key_points: Crew Resource Management (CRM) and Team Resource Management (TRM) are not effective without adherence to SOPs, because SOPs provide a standard reference for the ATC team and for the crew’s tasks on the flight deck

Even when crew members know each other very well, following Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs) is crucial so that actions are always completed in the same sequence, reducing the probability of missing a step and loss of situational awareness

Plus, SOPs can reduce friction between crew members which might result from the fact that a co-pilot is forced to perform a certain task to the captain’s preference while he/she would probably rather do it differently
learning.explanation: Crew Resource Management (CRM) and Team Resource Management (TRM) are not effective without adherence to SOPs, because SOPs provide a standard reference for the ATC team and for the crew’s tasks on the flight deck. Even when crew members know each other very well, following Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs) is crucial so that actions are always completed in the same sequence, reducing the probability of missing a step and loss of situational awareness. Plus, SOPs can reduce friction between crew members which might result from the fact that a co-pilot is forced to perform a certain task to the captain’s preference while he/she would probably rather do it differently. If the pilot monitoring is not providing any feedback or making any calls, it is very likely that he/she will eventually be out of the loop and loss of awareness of flight modes will become evident. It is important to note that when pilot does not conform to SOP’s he/she should be expected to be challenged by the other pilot. Failure to respond appropriately to 2 or more SOP deviation calls by the other pilot will lead them to assume he/she has become incapacitated and will assume control of the aircraft.

Hypoglycemia is a condition in which your blood sugar (glucose) level is lower than normal. When the body doesn't receive enough sugar or glucose for energy, brain cells can't function properly. content.question:
Which option is correct as regards the following statement? During the conflict-resolution process it is important to:
1. realise but be indifferent to the conflict,
2. verbalise mutual expectations,
3. search for common agreements,
4. express one’s own viewpoint.

options.C: 3 and 4 only
options.D: 1 and 3 only

key_points: CONFLICT MANAGEMENT Conflict management is the process by which disputes are resolved, where negative results are minimized and positive results are prioritized
This key management skill involves using different tactics depending on the situation, negotiation, and creative thinking
With properly managed conflict, an organization is able to minimize interpersonal issues, enhance client satisfaction, and produce better business outcomes
learning.explanation: CONFLICT MANAGEMENT Conflict management is the process by which disputes are resolved, where negative results are minimized and positive results are prioritized. This key management skill involves using different tactics depending on the situation, negotiation, and creative thinking. With properly managed conflict, an organization is able to minimize interpersonal issues, enhance client satisfaction, and produce better business outcomes. Some effective conflict-resolution techniques include: Acknowledging that a difficult situation exists and active listening. Honesty and clear communication play an important role in the resolution process. Acquaint yourself with what's happening and be open about the problem. It is also important to have the desire to understand the different point of view of the other person. Determining the underlying need. The goal of conflict resolution is not to decide which person is right or wrong; the goal is to reach a solution that everyone can live with. Looking first for needs, rather than solutions, is a powerful tool for generating win/win options. To discover needs, you must try to find out why people want the solutions they initially proposed. Once you understand the advantages their solutions have for them, you have discovered their needs. Find common areas of agreement and express mutual expectations, no matter how small: Agree on the problem Agree on the procedure to follow Agree on worst fears Agree on some small change to give an experience of success "1. realise but be indifferent to the conflict" Incorrect. Avoiding is when people just ignore or withdraw from the conflict. They choose this method when the discomfort of confrontation exceeds the potential reward of resolution of the conflict. While this might seem easy to accommodate for the facilitator, people aren’t really contributing anything of value to the conversation and may be withholding worthwhile ideas. When conflict is avoided, nothing is resolved.
