options.D: unstable.

key_points: Personality is based on heredity, childhood, upbringing and experience
It could be defined as the unique organisation of characteristics which determine the typical or standard behaviour of an individual toward the outside world
Personality is believed to be genetically predetermined
learning.explanation: Personality is based on heredity, childhood, upbringing and experience. It could be defined as the unique organisation of characteristics which determine the typical or standard behaviour of an individual toward the outside world. Personality is believed to be genetically predetermined. Once it is formed, it is rather stable and generally not as prone to change as attitude and behaviour. Although personality is less prone to change, it develops throughout life due to learning processes and experience.

content.question: With which risk is skill based behaviour associated?

options.A: Error of commission
options.B: Confirmation bias
options.C: Action Slip
options.D: Deviation from standard operating procedures

key_points: According to Rasmussen, three levels of behaviour with respect to the performance of tasks and problem-solving can be isolated, in which errors can occur
Rasmussen introduced the “SRK” model which consists of: S = Skill-based behaviour R = Rule-based behaviour K = Knowledge-based behaviour Skill-based behaviour
This behaviour is shown when performing skills
learning.explanation: According to Rasmussen, three levels of behaviour with respect to the performance of tasks and problem-solving can be isolated, in which errors can occur. Rasmussen introduced the “SRK” model which consists of: S = Skill-based behaviour R = Rule-based behaviour K = Knowledge-based behaviour Skill-based behaviour. This behaviour is shown when performing skills. It is based on practice and prior learning, to become part of motor programmes. Reactions are largely unconscious and automatic. As such, conscious control is usually not required. There are 2 types of pilot errors relating to skills, which typically do not occur in novices since they normally have to think about each action. Skill-based errors only occur in those with experience. Experienced personnel should keep in mind that they are prone to errors at this level when they are preoccupied, tired, or otherwise distracted. Associated errors: - Environmental Capture and Action slip => often known as Errors of Routine.

content.question:
An experienced commander is flying with an equally experienced copilot, who is new to the company. The commander does not have much experience with flying over high seas, but the copilot has gained experience with his previous employer. When they fly over high seas, the copilot gives the commander a lot of advice, but the commander won’t listen. The commander then commits an error that the copilot helps him correct.
What is the correct description of the cockpit authority situation?

options.A: The commander and copilot operate in good synergy.
options.B: The commander is a good follower to his autocratic copilot.
options.C: The commander is autocratic and the copilot acts as a good follower.
options.D: The cockpit is run in a laissez-faire style, as the copilot does not prevent the commander from making the error.

key_points: The copilot is acting as a good follower
While sharing his/her experience and giving the commander advice, he/she does not question the commander’s authority
At the same time, when the commander autocratically ignores the copilot’s advice, the first officer does not disengage and shows him/herself available when an error is made
learning.explanation: The copilot is acting as a good follower. While sharing his/her experience and giving the commander advice, he/she does not question the commander’s authority. At the same time, when the commander autocratically ignores the copilot’s advice, the first officer does not disengage and shows him/herself available when an error is made. The commander, on the other hand, applies an autocratic leadership style which consists of a management style wherein the captain controls all the decisions and takes very little inputs from the copilot.

content.question: A pilot conducts a routine simulator flight with an examiner. The examiner notes that the pilot is excessively nervous given the standard and uneventful simulator flight. What might be a reason for the pilot's nervousness?

options.A: The pilot may have been afraid of dismissal because of a poor performance in the check ride.
options.B: The pilot may have felt social pressure, because he does not know the examiner personally and has never heard of him.
options.C: It might be an outward display of hypovigilance resulting from the eventless session.
options.D: The pilot might have been afraid of an upcoming simulated engine failure.

key_points: STRESS Simulator sessions are very common for commercial pilots

They are, however a point of potential nervousness for the pilot, as they might not have had their skills examined for 6 months, and may be feeling like they are sub-standard, or not well prepared for the simulator flight, which is an assessment
There will be events involved that are not practiced in normal flight, and use of checklists that the pilot might not have seen for a while, or properly studied recently
learning.explanation: STRESS Simulator sessions are very common for commercial pilots. They are, however a point of potential nervousness for the pilot, as they might not have had their skills examined for 6 months, and may be feeling like they are sub-standard, or not well prepared for the simulator flight, which is an assessment. There will be events involved that are not practiced in normal flight, and use of checklists that the pilot might not have seen for a while, or properly studied recently. The added stress/anxiety of an assessed simulator flight can cause a reduction in performance during the flight itself, as unsatisfactory performance could (eventually) lead to a potential dismissal. Of course, there is a long line of events that occur before dismissal, but a pilot that is already stressed might focus on the threat of losing their job, causing them even more stress, and reduced performance. To address the other possible answers; It is very common not to know the examiner, however, this should not be a factor in the pilot's performance during the session. Hypovigilance is the opposite of what is occurring here. The pilot is stressed due to hypervigilance rather than hypovigilance, and the routine simulator session would usually be very eventful. An engine failure scenario is (hopefully) not practised during line flying, but the procedures for dealing with one are very well learnt in training, and practiced every 6 or 12 months in the simulator. This could contribute to stress, but not likely as much as the potential of losing one's job. Note: There has been conflicting feedback about the answer to this question. Any further exam feedback can be put in the comments or emailed to info@atplquestions.com, thank you!

content.question: "Feedback" in communication implies that:

options.A: the flight crew do not need to talk all the time because the feedback is automatic.
options.B: storing of messages in short time memory is available for later release.
options.C: readback of a message is rarely necessary except in the case of specific ATC procedures.
options.D: a message is measured and corrected against the original meaning.

key_points: Providing feedback is a sign of active listening
In an interactive communication process, the receiver can send feedback to the sender to indicate that the message has been received and how it has been interpreted
This can start an interactive back-and-forth exchange that can assure the sender that the message has been received and understood correctly
learning.explanation: Providing feedback is a sign of active listening. In an interactive communication process, the receiver can send feedback to the sender to indicate that the message has been received and how it has been interpreted. This can start an interactive back-and-forth exchange that can assure the sender that the message has been received and understood correctly.

content.question: An aircraft experiences a landing-gear malfunction while executing an approach for landing. The pilots are unable to determine the condition of the landing gear extension. In order to resolve the situation and prepare the aircraft for an emergency landing, they remain in the published holding pattern for one hour. When the aircraft exits the holding pattern to start its approach for landing, the aircraft runs out of fuel. The pilots failed to notice the critical fuel quantity while resolving the landing gear issue. Which statement describes the situation?

options.A: This type of incident is unlikely to occur, because monitoring the fuel quantity and calculating the fuel consumption during flight are ordinary tasks that would be automatically carried out by the Crew.
options.B: The Crew failed to follow the procedure designed for landing-gear malfunctions. In order to prevent the risk of overlooking important tasks if an abnormal situation arises, specific checklists are used. These would include routine tasks such as fuel monitoring.
options.C: The Crew's attention was distracted from important yet basic operations in this situation of high workload. This is a risk that must be taken into account and addressed in training, in order to prevent safety hazards.
options.D: There was a failure in the fuel warning system. The Crew focus their attention on the most critical issue and employ their resources to solve the problem, because they are aware that the aircraft systems are designed to monitor parameters and warn the crew if any limitations are exceeded.

key_points: This scenario is an illustration of distraction and blinkered attention
Both pilots are focusing their attention on the urgent task, in this case, prepare the aircraft for an emergency landing, that they lose awareness of fundamental flight procedures
The crew followed the emergency landing preparation procedure as written in the checklist, which probably does not include a fuel level check
learning.explanation: This scenario is an illustration of distraction and blinkered attention. Both pilots are focusing their attention on the urgent task, in this case, prepare the aircraft for an emergency landing, that they lose awareness of fundamental flight procedures. The crew followed the emergency landing preparation procedure as written in the checklist, which probably does not include a fuel level check. This was an "omission error" where the pilots forgot to perform a necessary action, namely checking the fuel. The pilots correctly executed the actions they did take, but they missed certain steps, such as checking the fuel, which might have been a memorized task or part of the normal descent checklist. A failure in the fuel warning system is not confirmed, and in any case the crew is responsible for monitoring fuel quantity, especially when entering a holding pattern. The pilots became excessively fixated on the emergency situation, leading to a loss of situational awareness and distraction. Flight training addresses this issue, but it's a common human error that needs to be overcome. Tools like TDODAR, the decision-making process, include a consideration of time, which is constrained by the remaining fuel and should have factored into the flight crew's decision-making.

content.question: The expression "when perception matches reality" describes:

options.A: Vigilance
options.B: Situational Awareness
options.C: Alertness
options.D: Attention

key_points: SITUATIONAL AWARENESS This is the ability to accurately perceive what is happening in- and outside the aircraft, plus the ability to understand the meaning of different elements in the environment and the projection of their status in the near future (where the aircraft is, where it has been, and where it is going)
To do this successfully, you have to know how things should be to recognize what’s wrong
More simply, situational awareness means that the pilot’s idea of a situation equals reality
learning.explanation: SITUATIONAL AWARENESS This is the ability to accurately perceive what is happening in- and outside the aircraft, plus the ability to understand the meaning of different elements in the environment and the projection of their status in the near future (where the aircraft is, where it has been, and where it is going). To do this successfully, you have to know how things should be to recognize what’s wrong. More simply, situational awareness means that the pilot’s idea of a situation equals reality. The process of achieving situational awareness consists of: Perceiving objects in the environment – Monitor; Understanding their meaning and impact – Evaluate; Correct prediction of changes to the environment and the future state of the objects for a sufficient period of time – Anticipate.

content.question:
An experienced pilot is employed by an airline operator on a fixed-term contract as First officer. The Operator will offer a permanent contract to only 1 pilot at the end of the year, so the First Officer is really motivated to perform at his/her best.
The commander of the aircraft who flies with him/her should be aware that...

options.A: High motivation increases arousal but reduces the perceived stress level, so the First Officer will be prone to hypervigilance during the cruise.
options.B: Over-motivation will affect performance, because the associated high levels of arousal are a physiological source of stress.
options.C: High levels of motivation lead to higher arousal, resulting in the First Officer performing his/her monitoring duties more effectively.
options.D: Strong motivation to achieve is a cognitive stressor, and it can negatively affect performance.

key_points: Motivation refers to degree of readiness of an organism to pursue some designated goal and implies the determination of the nature and locus of the forces, including the degree of readiness
In other words, it is a drive to behave in a particular fashion which usually leads to a change of behaviour
It is an internal force which can affect the quality of performance
learning.explanation: Motivation refers to degree of readiness of an organism to pursue some designated goal and implies the determination of the nature and locus of the forces, including the degree of readiness. In other words, it is a drive to behave in a particular fashion which usually leads to a change of behaviour. It is an internal force which can affect the quality of performance. The learning process is vastly improved with motivation and high performance rarely comes without it, as it increases attention and vigilance. Over-motivation can be just as much of a hindrance – excessive motivation together with high levels of stress will limit your attention-management capabilities. In short, you can get fixated. With regards to this question, this situation will place extra cognitive stress on the individual which can negatively affect performance.

content.question: Expressed as a simple mathematical statement when considering a crew of two, good synergy is:

key_points: SYNERGY Synergy describes a cooperation of creatures, matter or forces in terms of mutual support
In simple words, it is the state where the group performance exceeds the sum of the individual performances (“the whole is more than the sum of its parts”)

Synergy can be expressed as a simple mathematical statement: (considering a crew of two) 1 + 1 = > 2 When the group performance is less than the sum of individual performances, synergy is said to be poor and can be mathematically expressed as follows: 1 + 1 = < 2 The most critical moment for development of synergy among the crew is the pre-flight briefing
learning.explanation: SYNERGY Synergy describes a cooperation of creatures, matter or forces in terms of mutual support. In simple words, it is the state where the group performance exceeds the sum of the individual performances (“the whole is more than the sum of its parts”). Synergy can be expressed as a simple mathematical statement: (considering a crew of two) 1 + 1 = > 2 When the group performance is less than the sum of individual performances, synergy is said to be poor and can be mathematically expressed as follows: 1 + 1 = < 2 The most critical moment for development of synergy among the crew is the pre-flight briefing. The captain (the designated leader) should take the opportunity to emphasize that all crew members working on the aircraft form one crew. Synergy should then be maintained until the end of the duty period. A non-synergetic cockpit will most likely lead to unclear communication and crew members withdrawn.

content.question: Which statement about acute or chronic fatigue is INCORRECT?

options.A: Chronic fatigue may be caused by inadequate recuperation from periods of acute fatigue.
options.B: Acute fatigue generally has psychological roots.
options.C: Chronic fatigue may lead to a person being totally apathetic and indifferent to what goes on around them.
options.D: Acute fatigue is felt after a period of significant exertion or emotional excitement.

key_points: Fatigue is a feeling of constant tiredness or weakness and can be physical, mental or a combination of both
The two types of fatigue are acute and chronic: Acute fatigue – short-term, more intense which usually affects the body, and just needs a good nights’ sleep to sort things out
Acute stress activates the General Adaptation Syndrome (GAS), where physical, emotional and mental resources are mobilized to fight stress
learning.explanation: Fatigue is a feeling of constant tiredness or weakness and can be physical, mental or a combination of both. The two types of fatigue are acute and chronic: Acute fatigue – short-term, more intense which usually affects the body, and just needs a good nights’ sleep to sort things out. Acute stress activates the General Adaptation Syndrome (GAS), where physical, emotional and mental resources are mobilized to fight stress. Chronic fatigue – arises from more long-term effects, like many episodes of acute fatigue. Chronic fatigue typically happens after you’ve had no rest for some time and the body’s energy level cannot be restored after normal or increased periods of sleep. Coping with the impact of chronic stress can be challenging. Because the source of long-term stress is more constant than acute stress, the body never receives a clear signal to return to normal functioning. Note; this question asks for an incorrect statement.

content.question: Errors may be classified into two major categories: active and latent. Which one of the definitions below relates to a latent error?

options.A: An error that arises from inadequate knowledge or experience.
options.B: An issue that stems from a failure in applying an inappropriate rule.
options.C: A system containing unrecognised faults, which become evident under specific circumstances.
options.D: An event that occurs immediately before an incident or accident.

key_points: ACTIVE AND LATENT ERRORS An error, officially, arises when a planned sequence of activities fails to achieve the intended outcome, where random external intervention is not involved
The terms active and latent as applied to errors were coined by Reason

Latent errors have consequences that lie dormant and are difficult to recognize or foresee because of the time lag between their generation and occurrence, while active errors, which are committed at the human/system interface, have consequences that are felt almost immediately, which is how they can be detected
learning.explanation: ACTIVE AND LATENT ERRORS An error, officially, arises when a planned sequence of activities fails to achieve the intended outcome, where random external intervention is not involved. The terms active and latent as applied to errors were coined by Reason. Latent errors have consequences that lie dormant and are difficult to recognize or foresee because of the time lag between their generation and occurrence, while active errors, which are committed at the human/system interface, have consequences that are felt almost immediately, which is how they can be detected. Active errors are committed by the “sharp end”, those people who are directly involved in flight operations (pilots, ATC, etc). Latent errors are usually committed by the blunt-end, people who are not directly engaged in flight operations. However, latent errors can also be made by front-line personnel. An example of a latent error committed by a pilot would be the selection of a wrong waypoint in a GPS database. Latent errors sometimes require the occurrence of an inevitable active error to have consequences at all, lulling the pilots in security.

content.question: During a visual approach to an aerodrome, the pilot is concentrated on the decreasing airspeed and fails to cross-check the altimeter and vertical speed indications. How can this scenario be characterized?

options.A: The pilot is prioritizing the correct parameter for a safe approach.
options.B: The situation is normal as airspeed is the primary focus during the approach.
options.C: It indicates the pilot has good situation awareness by focusing on airspeed.
options.D: It is a cue for loss of situational awareness as the pilot is concentrating only on one parameter.

key_points: SITUATIONAL AWARENESS Situational awareness of a pilot is the perception of the environment and its elements, the interpretation of their significance and the anticipation of their state in the future
The pilot should be able to monitor the flight parameters and the environment, evaluate the circumstances and anticipate possible future outcomes
During the approach for landing, the pilot should: Follow the correct heading to be aligned with the runway
learning.explanation: SITUATIONAL AWARENESS Situational awareness of a pilot is the perception of the environment and its elements, the interpretation of their significance and the anticipation of their state in the future. The pilot should be able to monitor the flight parameters and the environment, evaluate the circumstances and anticipate possible future outcomes. During the approach for landing, the pilot should: Follow the correct heading to be aligned with the runway. Keep the appropriate approach speed for the aircraft type. Follow the appropriate glide path by monitoring the distance from the runway and the current altitude. Ensure that the vertical speed is within limits for a stabilized approach Therefore, monitoring the airspeed, altimeter and vertical speed indicator is crucial during an approach for landing, and focusing only on the airspeed is an incorrect technique that indicates loss of situational awareness.

content.question: Any stimulus that causes stress is referred to as a stressor. In the cockpit, an example of an environmental stressor is..

options.A: lack of sleep.
options.B: engine noise.
options.C: financial worries.
options.D: work overload.

key_points: STRESS Stress disturbs the body’s homeostasis and enables you to adapt to encountered situations
It is the body’s response to a stressor, which is an internal or external stimulus that is interpreted as a threat to the body’s equilibrium, and prepares it for action
There are three types of stressors: Environmental Stressors – environmental conditions, noise, vibrations
learning.explanation: STRESS Stress disturbs the body’s homeostasis and enables you to adapt to encountered situations. It is the body’s response to a stressor, which is an internal or external stimulus that is interpreted as a threat to the body’s equilibrium, and prepares it for action. There are three types of stressors: Environmental Stressors – environmental conditions, noise, vibrations. Physiological Stressors – fatigue, lack of physical fitness, improper eating habits, hunger, thirst, cold/too hot, humidity, dehydration, vibration, accelerations; Psychological/emotional stress – inter-personal conflicts, discrimination, fear of failure, death of a relative, divorce, financial problems, job insecurity.

content.question:
Which of the following choices are good examples of pre-planning and anticipation?
1. A pilot after experiencing an emergency in flight quickly decides to deviate to a well known alternative aerodrome.
2. After experiencing an emergency, the pilots asks the ATC for assistance in choosing an alternate aerodrome.
3. On a cruise flight over water, the aircraft suffers an emergency which requires one engine to be shut down. The pilot quickly decides whether to continue the flight or divert to and nearest suitable aerodrome.
4. An aeroplane lines up for take-off when the ATC informs the pilot of a change of wind direction and speed meaning the aircraft's crosswind limitation is exceeded. The pilot asks for a different runway and starts to calculate performance and navigation accordingly.

options.A: 1, 2 and 4
options.B: 2 and 4 only
options.C: 1 and 3 only
options.D: 1, 3 and 4

key_points: We can evaluate each scenario individually: 1
A pilot after experiencing an emergency in flight quickly decides to deviate to a well known alternative aerodrome
The commander prepared for the flight, studied the alternate airports for each leg of the flight plan and planned his deviations carefully
learning.explanation: We can evaluate each scenario individually: 1. A pilot after experiencing an emergency in flight quickly decides to deviate to a well known alternative aerodrome. The commander prepared for the flight, studied the alternate airports for each leg of the flight plan and planned his deviations carefully. Ahead of time, the commander took advantage of the available data and made deviation scenarios to be able to anticipate emergency deviations and act without delay. This is an example of good pre-planning and anticipation. 2. After experiencing an emergency, the pilots asks the ATC for assistance in choosing an alternate aerodrome. It is the commander’s responsibility to study alternate aerodromes during pre-flight preparation, and have knowledge of the anticipated weather and characteristics of these aerodromes. Due to poor pre-flight preparation and lack of anticipation of a need to deviate, the commander is unable to handle the situation and asks the help of the ATC. 3. On a cruise flight over water, the aircraft suffers an emergency which requires one engine to be shut down. The pilot quickly decides whether to continue the flight or divert to and nearest suitable aerodrome. It is the commander’s responsibility to be able to handle emergency situations, be familiar with the emergency checklist and prepared to act in case of an emergency. The pilot has studied the alternate airports and pre-planned situations that he would have to make critical decisions, so he is prepared to make a quick and appropriate decision. This is an example of good pre-planning and anticipation. 4. An aeroplane lines up for take-off when the ATC informs the pilot of a change of wind direction and speed meaning the aircraft's crosswind limitation is exceeded. The pilot asks for a different runway and starts to calculate performance and navigation accordingly. The commander is responsible to plan his mission and calculate performance data in advance for each runway. This is an example of poor pre-flight planning.

content.question: Which of the following is an example of hypovigilance developing during a VFR flight in good weather?

options.A: After deciding for a diversion from the originally planned route, the pilot is entering the GPS coordinates for a new waypoint, and fails to hear the ATC operator calling his/her aircraft call sign.
options.B: During a precautionary landing due to a possible impending engine failure, the pilot keeps monitoring the engine instruments indications, preparing for an emergency, and fails to extend the landing gear.
options.C: During the cruise, after looking at regular intervals inside the cockpit to check the instruments, the pilot realises he/she has just looked at the panel without actually reading the instrument indications.
options.D: Just before the approach for landing at the destination in the late afternoon, the pilot feels tired and decides to change his/her plans for the evening so he/she has more time to sleep.

key_points: Vigilance is a term that refers to an individual’s ability to pay close and continuous attention to a field of stimulation for a period of time, watchful for any particular changing circumstances
These changes may be quite small, but their potential effect may be considerable
The speed and accuracy with which we detect these changes (assuming we detect them at all) determine the timeliness of our decisions and actions
learning.explanation: Vigilance is a term that refers to an individual’s ability to pay close and continuous attention to a field of stimulation for a period of time, watchful for any particular changing circumstances. These changes may be quite small, but their potential effect may be considerable. The speed and accuracy with which we detect these changes (assuming we detect them at all) determine the timeliness of our decisions and actions. Vigilance is greatly affected by our level of alertness, and this is why we can be affected not only by being overloaded but also by being ‘under-loaded’. Hypovigilance is a state that which vigilance is reduced and the crew become more prone to errors. This can be also described as a microsleep since it has similar characteristics. Hypovigilance can occur during periods of: Monotony, reduction of workload, during simple or repetitive tasks, constant and monotonous noise, low lighting, high temperature, isolation, sleep debit, fatigue. It can also occur shortly after a meal. From the available options, looking to instruments without reading during the cruise is a very good example of hypovigilance.

content.question: During the decision making process in the cockpit:

options.A: a detailed analysis can only be made once, at the moment the problem occurs.
options.B: habits and routines play no role.
options.C: the amount of time available has a large influence on the analysis of the situation.
options.D: the crew should always decide on more than one alternative.

key_points: Since decision making is usually a time consuming process, time is an important resource for making optimal decisions
The allocation of less time than what is needed for making decision can cause a feeling of time stress and can harm the optimality of the decision making process
In contrast to travelling by car, it is not possible to simply stop at the side of an airway while flying and analyse the situation
learning.explanation: Since decision making is usually a time consuming process, time is an important resource for making optimal decisions. The allocation of less time than what is needed for making decision can cause a feeling of time stress and can harm the optimality of the decision making process. In contrast to travelling by car, it is not possible to simply stop at the side of an airway while flying and analyse the situation. Every good decision-making process must take this into consideration. To improve the quality of decision, if the time is not the immediate limiting factor, a pilot should take all the available time that he needs to make up his mind and should try not to feel pressured to speed up the decision-making process unnecessarily by his crewmembers. Rushed decision should be avoided, as these will increase the risk of overlooking important facts and losing situational awareness. It is important to emphasise that, during flight, the overall situation is constantly evolving and changing. Therefore, decisions only remain valid for a limited period of time - until the next change in the overall situation occurs. Thereafter, a new decision is needed.

content.question: How can one distinguish between cooperation and coaction?

options.A: Cooperation is the performance of coactions one by one. Coaction is when each person completes several tasks, to lighten each others' workload.
options.B: Cooperation is working together for a common purpose. Coaction is each person taking the same action to enhance safety.
options.C: Cooperation is joining forces for a common purpose. Coaction is when each person carries out their assigned part.
options.D: Cooperation is the division of tasks for different purposes. Coaction is joining forces for a common purpose.

key_points: Coaction: every crewmember is doing what he or she perceives as being his/her task at the moment, unaware of what others are doing and not giving any feedback about his/her own actions

Cooperation: every crew member is responsible for performing his/her duties as stated in the company’s SOP and informs the other crewmember about his/her actions and their respective results to provide redundancy
In simple words, it means coordinated common activity
learning.explanation: Coaction: every crewmember is doing what he or she perceives as being his/her task at the moment, unaware of what others are doing and not giving any feedback about his/her own actions. Cooperation: every crew member is responsible for performing his/her duties as stated in the company’s SOP and informs the other crewmember about his/her actions and their respective results to provide redundancy. In simple words, it means coordinated common activity.

content.question:
The following factors tend to decrease your state of vigilance:
1. Monotony
2. Increased workload
3. Constant and monotonous noise
4. Low lighting
5. Low ambient temperature
6. Distracting tasks
7. Sleep debt

key_points: One of the most important aspects of a safe flight operation is the requirement for crew members to carefully monitor the aircraft's flight path and systems, as well as actively cross-check each other's actions
Humans are not good at monitoring constant situations and, therefore, it is easy to fall behind the aircraft
This is especially true when no deviations are expected to occur, as in the case when monitoring automated systems
learning.explanation: One of the most important aspects of a safe flight operation is the requirement for crew members to carefully monitor the aircraft's flight path and systems, as well as actively cross-check each other's actions. Humans are not good at monitoring constant situations and, therefore, it is easy to fall behind the aircraft. This is especially true when no deviations are expected to occur, as in the case when monitoring automated systems. This can induce a feeling of automation complacency (too much reliance on the machine) and lead you not to check things as often as you should (hypovigilance). Hypovigilance is a lack of attention to detail, it is akin to a microsleep which can occur at any time during the flight, especially during periods of monotony, reduction of workload, during simple and repetitive tasks, low lightning, high temperature and constant and monotonous noise. During long-haul flights, hypovigilance is often unavoidable. To help prevent hypovigilance during flight, in a multi-crew operation, it is possible for crew-members to take planned naps (controlled rest) - these should be short, approx. 20min. It is also helpful to engage in social conversation and physical activity such as arm and leg stretching may also assist in maintaining wakefulness. During the night, turning up the cockpit lights will also help. However, this deteriorates night vision.

content.question: Which of the following is an example of human underload?

options.A: A good landing at an airfield with which the pilot is familiar in poor weather conditions.
options.B: A poor landing at an airfield with which the pilot is unfamiliar, in marginal weather conditions.
options.C: An unexpectedly good landing at an airfield with which the pilot is unfamiliar in perfect weather conditions.
options.D: An unexpectedly poor landing at an airfield with which the pilot is familiar in perfect weather conditions.

key_points: Underload is increased with lack of external stimuli
It translates into a workload which is below optimum, where arousal is low and the pilot is hypovigilant
In this state, the pilot will not be able to react quickly to slight deviations or his/her actions will be late in general
learning.explanation: Underload is increased with lack of external stimuli. It translates into a workload which is below optimum, where arousal is low and the pilot is hypovigilant. In this state, the pilot will not be able to react quickly to slight deviations or his/her actions will be late in general. The relationship between workload and performance is a symmetrical inverted U (performance being on the vertical axis and workload on the horizontal axis). Increases in workload will result in the increase of performance, up to a point, called the break point, beyond which further workload is dysfunctional to the outcome of performance and will dramatically narrow the span of attention. This question depicts a situation where the pilot is perhaps overconfident and familiarity breeds contempt. Placing him on the left side of the performance vs pressure/workload curve. We’ve all experienced the negatives and positives of pressure. Too much and you feel you can’t cope. Not enough, and you struggle to get anything done. Not only do we not perform well with insufficient pressure, the resultant tedium can also be very stressful.

content.question: The first cockpit tool that tends to suffer as a result of stress:

options.A: Cockpit entity
options.B: Cockpit synergy
options.C: Cockpit communications
options.D: Cockpit cohesion

key_points: COMMUNICATION The first cockpit tool that tends to suffer from stress is communication

When several tasks have to be performed simultaneously, especially when these tasks require a lot of conscious attention, people tend to reduce communication, because communication also uses up mental resources

learning.explanation: COMMUNICATION The first cockpit tool that tends to suffer from stress is communication. When several tasks have to be performed simultaneously, especially when these tasks require a lot of conscious attention, people tend to reduce communication, because communication also uses up mental resources. Communication is the exchange of thoughts, messages, or information by various means, including speech. Officially, around 80% of all communication is achieved by factors other than words, otherwise known as metacommunication, which consists of those tools, other than the words, which complement them in order to communicate. The fact that somebody is not talking does not mean they are not communicating. It is said that 7% of communication is accomplished verbally, 38% by unconscious signals, such as tone of voice, and the remainder 55% by non-verbal means, such as body language. Non-verbal communication can accompany verbal communication, such as a smile during a face-to-face chat. Body language can be very subtle, but powerful – for example, the word “no” with a smile will be interpreted quite differently from one accompanied by a smack in the mouth. Non-verbal communication may also include written information or notes. Unfortunately, the side-by-side seating arrangements in the cockpit tend to lessen the effects of body language, so the choice of words (and their packaging) assumes a greater importance.

key_points: BRIEFINGS The main objective of crew briefings is that all crew members understand the desired sequence of events and actions, the condition of the aircraft, any special circumstances affecting the planned flight
At the end of a briefing, all crew members should share a common mental model of the situation
Briefings can be a powerful means of transferring information; if properly given they can be extremely effective
learning.explanation: BRIEFINGS The main objective of crew briefings is that all crew members understand the desired sequence of events and actions, the condition of the aircraft, any special circumstances affecting the planned flight. At the end of a briefing, all crew members should share a common mental model of the situation. Briefings can be a powerful means of transferring information; if properly given they can be extremely effective. Effective briefings are: Short. A briefing is designed to provide information quickly and effectively. Of standard type/standard sequence of briefing items. Elements always appear in the same sequence, and meet the expectations of the receiver who is used to that sequence making it easy to spot an omission. Understood by all crew members. A simple but well-understood plan of action, supported by all is preferable to a possibly brilliant but misunderstood plan. The purpose of a crew briefing is to refresh the memories of the crew members relating to the actions to be taken on the flight, usually during the critical phases. Its main purpose is as a memory tool, to make it fresh in each crew member's memory. The correct answer mentions that it is the long term memory which is "re-activated" during the briefing, which is true, as that is the main way that a briefing improves memory recall during the subsequent flight.

key_points: The following techniques that can be employed to enhance short-term memory: Chunking: By using the method of "chunking," individuals can increase the amount of information retained in their short-term memory
Chunking involves grouping related material together, which works best when the person is already familiar with the information
For example, a long telephone number like 846358690581 can be chunked into smaller segments like 8463, 5869, 0581, reducing the number of items to be held in memory
learning.explanation: The following techniques that can be employed to enhance short-term memory: Chunking: By using the method of "chunking," individuals can increase the amount of information retained in their short-term memory. Chunking involves grouping related material together, which works best when the person is already familiar with the information. For example, a long telephone number like 846358690581 can be chunked into smaller segments like 8463, 5869, 0581, reducing the number of items to be held in memory. This technique is also utilized in the French telephone directory, where numbers are presented in separated blocks, allowing individuals to remember them in chunks of three figures. Association: Association is a technique commonly employed to remember spoken lists of items. It involves creating wild and unusual associations and linking them to each item on the list. Many people, including politicians, utilize this method to help connect names with faces and enhance recall. Mnemonics: Mnemonics is an effective tool for remembering multiple points by creating a word, phrase, or sentence that represents the information. This technique involves using memorable associations or patterns to aid memory recall. Acronyms like "HASELL" or "FREDA" can aid in memory recall by providing a structured and memorable way to associate and organize information. By employing these techniques, individuals can improve their short-term memory retention and retrieval capabilities. In the example "I'M SAFE" (Illness, Medication, Stress, Alcohol, Fatigue, Eating) the mnemonic techique is used. A word is created and each letter represents an item that needs to be memorised.

content.question: The crew of a transport aircraft experience a landing gear issue meaning that they cannot tell if the gear is down. To give the crew time to prepare the aircraft for an emergency landing, they hold for an hour. Subsequently, on the final approach they run out of fuel. Which of these options best describes what happened?

options.A: The crew were relying on a low fuel indication from the aircraft. Thus the low fuel warning system is unserviceable.
options.B: The crew has not conducted the correct actions, or they would have picked up on the low fuel indication.
options.C: The crew have missed important yet basic tasks such as monitoring the fuel. This is a risk and should be taught in basic flight training.
options.D: This scenario is unlikely to happen.

key_points: This situation is a prime example of distraction, and blinkered attention, where both pilots are so focussed on the rare task at hand (that they must make an emergency landing), that they lose situational awareness of basic flight items

The problem here is that they did not conduct incorrect actions, as one option suggests, because they will have followed the procedure for the emergency landing prep as normal, which probably does not ask the pilots to check fuel levels
This was an "error of omission", where the pilots forgot to do something that they needed to do, which was to check the fuel
learning.explanation: This situation is a prime example of distraction, and blinkered attention, where both pilots are so focussed on the rare task at hand (that they must make an emergency landing), that they lose situational awareness of basic flight items. The problem here is that they did not conduct incorrect actions, as one option suggests, because they will have followed the procedure for the emergency landing prep as normal, which probably does not ask the pilots to check fuel levels. This was an "error of omission", where the pilots forgot to do something that they needed to do, which was to check the fuel. The pilots correctly conducted the actions that they made (as far as we know), they just missed actions like checking the fuel, which will likely have been a memory item. The pilots became overly focussed on the emergency and lost situational awareness, and became distracted. This is taught in flight school, but is a natural error of the human condition that we must learn to overcome. Tools such as TDODAR, the decision making process, include reference to "time", which is absolutely limited by fuel remaining, and should have been a consideration to this flight crew. To address the other options, the crew would not "rely" on a low fuel indication, and so it is irrelevant whether it was serviceable or not. This scenario is, unfortunately, very easy to do, as distraction and "tunnel vision" on a task is something our brains do very regularly, that we have to fight.

content.question:
The fatigue risk management system (FRMS) is a data-driven means of continuously monitoring and managing fatigue-related safety risks, based upon scientific principles and knowledge as well as operational experience that aims to ensure relevant personnel are performing at adequate levels of alertness.
Which kind of safety culture is established in a company using a FRMS?

options.A: Non-punitive culture.
options.B: Closed culture.
options.C: Anti-authority.
options.D: Learning culture.

key_points: Crewmember fatigue can be defined as: A physiological state of reduced mental or physical performance capability resulting from sleep loss or extended wakefulness, circadian phase, or workload (mental and/or physical activity) that can impair a crew member’s alertness and ability to safely operate an aircraft or perform safety related duties
Fatigue is a major human factors hazard because it affects most aspects of a crewmember’s ability to do their job
It therefore has implications for safety
learning.explanation: Crewmember fatigue can be defined as: A physiological state of reduced mental or physical performance capability resulting from sleep loss or extended wakefulness, circadian phase, or workload (mental and/or physical activity) that can impair a crew member’s alertness and ability to safely operate an aircraft or perform safety related duties. Fatigue is a major human factors hazard because it affects most aspects of a crewmember’s ability to do their job. It therefore has implications for safety. ICAO defines a Fatigue Risk Management System (FRMS) as: A data-driven means of continuously monitoring and managing fatigue-related safety risks, based upon scientific principles and knowledge as well as operational experience that aims to ensure relevant personnel are performing at adequate levels of alertness. An FRMS aims to ensure that flight and cabin crew members are sufficiently alert so they can operate to a satisfactory level of performance. It is a set of guidelines aimed at reducing fatigue-induced safety risks and considers additional factors such as the circadian rhythm, the importance of adequate sleep within the rest period, and the unique properties of the individual operation. FRMS is based on computer models which anticipate the expected performance capability of a person from his/her sleep/awake history. Such models must be continuously updated by analyses of data and reports. The quality of the FRMS depends on its ability to learn. The term used for this kind of safety culture is “learning culture”. It is also dependent on the willingness of aircrew to report fatigue-related issues and in a culture where crew members are encouraged to report safety risks. However, such safety cultured is named “just culture” and not “non-punitive culture”.

learning.explanation: Mnemonics use combinations of letters or words to represent essential items to remember, facilitating the transfer of information from short-term to long-term memory. Techniques like DECIDE, IMSAFE, and PAVE provide a structured approach to decision-making, ensuring that all necessary steps are considered and followed, thus preventing shortcuts. By offering a systematic method, mnemonics help maintain consistency, thoroughness, and reliability in decision-making processes, which is especially important in high-stakes environments such as aviation. For instance, some pilots use the IMSAFE mnemonic to assess their fitness for flying: I Illness Am I suffering from illness, disease, or injury that might effect me? key_points: Acute stress, which refers to short term stress (i
e
caused by the issues of the flight), triggers the body's "fight or flight" response, leading to heightened arousal and increased attention to potential threats
learning.explanation: Acute stress, which refers to short term stress (i.e. caused by the issues of the flight), triggers the body's "fight or flight" response, leading to heightened arousal and increased attention to potential threats. This state of heightened arousal can sometimes enhance situational awareness as individuals focus more on pertinent environmental cues. However, it is crucial to acknowledge that acute stress may also have detrimental effects on situational awareness and performance. Individuals under acute stress may exhibit tunnel vision (fixation), wherein the five senses, except for a limited visual field in each eye, become filtered out. Loud noises and pain may go unnoticed during this narrowed focus. It's noteworthy that stress, both in its causes and manifestations, is subjective and varies significantly among individuals. In line with EASA expectations based on student feedback, it's emphasized that auditory information is often discarded first under acute stress. This aligns with the common phenomenon of auditory exclusion, where individuals may not effectively process auditory stimuli during high-stress situations.

Conflict management is the process by which disputes are resolved, where negative results are minimized and positive results are prioritized. It involves the participation of all involved parties in finding an acceptable collective solution. Different strategies exist to discover misunderstandings, de-escalate a situation and restore appreciative relationship: Active listening. Active listening is a way of listening and responding to another person that improves mutual understanding. This is where you make a conscious effort to hear not only the words that another person is saying but, more importantly, the complete message being communicated. One can demonstrate that he/she is listening by smiling, nodding to show one has understood or saying “yes” or “mhh” to encourage him/her to continue. Metacommunication. Metacommunication literally means "communication about communication", and it refers to all the nonverbal cues (tone of voice, body language, gestures, facial expression, etc.) that carry meaning that either enhance or disallow what we say in words. Tonal presentation or body language can go a long way to help defuse conflict. If a forceful point of view must be made, it may become more acceptable if it is accompanied with tactful or non-aggressive body language/tone of voice.

learning.explanation: Arousal and Performance Arousal is the measure of the human being's readiness to respond. The relationship between arousal and performance is a symmetrical inverted U (performance being on the vertical axis and arousal on the horizontal axis). Increases in arousal will result in the increase of performance, up to a point, called the break point, beyond which further arousal is dysfunctional to the outcome of performance and will dramatically narrow the span of attention. At the optimum arousal level, we are at our most efficient - optimum arousal happens just below the breakpoint. Regarding this question: Stress increases along with arousal. Initially, we experience eustress (positive stress) and then distress (negative stress). As previously mentioned, the point of highest performance (optimum arousal or stress) is just below the breakpoint. After this breakpoint, performance decreases as stress becomes overwhelming. However, arousal and stress will still increase.

It considers both individual and group needs, fosters trust, and resolves conflicts. In training, errors are expected; during commercial operations, it validates actions and aligns with established protocols. Both coordination and cooperation enhance safety and performance in aviation. An argument between pilots in the flight deck can disrupt communication, coordination, and decision-making, diverting focus from critical tasks, increasing stress, and fostering a negative environment. This is especially true when no deviations are expected to occur, as in the case when monitoring automated systems. This can induce a feeling of automation complacency (too much reliance on the machine) and lead you not to check things as often as you should (hypovigilance). key_points: HAZARDOUS ATTITUDES Studies have identified five hazardous attitudes among pilots that can interfere with a pilot’s ability to make effective decisions

learning.explanation: HAZARDOUS ATTITUDES Studies have identified five hazardous attitudes among pilots that can interfere with a pilot’s ability to make effective decisions. ANTI-AUTHORITY (“don’t tell me”) – You display this attitude if you resent having someone tell you what to do, or you regard rules and procedures as unnecessary. Antidote – Follow the rules. They are usually right. IMPULSIVITY (“do it quickly”) – If you feel the need to act immediately and do the first thing that comes to mind without considering the best solution to a problem, then you are exhibiting impulsivity. Antidote – Not so fast. Think first. INVULNERABILITY (“It won’t happen to me”) – You are more likely to take chances and increase risk if you think accidents will not happen to you. Antidote – It could happen to me. MACHO (“I can do it”) – If you have this attitude, you might take risks trying to prove that you are better than anyone else. Women are just as likely to have this characteristic as men. Antidote – Taking chances is foolish. RESIGNATION (“What’s the use?”) – You are experiencing resignation if you feel that no matter what you do, it will have little effect on what happens to you. You may feel that when things go well, it is just good luck and when things go poorly, it is bad luck or someone else is responsible. This feeling can cause you to leave the action to others – for better or worse. Antidote – I am not helpless. I can make a difference.

content.question: According to James Reason, what are the different categories of error?

options.A: Defects, deficiencies, ambiguities, and anomalies.

key_points: James Reason defines errors as planned actions that fail to achieve their desired consequences without interventionof some chance or unforeseeable agency
According to the professor, different types of errors can be distinguished depending on the mode of operation and the awareness of deviation: Slips/Lapses
Slips do not satisfy the operator’s intent although the intent was correct
learning.explanation: James Reason defines errors as planned actions that fail to achieve their desired consequences without interventionof some chance or unforeseeable agency. According to the professor, different types of errors can be distinguished depending on the mode of operation and the awareness of deviation: Slips/Lapses. Slips do not satisfy the operator’s intent although the intent was correct. An example from aviation would be raising the flaps early on departure instead of the landing gear. When the intended correct action is not carried out at all or a certain step of the action is left out, this is referred to as lapse. An example would be missing an item from a checklist. In both cases, the errors are committed unintentionally. Mistakes. Also known as faults. The action satisfies the operator’s intent, but the intent itself was incorrect - the application of a rule that does not fit the situation. In contrast to slips and lapses, a person making a mistake does what he/she intends to do, but the action plan was inadequate to the situation. Violations. Sometimes appear to be human errors but they differ from slips and lapses in so far as they are deliberate “illegal” actions. This type of error is comitted deliberately while totally aware that a deviation from standards or rules will occur. An aviation example would be exceeding the maximum speed, which is clearly marked red on the airspeed indicator.

learning.explanation: AUTOMATION Cockpit automation has the potential to increase or decrease the flight safety, depending on how well you use the equipment. Automation can conserve resources and attention, relieving pilot workload and giving time for supervision. However, if given too much control, the cockpit becomes boring, and errors can go unnoticed amongst the monotony. Pilots can also become less confident in their basic airmanship and flying skills. On the one hand, automation is good, because it can take a lot of routine work away from you. On the other hand, automation can induce a feeling of automation complacency – too much reliance on the machine, and lead you not to check thing as often as you should. Mode awareness means being aware of the active modes and understanding the relevant actions and responses to use the system properly. It involves knowledge of the configurations of an aircraft and their interactions with the modes of the automatic flight system in use, which include such items as current and target speed, altitude, heading. The lack of understanding of what an automatic system is doing is called mode confusion.

Mental models are cognitive frameworks or representations shaped by past experiences that help individuals understand and navigate the world, influencing how they interpret information and make decisions. Each individual creates mental models, also called 'filters of perception', based on past experience and knowledge. Since past experience is unique for each individual, mental models differ from person to person and perception is subjective. Each pilot brings his/her unique background and experience to the cockpit, which results in each pilot forming their own mental models affecting their perception. Confirmation bias can lead to interpreting information in a way that aligns with preexisting beliefs or expectations while ignoring contradictory information. Each pilot has his own expectations for the situation based on his/her own preexisting beliefs, affecting his/her perception. Therefore confirmation bias affects each pilot in a different way leading them to different conclusions. Different mental models and confirmation bias affect perception, causing each pilot to understand something different when they receive the same message.

key_points: Decision-making is the cognitive process of selecting a course of action or a choice from multiple alternatives

learning.explanation: Decision-making is the cognitive process of selecting a course of action or a choice from multiple alternatives. It involves identifying a problem or opportunity, gathering relevant information, assessing potential options, and ultimately making a commitment to a specific course of action. Key components of decision-making include (DECIDE mnemonic): DETECT (Identification of the Issue): Recognizing the need to make a decision, often in response to a problem, opportunity, or change in circumstances. ESTIMATE (Evaluation of Options): Assessing various possible courses of action or alternatives, considering their potential outcomes, risks, and benefits. CHOOSE (Selection of the Best Alternative): Choosing the most appropriate and desirable option based on the evaluation of available alternatives. IDENTIFY (Determine required Actions): Determine specific actions and strategies that can be employed to address the detected change. DO (Implementation): Putting the chosen decision into action, which may involve planning, execution, and coordination of resources. EVALUATE (Review and Adjustment): Reflecting on the outcomes of the decision, learning from the experience, and making adjustments or corrections if necessary. This step often feeds back into the decision-making process for future situations. The flight crew detected the problem correctly. During the evaluation of the options, the flight crew did not asses correctly the potential risk of failure of the electrical system. Consequently, they choose to continue to the destination with the risk of a total electrical failure instead of deviating to the alternate airport. This is an example of bad decision making.

content.question: Which of the following correctly describes "self-concept"?

options.A: The self-constructed idea formed by the beliefs one holds about oneself and the responses of others.
options.B: The innate, unchangeable characteristics and traits that define an individual's identity.
options.C: The degree of worth or self-acceptance a person holds for themselves.
options.D: The perception of all the characteristics and roles a person possesses at this particular moment.

key_points: Self-concept is the image that we have of ourselves
Self-concept is how you perceive your behaviour, abilities, and unique characteristics
For example, beliefs such as "I am a good friend" or "I am a kind person" are part of an overall self-concept
learning.explanation: Self-concept is the image that we have of ourselves. Self-concept is how you perceive your behaviour, abilities, and unique characteristics. For example, beliefs such as "I am a good friend" or "I am a kind person" are part of an overall self-concept. Carl Rogers believes that the self-concept has three different components: The view you have of yourself (self-image); How much value you place on yourself (self-esteem or self-worth); and What you wish you were really like (ideal-self).

content.question: What is the factor that can negatively influence decision-making?

options.A: Clear communication.
options.B: Sufficient time.
options.C: Biases and group effects.
options.D: Initial plan continuation and incorrect mental picture.

key_points: Mental picture: a cognitive representation of a visual scene or concept formed in the mind without the actual presence of the physical stimuli
It refers to the ability of the human mind to recreate, store, and manipulate information based on past experiences, memories, and imagination
Confirmation Bias: Decision-makers might have a tendency to favor information that confirms their preexisting beliefs or initial plan
learning.explanation: Mental picture: a cognitive representation of a visual scene or concept formed in the mind without the actual presence of the physical stimuli. It refers to the ability of the human mind to recreate, store, and manipulate information based on past experiences, memories, and imagination. Confirmation Bias: Decision-makers might have a tendency to favor information that confirms their preexisting beliefs or initial plan. This bias can lead them to overlook or dismiss contradictory information, which can result in flawed decision-making. They may actively seek out data that aligns with their initial plan while neglecting critical evidence that suggests alternative courses of action. This can lead to a failure to adapt to changing circumstances. Decision-makers who are overly confident in their initial plan or mental picture may not adequately consider potential risks or alternative options. This can lead to underestimating challenges and overestimating the chances of success, resulting in poor decisions. Decision-makers may fail to update their mental picture or adjust their plan when new, relevant information becomes available. This inflexibility can lead to missed opportunities. Focusing excessively on the initial plan or mental picture may cause decision-makers to overlook other crucial aspects of the situation. They may become so fixated on their preconceived ideas that they miss out on valuable insights, creative solutions, or warning signs that could influence their decision. Group effects do not always affect negative the decision making process.

What are the behaviours in this situation?

options.B: Captain - autonomous, first officer - cognitive, student pilot - associative.
options.C: Captain - associative, first officer - autonomous, student pilot - cognitive.
options.D: Captain - cognitive, first officer - associative, student pilot - autonomous.

key_points: Motor programmes are stored routines that enable patterns of behaviour to be executed without continuous conscious control
Motor programmes are stored in the procedural part of long-term memory and are retrieved when a skill shall be performed

Motor programmes enables an individual to perform more than one task at the same time by freeing mental resources – this way, one task can be performed requiring conscious attention, while performing another one at an unconscious level (motor programme)
learning.explanation: Motor programmes are stored routines that enable patterns of behaviour to be executed without continuous conscious control. Motor programmes are stored in the procedural part of long-term memory and are retrieved when a skill shall be performed. Motor programmes enables an individual to perform more than one task at the same time by freeing mental resources – this way, one task can be performed requiring conscious attention, while performing another one at an unconscious level (motor programme). According to J. R. Anderson, the acquisition of such expertise involves three stages, namely: Cognitive, Associative and Autonomous. Cognitive phase – the learner thinks consciously about each individual action. In this phase, movements are slow, inconsistent, and inefficient. The learner might need to recite mentally or aloud the steps which need to be taken. Associative phase – the separate components of the overall action become integrated. Movements become more fluid, reliable, and some parts of the action are controlled automatically. Automatic phase – the total manoeuvre can be executed smoothly without conscious control. At this stage, trying to consciously monitor its execution will slow it down and increase rate of error.

content.question: On a particular flight, the captain will be pilot flying and the copilot will be pilot monitoring. Before departure, both pilots have their radios tuned to the ground frequency. When they receive their taxi instructions, neither pilot hears the clearance. Who has committed an error?

options.A: Both pilots. While the pilot monitoring was in charge of active communication, also the pilot flying had to listen for instructions via radio.
options.B: The captain, because it was his responsibility as a commander to make sure his copilot monitored the frequency.
options.C: The ground controller, because he issued his clearance at a time where none of the pilots were actively listening.
options.D: The copilot, because he failed to closely monitor radio traffic, which was his obligation as the pilot monitoring.

key_points: Both Flight Crew members shall normally maintain a listening watch on the appropriate ATC frequency, including on the ground pre-flight
If a Flight Crew member goes off frequency, he/she must inform the other Flight Crew member
In a multi-crew environment, operators usually define who will be responsible for radio communicadtions, that is usually the pilot monitoring
learning.explanation: Both Flight Crew members shall normally maintain a listening watch on the appropriate ATC frequency, including on the ground pre-flight. If a Flight Crew member goes off frequency, he/she must inform the other Flight Crew member. In a multi-crew environment, operators usually define who will be responsible for radio communicadtions, that is usually the pilot monitoring. However, both pilots shall react independently and simultaneously to an ATC instruction. Both pilots have defined actions to do on receipt of a clearance and there is a cross check built into the process. The reason for independent simultaneous action is to ensure that both pilots have heard the instruction, have actioned the instruction and the crosscheck will identify any error by an individual pilot. If the response is not independent and simultaneous one pilot tends to follow the other and there is no opportunity to capture an error if one is made at this point. In this case, the question states that both pilots are tuned to the ground frequency, therefore both should be monitoring the radio - therefore, both have committed the error.

The long term memory contains information which is classified into three types Semantic memory - a type of long-term memory involving the capacity to recall words, concepts, or numbers, which is essential for the use and understanding of a language, for instance (stores general knowledge of the world)
Episodic memory - is a category of long-term memory that involves the recollection of specific events, situations, and experiences

The long term memory contains information which is classified into three types Semantic memory - a type of long-term memory involving the capacity to recall words, concepts, or numbers, which is essential for the use and understanding of a language, for instance (stores general knowledge of the world). Procedural memory/Motor programmes/skills - are behavioural sub-routines which are learnt by practice and/or repetition and are held within the long term memory and can be carried out without conscious thought. A skill is an organized and coordinated pattern of activity. It may be physical, social, linguistic or intellectual.

key_points: STANDARD OPERATING PROCEDURES (SOPs) Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs) in a multi-crew environment are essential for consistent and predictable responses to routine and emergency situations
They also provide for enhanced morale (meaning less friction) between crew members that is often caused by doing things differently
For pilots who are in training, or new to the company, they will help to ensure faster integration
learning.explanation: STANDARD OPERATING PROCEDURES (SOPs) Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs) in a multi-crew environment are essential for consistent and predictable responses to routine and emergency situations. They also provide for enhanced morale (meaning less friction) between crew members that is often caused by doing things differently. For pilots who are in training, or new to the company, they will help to ensure faster integration. SOPs provide a shared reference framework for all crew members and promote crew synergy. Standardization brings quality and healthy environments to achieve the highest level of safety. In fact, there are many reasons for SOPs, including: A logical order of events; Improvement in communication; Better error management; Better workload management and prioritisation; Improvements in cross-checking. The development of procedures makes pilots more effective and reliable in their activities - a process called - procedural consistency.

content.question: A pilot experiences an acute fatigue when (1) _____ and a chronic fatigue when (2) _____.

options.A: (1) on high workload; (2) stressed at home or at job
options.B: (1) lack of sleep; (2) physically stressed
options.C: (1) mentaly of physically stressed; (2) stressed at home or at job
options.D: (1) lack of sleep; (2) stressed at home or at job

key_points: Fatigue is a feeling of constant tiredness or weakness and can be physical, mental or a combination of both
The two types of fatigue are acute and chronic: Acute fatigue – short-term, more intense which usually affects the body
Acute stress activates the General Adaptation Syndrome (GAS), where physical, emotional and mental resources are mobilized to fight stress
learning.explanation: Fatigue is a feeling of constant tiredness or weakness and can be physical, mental or a combination of both. The two types of fatigue are acute and chronic: Acute fatigue – short-term, more intense which usually affects the body. Acute stress activates the General Adaptation Syndrome (GAS), where physical, emotional and mental resources are mobilized to fight stress. Acute fatigue often results from lack of sleep, therefore the most important measure to prevent fatigue-related performance loss is to ensure sufficient and restful sleep. Chronic fatigue – arises from more long-term effects, like many episodes of acute fatigue. Chronic fatigue typically happens after you’ve had no rest for some time and the body’s energy level cannot be restored after normal or increased periods of sleep. Psychological conditions related to chronic fatigue include anxiety, depression and chronic stress.

content.question:
During a long cruise with the auto-flight system engaged, a pilot becomes bored and realises that they may be suffering from hypovigilance. What can they do to overcome this?
1. Maintain good crew communication.
2. Keep vigilant during the cruise and strictly adhere to SOPs.
3. Fly the aircraft manually if conditions permit.
4. Experiment with the auto-flight system during the cruise to learn and fully understand its operating principles.

options.A: 1 and 2
options.B: 1, 2 and 3
options.C: 1, 2 and 4
options.D: 3 and 4

key_points: Note: This is very similar to question 403201, but with 1 less option, and slightly different wording

One of the most important aspects of a safe flight operation is the requirement for crew members to carefully monitor the aircraft's flight path and systems, as well as actively cross-check each other's actions
Humans are not good at monitoring constant situations and, therefore, it is easy to fall behind the aircraft
learning.explanation: Note: This is very similar to question 403201, but with 1 less option, and slightly different wording. One of the most important aspects of a safe flight operation is the requirement for crew members to carefully monitor the aircraft's flight path and systems, as well as actively cross-check each other's actions. Humans are not good at monitoring constant situations and, therefore, it is easy to fall behind the aircraft. This is especially true when no deviations are expected to occur, as in the case when monitoring automated systems. This can induce a feeling of automation complacency (too much reliance on the machine) and lead you not to check things as often as you should (hypovigilance). Hypovigilance is a lack of attention to detail, it is akin to a microsleep which can occur at any time during the flight, especially during periods of monotony, reduction of workload, during simple and repetitive tasks, low lighting, high temperature and constant and monotonous noise. During long-haul flights, hypovigilance is often unavoidable. To help prevent hypovigilance during flight, in a multi-crew operation, it is possible for crew-members to take planned naps (controlled rest) - these should be short, approx. 20min. It is also helpful to engage in social conversation with other crew members and physical activity such as arm and leg stretching may also assist in maintaining wakefulness. During the night, turning up the cockpit lights will also help. However, this deteriorates night vision. The SOPs have been written, authorised and amended for such long-haul flights with many physiological factors taken into account, and will make sure that the flight is completed to the correct safety standards, without faults or omissions, so they should always be followed. As for the other options, you should not "Experiment with the auto-flight system", as this gives the potential to induce an error which puts the current flight at risk. You should also not fly the aircraft manually, as this will likely be against SOPs (and against the law when inside RVSM airspace), and no-offence, but the autopilot is much more reliable to fly accurately in the cruise than a human pilot.

content.question: One negative aspect of the highly automated cockpit results in:

options.A: pilots disregarding the automatic equipment
options.B: less experienced crews because of more transparent system details
options.C: complacency among the crew members
options.D: constantly high crew overload with regard to the monitoring tasks

key_points: AUTOMATION Cockpit automation has the potential to increase or decrease the flight safety, depending on how well you use the equipment
Automation can conserve resources and attention, relieving pilot workload and giving time for supervision
However, if given too much control, the cockpit becomes boring, and errors can go unnoticed amongst the monotony
learning.explanation: AUTOMATION Cockpit automation has the potential to increase or decrease the flight safety, depending on how well you use the equipment. Automation can conserve resources and attention, relieving pilot workload and giving time for supervision. However, if given too much control, the cockpit becomes boring, and errors can go unnoticed amongst the monotony. Pilots can also become less confident in their basic airmanship and flying skills. Whereas machines can wait for infrequent information without getting bored, can perform long-term control and set values, again, without getting bored; people can exercise judgement, make better decisions, and detect unusual conditions (smells, noises), while getting easily bored. So, on the one hand, automation is good, because it can take a lot of routine work away from you. On the other hand, automation can induce a feeling of automation complacency – too much reliance on the machine, and lead you not to check things as often as you should. A high degree of automation may alter traditional tasks so much that your attention and competence is reduced once you are out of the loop. Thus, communication and coordination call for a greater effort from the crew. You can avoid automation complacency by regarding systems as one more crewmember that needs to be cross-checked – that is, you have to make sure that the autopilot is actually taking you in the right direction. You can cope with low error tolerant situations by constantly complying with cross-over verification procedures.
