learning.explanation: "1. quality of instruction" CORRECT. It is important that the effective instructor understands the subject being taught, the learner, the learning process, and the interrelationships that exist. An effective instructor also realizes learning is a complex procedure and assists each learner in reaching the desired outcomes while helping build self-esteem and confidence. It is important that the instructor adapts his instruction to the level of the trainee. "2. motivation" CORRECT. People learn and remember only what they wish to know. Without motivation there is little chance for recall. The most effective motivation is based on positive or rewarding objectives. To keep learning pleasant and to maintain motivation, an instructor should make positive comments about the learner’s progress before discussing areas that need improving. "3. feedback on the results of learning" CORRECT. As a learner practices a skill, it is important that he or she perform the skill correctly and that the skill being practiced is one that needs to be developed to maturity. An instructor ensures a skill is practiced correctly by monitoring the practice and providing feedback about the skill development. The learner profits by having someone watch the performance and provide constructive criticism to help eliminate errors. Providing compliments on aspects of the skill that were performed correctly help keep the evaluation positive. Allowing the learner to critique his or her performance enhances learner-centered training. "4. a large amount of reference material" INCORRET. Having different resources available to get information from is good. Each learner can select for him/herself which approach will work best. However, learners can get overwhelmed by too many resources (excessive options). It is difficult for learners to make decisions on how to learn when they are facing with a large amount of learning resources. A good instructor should guide the student through the many available options. "5. being free from time restrictions." INCORRET. Some people thrive on time constraints as the stress motivates them to do it.

content.question: Motor programmes involve behaviour routines, which...

options.A: are learnt by practice and carried out automatically.
options.B: are stored in the episodic memory and enable multi-tasking.
options.C: need to be monitored continuously.
options.D: are carried out with conscious attention and control.

key_points: Learning Objective 040
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 040.03.01.04.06: Explain the term ‘motor programme’ or ‘mental schema’. Motor programmes are stored routines that enable patterns of behaviour to be executed without continuous conscious control. Motor programmes are stored in the procedural part of long-term memory and are retrieved when a skill shall be performed. Motor programmes enable an individual to perform more than one task at the same time by freeing mental resources – this way, one task can be performed requiring conscious attention, while performing another one at an unconscious level (motor programme). According to J. R. Anderson, the acquisition of such expertise involves three stages, namely: Cognitive, Associative and Autonomous. Practising these routines allow a person to move up the phases over time, making the motor program more automatic. Cognitive phase – the learner thinks consciously about each individual action. In this phase, movements are slow, inconsistent, and inefficient. The learner might need to recite mentally or aloud the steps which need to be taken. Associative phase – the separate components of the overall action become integrated. Movements become more fluid, reliable, and some parts of the action are controlled automatically. Automatic phase – the total manoeuvre can be executed smoothly without conscious control. At this stage, trying to consciously monitor its execution will slow it down and increase rate of error.

content.question: Which of the following events would lead to the maximum domestic stress and affect a pilot’s mental well-being?

options.A: Death of a spouse or a child.
options.B: Divorce.
options.C: Depts.
options.D: Other significant life stressors (e.g., job loss, legal troubles).

key_points: STRESS Stress is a physiological and psychological response to events or situations that are perceived as challenging or threatening
It is a natural reaction that helps individuals cope with demanding circumstances by activating the body's "fight or flight" response
Stressors can be subdivided into internal (subjective) and external (objective) stressors
learning.explanation: STRESS Stress is a physiological and psychological response to events or situations that are perceived as challenging or threatening. It is a natural reaction that helps individuals cope with demanding circumstances by activating the body's "fight or flight" response. Stressors can be subdivided into internal (subjective) and external (objective) stressors. Another possible classification of stressors distinguishes between different categories, all of which can be subjective or objective: Environmental Stressors – environmental conditions, noise, vibrations, cosmic radiation, accelerations. Physiological Stressors – fatigue, lack of physical fitness, improper eating habits, hunger, thirst, cold/too hot, humidity, dehydration. Psychological/emotional stress – inter-personal conflicts, discrimination, fear of failure, death of a relative, divorce, financial problems, job insecurity. Domestic stressors – Social stressors (marriage, pregnancy or death), Economic stressors (bank loans, partner's loss of job, children's Christmas wishes, etc) and Environmental stressors (defective air conditioning or contruction sites close-by). Occupational or organisational stressors – strict policies and protocols implemented by the organization, restricted possibilities for professional and personal self-growth and conflicts among individuals in a department or between organizational groups. The death of a spouse, partner, or child has been identified as causing more stress than any other event. Certain airlines have policies in place to temporarily remove pilots from flying duties if they experience such a loss. This is because the stress levels of the pilot may be significantly elevated, potentially leading to a severe decline in performance and reaction times.

content.question: The available cognitive resources of the human brain..

options.A: are limited and make it impossible to perform two attentional tasks at the same time.
options.B: allow for simultaneous operation of twin tasks without any loss of effectiveness.
options.C: are limited but make it possible to easily perform several tasks at the same time.
options.D: are virtually unlimited.

key_points: The available cognitive resources are limited, so you cannot perform two attentional tasks at the same time
This is where motor programmes and divided attention come into play
Motor programmes are stored routines that enable patterns of behaviour to be executed without continuous conscious control
learning.explanation: The available cognitive resources are limited, so you cannot perform two attentional tasks at the same time. This is where motor programmes and divided attention come into play. Motor programmes are stored routines that enable patterns of behaviour to be executed without continuous conscious control. Motor programmes enables an individual to perform more than one task at the same time by freeing mental resources – this way, one task can be performed requiring conscious attention, while performing another one at an unconscious level (motor programme). Divided attention means a distribution of attention between two or more tasks that must be performed at the same time. However, due to the functioning principle of the human brain, attention can never really be divided. Instead, the brain is constantly switching back and forth between the tasks, always performing one of them at a time.

content.question: Compared to individuals on their own, a group of people will usually take a more (1) _____ decision, partly due to the notion that the subsequent (2) _____ will be shared.

options.A: (1) considerate; (2) blame
options.B: (1) risky; (2) blame
options.C: (1) risky; (2) accomplishment

key_points: Learning Objective 040
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 040.03.03.01.09: Describe the positive and negative influences exerted by other group members on an individual’s decision-making process (risky shift). Groups are more likely than individuals to make decisions concerning risk, known as Risky Shift. In other words, Risky shift occurs when people change their decisions or opinions to become more extreme and risky when acting as part of a group, compared with acting individually. It is quite a simple concept really, and you may have seen its effects before. One of the potential causes of risky shift is mentioned in this question, by the fact that the individual members of the group see their decision as less risky as the blame for any problems could be shared (this is often a subconscious thought). That is not the only reason that risky shift occurs though, there are other psychological factors at play.

Commision - Errors of commission occur when crew members carryout a task incorrectly or do something that is not required
Later researchers further differentiated human error as: Slips - Which occur as the result of minor errors of execution
learning.explanation: Types of human error The simplest catergorisation of human error would be to split them into errors of omission or commission: Omission - Errors of omission occur when crew members fail to carryout a required task. Commision - Errors of commission occur when crew members carryout a task incorrectly or do something that is not required. Later researchers further differentiated human error as: Slips - Which occur as the result of minor errors of execution. Lapses - Which occur when a pilot becomes distracted and doesn’t complete a task or omits a step whilst performing it. Mistakes - Which occur when actions conform to an inadequate plan. Violations - Which occur where actions deviate from safe procedures standards or rules, be they deliberate or erroneous.

Safety Risk Management is one of the four components of ICAO framework. It is based on the general safety policy and aimed at detecting the safety threats in the individual operation and establishing procedures to mitigate the risks and/or contain the damage caused by a break. To do a risk assessment, the hazard must be identified, it is then important to determine the likelihood of the risk (probability) and its severity; so that it is possible to assess how immediately is our attention required, or if it is at all.

key_points: COMMUNICATION The first cockpit tool that tends to suffer from stress is communication

When several tasks have to be performed simultaneously, especially when these tasks require a lot of conscious attention, people tend to reduce communication, because communication uses up mental resources and time
Communication is the exchange of thoughts, messages, or information by various means, including speech
learning.explanation: COMMUNICATION The first cockpit tool that tends to suffer from stress is communication. When several tasks have to be performed simultaneously, especially when these tasks require a lot of conscious attention, people tend to reduce communication, because communication uses up mental resources and time. Communication is the exchange of thoughts, messages, or information by various means, including speech. Therefore, in a high workload environment, when a pilot's mind is already very busy on another task such as flying the aircraft or coordinating an abnormal situation, their communications will usually become lesser, as to not take up as much time, nor processing power in their already nearly saturated minds. This is one of the largest reasons to have SOPs (Standard Operating Procedures) which dictate what communications should be made, as it 'takes a load off' the pilot's mind, and allows the correct communication to be made without unnecessary stress or workload.

content.question: A copilot was hired by a renowned company for a short-term contract. Approaching the end of his/her contract, he/she learns that only one out of two co-pilots will be offered a subsequent contract for continuation of their employment. The copilot shows a high motivation. What should a commander flying with this copilot pay particular attention to?

options.A: It can be assumed that the copilot is under pressure to perform, because he feels that any mistake could cause his employer to give the vacant spot to his competitor at the end of the contract. The commander should aim to remove some of the pressure by reassuring the copilot that his work is highly appreciated.
options.B: The commander should be aware that the copilot will probably feel a lower desire to perform, because the end of his contract is approaching and he may not be working for the company for very long. The commander should remind the copilot that any deterioration in performance will not be tolerated.
options.C: It is the commander’s responsibility to assist his employer in deciding on the better copilot for continuation of the contract. He should therefore closely monitor the copilot’s work and report any errors or insecurities to his superior without the copilot noticing.
options.D: The commander should tell the copilot that he is aware of his possibly increased basic stress level and demand clearly that the copilot keep all his personal emotions out of the cockpit.

key_points: Motivation refers to degree of readiness of an organism to pursue some designated goal and implies the determination of the nature and locus of the forces, including the degree of readiness
In other words, it is a drive to behave in a particular fashion which usually leads to a change of behaviour
It is an internal force which can affect the quality of performance
learning.explanation: Motivation refers to degree of readiness of an organism to pursue some designated goal and implies the determination of the nature and locus of the forces, including the degree of readiness. In other words, it is a drive to behave in a particular fashion which usually leads to a change of behaviour. It is an internal force which can affect the quality of performance. The learning process is vastly improved with motivation and high performance rarely comes without it, as it increases attention and vigilance. Over-motivation can be just as much of a hindrance – excessive motivation together with high levels of stress will limit your attention-management capabilities. In short, you can get fixated. With regards to this question, this situation will place extra cognitive stress on the individual which can negatively affect performance. The commander shall be aware that his/her colleague is prone to make more errors, especially under challenging situations. Establishing a relaxed atmosphere on the flight deck could have a positive impact on the co-pilot's performance.

key_points: Top-down perception comes into play when you make a scene fit what you expect it to be, rather than perceive reality
These perceptions are heavily influenced by our expectations and prior knowledge
For example, when two similar objects are viewed from the same distance, our brain assesses them to have the same size
learning.explanation: Top-down perception comes into play when you make a scene fit what you expect it to be, rather than perceive reality. These perceptions are heavily influenced by our expectations and prior knowledge. For example, when two similar objects are viewed from the same distance, our brain assesses them to have the same size. From past experience, it will be assumed that the object which creates the smaller image has to be further away. Such assumption is based on stored data.

content.question: During flight, a terrain proximity caution sounds in the flight deck. The pilot misidentifies the problem, believing that the auditory alert is associated with a configuration warning; subsequently applying the wrong procedures. This error is associated with…

options.A: knowledge-based behaviour.
options.B: procedure-based behaviour.
options.C: skill-based behaviour.
options.D: rule-based behaviour.

key_points: Learning Objective 040
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 040.03.01.04.09: State the possible problems or risks associated with skill-, rule- and knowledge-based behaviour. In Rasmussen's model, he lays out three different layers of behaviours: Skill-based behaviours. Rule-based behaviours. Knowledge-based behaviours. It is therefore known as the "SRK model". The annex describes each type of behaviour, but in simple terms, skill-based behaviours are the lowest tier, items that are completed without thinking, rule-based behaviours are items that are completed from procedures already set out (from memory or written down) and knowledge-based behaviours, the highest tier, are when significant thought has to be put into something (and no specific rules are set out for it). This scenario required a bit of thought from the pilot, and reference to a procedure, making it a rule-based behaviour. The problem occurred in that the pilot misidentified the warning, which they had to think about, therefore ruling out that it might be a skill-based behaviour mistake (which would be an automatic - no thought required - reaction). There is a set procedure in place (whether by memory or in the checklist), so it is not a knowledge-based behaviour. The errors associated with rule-based behaviours are: Error of commission (doing something that should not have been done) Departure from rules interruptions violations This scenario is a classic case of "doing the wrong thing, the correct way", and is an error of commission.

It is recommended that learners try the different methods to discover which approach suits them best

learning.explanation: Each individual has their own unique mental training approach that works best for them. It is recommended that learners try the different methods to discover which approach suits them best. Practicing checks and flows using a cardboard cut-out of the cockpit can be a useful experience for many of us. It provides an opportunity to familiarize oneself with the layout of instruments and controls, and is an excellent way to rehearse checks without being in the actual aircraft. The more you practice, the easier it becomes when you finally take to the skies. The forms of mental training that one can explore include repetition, through reading, writing, or rehearsing again and again.

key_points: STANDARD OPERATING PROCEDURES (SOPs) Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs) in a multi-crew environment are essential for consistent and predictable responses to routine and emergency situations
They also provide for enhanced morale (meaning less friction) between crew members that is often caused by doing things differently
For pilots who are in training, or new to the company, they will help to ensure faster integration
learning.explanation: STANDARD OPERATING PROCEDURES (SOPs) Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs) in a multi-crew environment are essential for consistent and predictable responses to routine and emergency situations. They also provide for enhanced morale (meaning less friction) between crew members that is often caused by doing things differently. For pilots who are in training, or new to the company, they will help to ensure faster integration. SOPs provide a shared reference framework for all crew members and promote crew synergy. Standardization brings quality and healthy environments to achieve the highest level of safety. In fact, there are many reasons for SOPs, including: A logical order of events; Improvement in communication; Better error management; Better workload management and prioritisation; Improvements in cross-checking. The development of procedures makes pilots more effective and reliable in their activities - a process called - procedural consistency. Strict adherence to Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs) can eliminate or at least mitigate the adverse effects of various operational factors and human errors that can lead to incidents and accidents.

content.question: Motivation, crew-climate and "Confirmation Bias" are factors that:

options.A: can influence the situational awareness.
options.B: depend only on personality and are unchangeable.
options.C: have no influence on teamwork.
options.D: are easy to control.

key_points: Confirmation Bias is the term used to describe the tendency to search for information to confirm a theory, while overlooking contradicting information
Thus, even if presented with facts which would allow correcting the mental model, a pilot will probably find it difficult to get out of his original interpretation
It can be likened to making the ground fit the map, rather than accepting the fact that we are lost
learning.explanation: Confirmation Bias is the term used to describe the tendency to search for information to confirm a theory, while overlooking contradicting information. Thus, even if presented with facts which would allow correcting the mental model, a pilot will probably find it difficult to get out of his original interpretation. It can be likened to making the ground fit the map, rather than accepting the fact that we are lost. You could also look upon it as a tendency to ignore information that confirms a decision is a poor one. A good strategy to avoid confirmation bias is to actively search for information that could falsify the mental model of the current situation or for different interpretations of the given information. Crew-climate (in other words, working atmosphere) also affects situational awareness. For example, an unresolved conflict between crewmember uses up resources that cannot be directed to flight-related activities, thereby greatly reducing situational awareness. Motivation plays an important role on situational awareness. If motivation is too low (i.e., the task at hand is considered irrelevant), a person will have to force him/herself to concentrate on what he/she is doing. This will increase the probability of distractions interfering with the task, attention will generally be low. On the other hand, high motivation comes along with high levels of arousal. Consequently, situational awareness is lost.

content.question: Which one of the following statements is true about the "irony of automation"? It reduces the workload but...

options.A: ... It does not take control in an emergency.
options.B: ... It does not remove humans from the equation, only gives them new tasks.
options.C: ... It is too expensive, but does a lot of work.
options.D: ... It can make the aircraft uncontrollable in case of automation malfunction.

key_points: IRONIES OF AUTOMATION is a research paper written by Lisanne Bainbridge and published in Automatica in 1983, and has been widely recognized as a pioneering statement of the problems inherent in automation
This paper discusses the ways in which automation of industrial processes may expand rather than eliminate problems with the human operator
The thoughts of Bainbridge on the topic of automation from nearly forty years ago are just as relevant today, if not more so
learning.explanation: IRONIES OF AUTOMATION is a research paper written by Lisanne Bainbridge and published in Automatica in 1983, and has been widely recognized as a pioneering statement of the problems inherent in automation. This paper discusses the ways in which automation of industrial processes may expand rather than eliminate problems with the human operator. The thoughts of Bainbridge on the topic of automation from nearly forty years ago are just as relevant today, if not more so. Irony 1: Designers are human too! One of the ironies of designers attempting to eliminate humans from the system, is that operating problems may occur due to errors introduced by designers => humans are not removed from the system. Irony 2: Tasks that are not automated rely on humans Once people are eliminated as much as possible in the design, the human operator is left with an arbitrary collection of tasks that the designer could not eliminate. Whatever human tasks remain may not comprise a cohesive, meaningful or satisfying job role. Decisions tend to only consider allocating a task to a human or an automated system; when in fact, a more dynamic allocation of function may be more appropriate (i.e. allocation depending upon the scenario). Irony 3: The human may have to ‘take over’ if the system fails Automated systems can malfunction and then have to be repaired by human beings. Which means that even after it has been completed and is in use, automated systems depend on human work.

key_points: LONG TERM MEMORY This is where all our basic knowledge (e
g
, memories of childhood, training, etc
learning.explanation: LONG TERM MEMORY This is where all our basic knowledge (e.g., memories of childhood, training, etc.) is kept – you might liken it to the unconscious, with more capacity and ability to retain information than short term memory – its storage capacity is regarded as unlimited, and possibly consists of several interlaced systems, such as semantic memory, episodic memory, plus procedural memory. Procedural Memory: stores information about motor skills e.g. interaction of muscles and balance involved in riding a bicycle. Episodic Memory: stores information about past events which can be affected by suggestion e.g. last year’s holidays (can be unreliable). Amnesia usually affects only episodic memory. Semantic Memory: stores general knowledge e.g. the meaning of words, grammar rules etc. It tends to be accurate and long lasting. Repetition (or rehearsing) is used to get information into it, combined with organising it, placing it into some sort of context or associating it with an emotion. The main limitation of the long-term memory is that information retrieval can be difficult. Therefore, knowledge stored in long-term memory should be pre-activated (with planning and anticipation) so it can be available when required and have the access time reduced. Long-term memory is influenced by experience, repetition, suggestion, desires, and expectations.

content.question: Are expectations able to hamper effective communication?

options.A: Yes, a person expecting a particular message can assume that this is what they hear, while the actual message is different.
options.B: Yes, when one person expects another person to share the same values, they can make inappropriate statements.
options.C: Yes, when one person in a group feels that an expectation does NOT apply to them, it can make them feel uncomfortable and could lead to conflict.
options.D: No, expectations are NOT important as regards effective communication, but they are very important when it comes to conflict resolution.

key_points: Expectations can act as obstacles to effective communication
When someone has a specific expectation about the message they are about to receive, they may unconsciously filter or interpret the information in a way that aligns with their preconceived notion
This can lead to a misunderstanding or misinterpretation of the actual message being communicated
learning.explanation: Expectations can act as obstacles to effective communication. When someone has a specific expectation about the message they are about to receive, they may unconsciously filter or interpret the information in a way that aligns with their preconceived notion. This can lead to a misunderstanding or misinterpretation of the actual message being communicated. To overcome this obstacle, it is important for both the sender and the receiver to be aware of their own biases and expectations. The sender should strive to communicate clearly and explicitly, using precise language to minimize the chances of misinterpretation. The receiver should practice active listening, setting aside assumptions and allowing themselves to fully understand the message being conveyed. Expectations in communication have been responsible for several accidents, with one common example being when a flight crew anticipates their request to air traffic control to be approved. If the controller's response is unclear, abbreviated, too soft, or delivered rapidly, there is a risk that the expected approval is assumed by the crew. These incidents often occur when time is limited. The Tenerife disaster was influenced by multiple factors, including expectations in communication.

content.question: Metacommunication is defined as…

options.A: having an assessment conversation
options.B: active listening
options.C: those aids, other than the actual words, which complement those words in order to communicate
options.D: balancing the own ideas and interests with those of the receiver

key_points: COMMUNICATION The first cockpit tool that tends to suffer from stress is communication

When several tasks have to be performed simultaneously, especially when these tasks require a lot of conscious attention, people tend to reduce communication, because communication also uses up mental resources
Communication is the exchange of thoughts, messages, or information by various means, including speech
learning.explanation: COMMUNICATION The first cockpit tool that tends to suffer from stress is communication. When several tasks have to be performed simultaneously, especially when these tasks require a lot of conscious attention, people tend to reduce communication, because communication also uses up mental resources. Communication is the exchange of thoughts, messages, or information by various means, including speech. Officially, around 80% of all communication is achieved by factors other than words, otherwise known as metacommunication, which consists of those tools, other than the words, which complement them in order to communicate. The fact that somebody is not talking does not mean they are not communicating. It is said that 7% of communication is accomplished verbally, 38% by unconscious signals, such as tone of voice, and the remainder 55% by non-verbal means, such as body language. Non-verbal communication can accompany verbal communication, such as a smile during a face-to-face chat. Body language can be very subtle, but powerful – for example, the word “no” with a smile will be interpreted quite differently from one accompanied by a smack in the mouth. Non-verbal communication may also include written information or notes. Unfortunately, the side-by-side seating arrangements in the cockpit tend to lessen the effects of body language, so the choice of words (and their packaging) assumes a greater importance.

content.question: Considering Rasmussen's model of information processing when making decisions based on weather information, the processing:

options.A: Always involves the skill-based, rule-based, and knowledge-based levels.
options.B: By an experienced pilot involves only the knowledge-based level.
options.C: By an experienced pilot involves only the rule-based level.
options.D: Involves the rule-based and knowledge-based levels.

key_points: Rule-based behaviour The behaviour is guided by rules which the person has to perform known tasks
The person recognizes the situation and applies the right procedure to perform the task, and then performs a series of actions by the use of procedures
In this case, the cognitive engagement is high and implies a certain reasoning
learning.explanation: Rule-based behaviour The behaviour is guided by rules which the person has to perform known tasks. The person recognizes the situation and applies the right procedure to perform the task, and then performs a series of actions by the use of procedures. In this case, the cognitive engagement is high and implies a certain reasoning. Knowledge-based behaviour It is the behaviour to use when you are in the presence of new or unforeseen situations, that is not known, for which you do not know the rules or procedures of reference. The person must react creatively and independently, i.e. without the use of procedures or instinctive behaviors, based on the information available and the knowledge gained. "always involves the skill-based, rule-based, and knowledge-based levels." Incorrect ⇒ Decision-making does not always involve skill-based behaviour

content.question:
Which of the following are typical examples of the effects of long-term fatigue in flight crew?
1. General reduction in performance.
2. Tiredness and falling asleep for short periods without being aware that this happens.
3. Inability to sleep.
4. Increase in physiological and mental health problems.
5. Reduction in visual acuity.

key_points: Fatigue is a feeling of constant tiredness or weakness and can be physical, mental or a combination of both
The two types of fatigue are acute and chronic: Acute fatigue – short-term, more intense which usually affects the body, and just needs a good nights’ sleep to sort things out
Chronic fatigue – arises from more long-term effects, like many episodes of acute fatigue
learning.explanation: Fatigue is a feeling of constant tiredness or weakness and can be physical, mental or a combination of both. The two types of fatigue are acute and chronic: Acute fatigue – short-term, more intense which usually affects the body, and just needs a good nights’ sleep to sort things out. Chronic fatigue – arises from more long-term effects, like many episodes of acute fatigue. In this case, normal or increased periods of sleep cannot restore the body's energy level and people do not even feel refreshed for a short time after a night's sleep. Fatigue affects physical and mental functions, and is accompanied by hypovigilance, thus also having an effect on work performance. Fatigue is usually accompanied by a noticeable lack of concentraction and memory. Some people with chronic fatigue have sleep difficulties as well. These can include finding it hard to get to sleep, waking up often during the night and/or waking up too early in the morning. In addition to the effects that can be found with acute fatigue, chronic fatigue can cause serious health issues such as cardiovascular or gastro-intestinal disease, reduced fertility, diabetes, asthma and mental disorders like depression. content.question: Conflicts in cockpit are a serious threat to flight safety. What marks Conflict escalation?

options.A: Advocacy, negotiation and inquiry.
options.B: Increasing verbal aggression and entrenchment, but not violence.
options.C: Increasing verbal aggression and threats, and may or may not lead to violence.
options.D: Switching from intra- to interpersonal conflict.

key_points: Glasl divides the nine stages of conflict escalation into three levels
On the first three levels it is still possible for both parties to drop out without damage or even with profit (win-win), this level ends when empathy for the opponent is lost
On the second level one of the two must be the loser (win-lose)
learning.explanation: Glasl divides the nine stages of conflict escalation into three levels. On the first three levels it is still possible for both parties to drop out without damage or even with profit (win-win), this level ends when empathy for the opponent is lost. On the second level one of the two must be the loser (win-lose). It is no longer possible to find a solution which satisfies both parties. Threats are used to increase pressure and demonstrate power. On the third level there are only losses on both sides until mutual annihilation (lose-lose). Conflicting parties now no longer aim to have it "their way", they strive to cause the greatest damage to the opponent. Physical violence may be used. As seen above, the deeper you go towards the last level, the more primitive and inhuman the methods become by which the opponents try to win. Therefore, Glasl does not present his model as an ascent to the higher levels of escalation, but as a descending staircase that literally leads further and further into the depths of human morality

content.question: An aircraft only has a small crew. Will they still have influence on each other's behaviour?

options.A: No, because they are a small group.
options.B: Yes, they will still influence their decisions.
options.C: A group never influences a person's behaviour.
options.D: The small crew will be much less likely to agree on any decisions, which is dangerous.

key_points: Learning Objective 040
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 040.03.03.01.09: Describe the positive and negative influences exerted by other group members on an individual’s decision-making process (risky shift). Being in a group natural changes the way people behave, in comparison to if they were alone. Larger groups tend to make riskier decisions that a single person would make, due to many reasons, which include an element of bravado, and a slightly macho attitude (this is known as risky shift, and is something to watch out for). Alternatively, groups can include the right people who foster a higher quality outcome, such as if a highly experienced, amiable captain is paired with a less confident junior first officer, the first officer will often perform well and may learn plenty of valuable tips and tricks along the way. Even the smallest group of people (2 of course), will cause an effect on the behaviour and decisions of both the members, which will differ somewhat from if they were alone. Larger groups do have a different effect to smaller groups, but there is always an effect at play. Another effect is groupthink, which can occur when each member wants to conform with the group's thinking and decisions, and not many opposite opinions are put forward. This is another potentially dangerous effect. Note: This question was created from incomplete feedback. Any exam feedback can be put in the comments or emailed to info@atplquestions.com, thank you.

content.question: The behaviour of a group can be affected by a number of factors including:

options.A: Age, persuasion, conformity and height.
options.B: Conformity, age, obedience, background.
options.C: Compliance, conformity, height, obedience.
options.D: Persuasion, conformity, compliance, and obedience.

key_points: GROUPS Groups behave differently from individuals
That is to say, a person may carry out different actions in concert with others than would be done solo
The behaviour of a group can be affected by a number of factors including: Persuasion
learning.explanation: GROUPS Groups behave differently from individuals. That is to say, a person may carry out different actions in concert with others than would be done solo. The behaviour of a group can be affected by a number of factors including: Persuasion. Refers to the process of changing attitudes, opinions and behaviours of other group members. In contrast to negotiation, which implies retreating and meeting somewhere in the middle, persuasion means to make people completely abandon their point of view to accept the persuader's one. Pilots should not suppress opinions which could lead to a better outcome. Conformity. Concerns the likelihood of an individual to go along with a group decision. The idea of being integrated into the team, to be recognised as a leader, or to avoid conflicts, may lead to a disposition to agree with decisions made by others. This tendency increases when new people enter an existing group. This poses the threat for the group to lose valuable input, as it becomes difficult to voice an alternate opinion. Compliance. Compliant behaviour is shown in groups when requested by another group memeber or the leader. The aim being to be socially accepted, receive a reward or avoid punishment. Obedience. Being obedient means following the orders of someone with a higher social status just because the orders were given. Crew members should remain prepared to challenge orders if they are believed to be suboptimal.

content.question: The crew of an aircraft encounters total loss of both electrical power generators. The electrical sources remaining are the batteries which are designed to provide power for 30 minutes. The crew detects the failure but does NOT complete the check-list and does not disconnect non-essential electrical equipment. The nearest suitable aerodrome is 20 minutes away, but the Commander decides to continue to destination, which is 30 minutes away. During the approach to the destination aerodrome a complete electrical failure is encountered and critical flight instruments are lost. Which statements best describes the decision-making errors in this scenario?

options.A: Once the crew decide on their course of action, they fail to review their choice. In this type of emergency, it is important to make an immediate decision, as soon as the checklist is started.
options.B: The error lies in the implementation phase of the decision-making process: the decision to continue to the destination is a good one, since the batteries should last for 30 minutes, but the crew fail to follow the flight plan.
options.C: The crew misinterpret the situation, and the decision to continue to the destination is a consequence of this. Since they do NOT collect and evaluate all the relevant information about the electrical failure, a review of their decision is NOT necessary.
options.D: The crew correctly recognise the failure, but they act incorrectly regarding the checklist, they fail to properly assess the risk associated with the problem, they poorly evaluate the available options, and they fail to review their decision.

key_points: In this scenario, there are several decision-making errors made by the crew: Failure to complete the appropriate Checklist: The crew correctly detects the failure of both electrical power generators, which is a good initial response
However, they make an error by not completing the appropriate checklist
Checklists are designed to guide pilots through critical procedures and ensure that all necessary actions are taken to address the issue
learning.explanation: In this scenario, there are several decision-making errors made by the crew: Failure to complete the appropriate Checklist: The crew correctly detects the failure of both electrical power generators, which is a good initial response. However, they make an error by not completing the appropriate checklist. Checklists are designed to guide pilots through critical procedures and ensure that all necessary actions are taken to address the issue. By not completing the checklist, they may overlook important steps or fail to identify potential risks. Continuing to use non-essential electrical equipment: Even after detecting the failure, the crew continues to use non-essential electrical equipment. This decision could further drain the limited power supply from the batteries and reduce the available time to make critical decisions or take corrective actions. Failure to properly assess the risk: The crew does not adequately assess the risk associated with the problem. They are aware that the batteries are expected to last for only 30 minutes, but they do not consider the consequences of using non-essential electrical equipment and how it may impact the remaining power reserve. Poor evaluation of available options: The Commander decides not to divert to the nearest suitable aerodrome, which is 20 minutes away. Instead, they choose to continue to the destination, which is 30 minutes away. This decision shows poor evaluation of available options, as diverting to the nearest aerodrome would have been a safer choice given the limited remaining battery life. Failure to review the decision: After deciding to continue to the destination, the crew does not review or reassess their decision, even when faced with a complete electrical failure during the approach. A lack of review means they miss the opportunity to recognize the increasing risk and reconsider their plan. In summary, the crew correctly recognizes the initial failure but makes a series of decision-making errors by not completing the checklist, continuing to use non-essential electrical equipment, poorly evaluating options, and failing to review their decision. These errors lead to a critical situation during the approach to the destination, with the loss of critical flight instruments due to a complete electrical failure.

content.question: During high workload periods in the cockpit, the use of "professional language"...

options.B: can improve personal communication.

key_points: PROFESSIONAL LANGUAGE The use of professional language in the cockpit is essential to minimize misunderstandings during communication between the crew members, and during communication between the pilots and the ATC

Professional language refers to the call-outs used between the crew members as described in SOPs and the standard phraseology used between the pilots and the ATC as described in ICAO Doc 9432 (Manual of Radiotelephony)
Professional language specifies the exact wording to be used and the exact meaning and response required by the receiver
learning.explanation: PROFESSIONAL LANGUAGE The use of professional language in the cockpit is essential to minimize misunderstandings during communication between the crew members, and during communication between the pilots and the ATC. Professional language refers to the call-outs used between the crew members as described in SOPs and the standard phraseology used between the pilots and the ATC as described in ICAO Doc 9432 (Manual of Radiotelephony). Professional language specifies the exact wording to be used and the exact meaning and response required by the receiver. It includes restricted and specific wording, limited vocabulary and simplified grammar. This speeds up communication since no time is lost to interpret the message. The result is that quality communication is achieved in the cockpit in a small period of time and misunderstandings are minimized.

It is the body’s response to a stressor, which is an internal or external stimulus that is interpreted as a threat to the body’s equilibrium, and prepares it for action
There are three types of stressors: Environmental Stressors – environmental conditions, noise, vibrations, cosmic radiation, accelerations
learning.explanation: STRESS Stress disturbs the body’s homeostasis and enables you to adapt to encountered situations. It is the body’s response to a stressor, which is an internal or external stimulus that is interpreted as a threat to the body’s equilibrium, and prepares it for action. There are three types of stressors: Environmental Stressors – environmental conditions, noise, vibrations, cosmic radiation, accelerations. content.question: The tendency to avoid making difficult choices or accepting responsibility exhibits which attitude?

options.A: Resignation
options.B: Complacency
options.C: Machismo complex
options.D: Invulnerability

key_points: HAZARDOUS ATTITUDES Studies have identified five hazardous attitudes among pilots that can interfere with a pilot’s ability to make effective decisions
ANTI-AUTHORITY (“don’t tell me”) – You display this attitude if you resent having someone tell you what to do, or you regard rules and procedures as unnecessary
Antidote – Follow the rules
learning.explanation: HAZARDOUS ATTITUDES Studies have identified five hazardous attitudes among pilots that can interfere with a pilot’s ability to make effective decisions. ANTI-AUTHORITY (“don’t tell me”) – You display this attitude if you resent having someone tell you what to do, or you regard rules and procedures as unnecessary. Antidote – Follow the rules. They are usually right. IMPULSIVITY (“do it quickly”) – If you feel the need to act immediately and do the first thing that comes to mind without considering the best solution to a problem, then you are exhibiting impulsivity. Antidote – Not so fast. Think first. INVULNERABILITY (“It won’t happen to me”) – You are more likely to take chances and increase risk if you think accidents will not happen to you. Antidote – It could happen to me. MACHO (“I can do it”) – If you have this attitude, you might take risks trying to prove that you are better than anyone else. Women are just as likely to have this characteristic as men. Antidote – Taking chances is foolish. RESIGNATION (“What’s the use?”) – You are experiencing resignation if you feel that no matter what you do, it will have little effect on what happens to you. You may feel that when things go well, it is just good luck and when things go poorly, it is bad luck or someone else is responsible. This feeling can cause you to leave the action to others – for better or worse. Antidote – I am not helpless. I can make a difference.

content.question: What is correct regarding active errors? An active error is:

options.A: Produced either by a front-line operator (e.g. pilot) or by a remote operator (e.g. maintenance engineer) and the effects are hidden or have a delayed impact.
options.B: NOT common at the human-system interface and difficult to detect as it usually occurs in a complex system of uncontrolled and involuntary deviations.
options.C: The consequence of the application of a bad rule or poor application of a good rule by aircraft designers and/or manufacturers.
options.D: Committed by the operator (e.g. pilot, air traffic controller) and has an immediate effect.

key_points: ACTIVE AND LATENT ERRORS An error, officially, arises when a planned sequence of activities fails to achieve the intended outcome, where random external intervention is not involved
The terms active and latent as applied to errors were coined by Reason

Latent errors have consequences that lie dormant and are difficult to recognize or foresee because of the time lag between their generation and occurrence, while active errors, which are committed at the human/system interface, have consequences that are felt almost immediately, which is how they can be detected
learning.explanation: ACTIVE AND LATENT ERRORS An error, officially, arises when a planned sequence of activities fails to achieve the intended outcome, where random external intervention is not involved. The terms active and latent as applied to errors were coined by Reason. Latent errors have consequences that lie dormant and are difficult to recognize or foresee because of the time lag between their generation and occurrence, while active errors, which are committed at the human/system interface, have consequences that are felt almost immediately, which is how they can be detected. Active errors are committed by the “sharp end”, those people who are directly involved in flight operations (pilots, ATC, etc). Latent errors are usually committed by the blunt-end, people who are not directly engaged in flight operations. However, latent errors can also be made by front-line personnel. An example of a latent error committed by a pilot would be the selection of a wrong waypoint in a GPS database.

content.question: Which steps within the Aeronautical Decision Making (ADM) process relate to the "DECIDE" model?

options.A: Detect, Evaluate, Choose, Implement, Decide, Enable
options.B: Decide, Estimate, Clarify, Identify, Decide, Enable
options.C: Detect, Estimate, Choose, Identify, Do, Evaluate
options.D: Detect, Enable, Clarify, Implement, Do, Evaluate

key_points: DECIDE MODEL The six-step process DECIDE Model is another continuous loop process that provides the pilot with a logical way of making decisions: DETECT
The decision maker detects the fact that change has occurred; ESTIMATE
The decision maker estimates the need to counter or react to the change; CHOOSE
learning.explanation: DECIDE MODEL The six-step process DECIDE Model is another continuous loop process that provides the pilot with a logical way of making decisions: DETECT. The decision maker detects the fact that change has occurred; ESTIMATE. The decision maker estimates the need to counter or react to the change; CHOOSE. The decision maker chooses a desirable outcome (in terms of success) for the flight; IDENTIFY. The decision maker identifies actions which could successfully control the change; DO. The decision maker takes the necessary action; EVALUATE. The decision maker evaluates the effect(s) of his/her action countering the change.

content.question:
Which of the following describe(s) situations where "selective attention" and "divided attention" are employed?
1. During the take-off, the Pilot Monitoring and Pilot Flying select relevant information, dividing the workloads according to their specific duties
2. ATC instructs the pilot to climb to 2 500 ft on QNH 1011. The pilot uses selective attention to listen to the radio, and selective and divided attention to check the altimeter settings and aircraft level
3. A pilot training on basic instrument flying manoeuvres focuses attention on the basic instruments and divides attention in cross-checking their indications while controlling the aircraft

options.A: 1 and 2.
options.B: 1 and 3.
options.C: 2 and 3.
options.D: 3 only.

key_points: Attention is the process of directing and focusing psychological resources to enhance perception, performance and mental experience
Attention is a limited resource that can be affected by distraction, selectivity or motivation, which is where habit takes over

DIVIDED ATTENTION This is the alternative management of several matters of interest at (almost) the same time, as when monitoring the progress of a motor program on a relatively subconscious level whilst making a radio call (time sharing)
learning.explanation: Attention is the process of directing and focusing psychological resources to enhance perception, performance and mental experience. Attention is a limited resource that can be affected by distraction, selectivity or motivation, which is where habit takes over. DIVIDED ATTENTION This is the alternative management of several matters of interest at (almost) the same time, as when monitoring the progress of a motor program on a relatively subconscious level whilst making a radio call (time sharing). In this case, some tasks may suffer at the expense of others, especially if they are similar in nature. SELECTIVE ATTENTION With selective attention, one gives greater attention to one or more sources of input out of several. Such a selective mechanism is required because the resources of the Central Decision Maker and short-term memory are limited. It is the process during which information is sampled to see if it is relevant, which makes you able to detect information meant for you, such as your callsign, even if you are not specifically monitoring the source

content.question: A pilot is told by ATC to change their transponder squawk to a different 4-digit code, but at the same time, a cabin crew member enters the flight deck and asks a question. Once the question has been answered, the pilot realises they have forgotten the new squawk code without entering it into the transponder. What has happened?

options.A: The pilot could not store all 4 digits in their working memory at once.
options.B: The information was lost from the working memory because of the interruption.
options.C: The pilot could not recall the transponder code from their long-term memory.
options.D: The pilot did not "chunk" the digits to make them more memorable, and therefore lost them from memory.

key_points: WORKING MEMORY Otherwise known as short-term memory, this is for data that is used and forgotten almost instantly
The capacity of the working memory is limited to 5 plus/minus 2 items (7 plus/minus 2 according to the old syllabus), which can be stored for an average period of 15 to 20 seconds
Some information can last in short-term memory for up to a minute if rehearsal strategies are used
learning.explanation: WORKING MEMORY Otherwise known as short-term memory, this is for data that is used and forgotten almost instantly. The capacity of the working memory is limited to 5 plus/minus 2 items (7 plus/minus 2 according to the old syllabus), which can be stored for an average period of 15 to 20 seconds. Some information can last in short-term memory for up to a minute if rehearsal strategies are used. The information in short-term memory is also highly susceptible to interference. Any new information that enters short-term memory will quickly displace old information. Similar items in the environment can also interfere with short-term memories. A process called chunking (creating information chunks, made up of individual items) can increase the amount that can be stored in the working memory, but does take some thought (and would not be used for a squawk code). Therefore, to answer the question, "The pilot could not store all 4 digits in their working memory at once." This would not be a problem, especially as the numbers are linked (one big 4-digit number), the squawk code should only really take up one "slot" worth of working memory (maybe sightly more than one, but certainly not close to 5 of course. "The information was lost from the working memory because of the interruption." Correct. Interruptions take the mind away from what is stored in the working memory and cause time to pass, so it is more difficult to remember after the conversation. "The pilot could not recall the transponder code from their long-term memory." The transponder code will not have reached their long-term memory, only their working memory. "The pilot did not "chunk" the digits to make them more memorable, and therefore lost them from memory." The pilot would not need to "chunk" a 4 digit number to keep it in the working memory, but by remembering it as a 4-digit number instead of 4 x 1-digit numbers, it is naturally "chunked" anyway. Nonetheless, this is not what caused it to be forgotten.

content.question: The crew of a business jet is quite small. Will there still be an influence on each other’s behaviour?

options.A: Only if the crew consists of more than one pilot and/or more than one cabin crew, as there are no effects between cockpit and cabin crew.
options.B: Yes, the decisions of individual persons will still be influenced by the other persons.
options.C: Yes, but the effect will be negligible because of the small number of crew members.
options.D: No, this only happens in larger groups of people.

key_points: People try to live up to group norms, which can be set quite quickly, even in a group that hasn’t met much before

Have you ever been on a team where it seemed like everyone shared the same mind? They all agreed on everything, and things went along swimmingly? This seems great in theory, but when everyone agrees with each other all the time, it might mean that great ideas or important facts and concerns are getting left on the table, or not even considered at all
A team's power comes from the members' differing backgrounds, experience levels, and skillsets
learning.explanation: People try to live up to group norms, which can be set quite quickly, even in a group that hasn’t met much before. Have you ever been on a team where it seemed like everyone shared the same mind? They all agreed on everything, and things went along swimmingly? This seems great in theory, but when everyone agrees with each other all the time, it might mean that great ideas or important facts and concerns are getting left on the table, or not even considered at all. A team's power comes from the members' differing backgrounds, experience levels, and skillsets. We'd even go so far as to argue that you don't really need a team if everyone thinks the same. So, to build a team that is not only cohesive, but productive, it's important to encourage everyone to share their ideas, feedback, concerns and constructive criticism. The crew being rather small also promotes cohesion by how often crew members interact with each other. Cohesion describes the extent to which members of a group experience a sense of community. Team spirit results from high cohesion and promotes that individual members set aside their individual needs in favour of a group context (achieving a common goal).

content.question:
On 8th July 2010, the crew of a Boeing 737 from Nice to Frankfurt was cleared by the controller of Sector L14 to continue its climb to FL320. In an adjacent sector, the crew of an Airbus 319 from London to Milan were cleared to leave FL390 and to descend to FL330. The instruction was read back correctly, but the pilots incorrectly entered FL320 into the FMS. Upon being handed off to sector L14, the Airbus called the controller:
"Easy 529 Yankee, descending FL320 on radar heading 150"
The controller identified the traffic, however he/she did not realise the incorrect flight level reported by the Airbus.
Shortly after, the two aircraft were converging on FL320 and triggered potential conflict alerts on both the controller's system and the on-board TCAS of each aircraft. Corrective action had to be taken by each aircraft to re-establish separation.

Selecte the option which correctly states the type of communication and associated disadvantage which are illustrated by this serious incident of a "level bust" with resulting loss of separation:

options.A: Implicit communication, which is prone to being biased towards hearing a message in accordance with one's mental picture of a situation.
options.B: Implicit communication, which is open to interpretation due to receiving erroneous or inconsistent pieces of information.
options.C: Explicit communication, which is prone to confirmation bias, that is, we hear what we expect to hear and NOT what is being said.
options.D: Explicit communication, which means that the message is difficult to identify and is open to multiple interpretations.

key_points: With regards to this question, the communications between the pilot and ATC were clear and straight forward - EXPLICIT

The air traffic controller who receives an erraneous readback is required to correct the pilot and ensure that he has got the correct information - he should prompt the pilot to make a correct readback

Human Error is considered inevitable and readback obligations for vital information have been installed to detect such errors and prevent them from having adverse consequences (mi-air collisions, etc)
learning.explanation: With regards to this question, the communications between the pilot and ATC were clear and straight forward - EXPLICIT. The air traffic controller who receives an erraneous readback is required to correct the pilot and ensure that he has got the correct information - he should prompt the pilot to make a correct readback. Human Error is considered inevitable and readback obligations for vital information have been installed to detect such errors and prevent them from having adverse consequences (mi-air collisions, etc). Now, especially during peak traffic periods, special care should be taken in order to avoid what is called "Expectancy", where a pilot/ATC don't pay full attention to a communication/readback and "hear what they want to hear" Further information Explicit is, “to fully and clearly express something, leaving nothing implied.” Something is explicit when it is cleared stated and spelled out and there is no room for confusion, as in the writing of a contract or statute. Implicit is, “implied or understood though not plainly or directly expressed.” Something is, therefore, implicit when it is not directly stated but is either suggested in the wording or necessary to effectuate the purpose.

SELECTIVE ATTENTION With selective attention, one gives greater attention to one or more sources of input out of several. Such a selective mechanism is required because the resources of the Central Decision Maker and short-term memory are limited. It is the process during which information is sampled to see if it is relevant, which makes you able to detect information meant for you, such as your callsign, even if you are not specifically monitoring the source.

content.question: In terms of flight safety, what fundamental principle governs the balance between manual piloting and automation utilization?

options.A: Automation should be used where pilots have to make decisions and manual flying should be compulsory in abnormal situations.
options.B: Manual flying should be used when in VMC, and automation should be used in IMC and to assist in complex operations and abnormal situations.
options.C: Automation should be used as much as possible; manual flying should be avoided as the pilot will inevitably make mistakes.
options.D: Automation when used correctly and with an awareness of its weaknesses and dangers adds to the overall safety of flight.

key_points: AUTOMATION Due to the significant role of human error in approximately 70% of aviation accidents, companies are actively seeking methods to reduce the human element, provided safety is not compromised
As a result, automation is increasingly prevalent in aviation
Automation is intended to support pilots rather than supplant them, enabling them to focus on higher-level decision-making and enhancing flight safety
learning.explanation: AUTOMATION Due to the significant role of human error in approximately 70% of aviation accidents, companies are actively seeking methods to reduce the human element, provided safety is not compromised. As a result, automation is increasingly prevalent in aviation. Automation is intended to support pilots rather than supplant them, enabling them to focus on higher-level decision-making and enhancing flight safety. Automation systems can execute routine tasks while pilots can focus on decision making and cross-checking. However, this shift presents new challenges the pilots must be aware of, in order to use automation efficiently. DANGERS OF AUTOMATION 1. Hypovigilance and loss of situational awareness. Automation can lead to a reduced state of alertness due to boredom and lack of physical activity. Pilots may become too focused on monitoring automated systems, potentially missing important cues or developments in their surroundings. 2. Automation complacency. Overreliance on automation may lead to complacency among pilots, where they become overly reliant on automated systems, potentially not checking the system as often as needed. 3. Blinkered attention. Pilots may develop tunnel vision or blinkered attention, concentrating solely on monitoring automated systems, potentially missing broader situational factors or unexpected events. 4. Mode errors. Incorrectly configuring or selecting automation modes can result in mode errors, where the aircraft behaves differently from what the pilot intended, possibly leading to unsafe situations. 5. Reduced crew communication. Overreliance on automation may decrease crew communication, as pilots may communicate less when automation systems handle many tasks. Automation is used during commercial flights in order to increase flight safety. In emergency situations, the pilots may need to revert to manual flying, depending on the nature of the emergency.

key_points: MOTIVATION AND LEARNING Motivation plays a crucial role in sustaining a learner's effort and focus throughout the learning journey
When individuals are motivated, they are more likely to persevere through challenges and setbacks, which are common in the learning process
Successful learning experiences can reinforce motivation
learning.explanation: MOTIVATION AND LEARNING Motivation plays a crucial role in sustaining a learner's effort and focus throughout the learning journey. When individuals are motivated, they are more likely to persevere through challenges and setbacks, which are common in the learning process. Successful learning experiences can reinforce motivation. When students see their efforts translating into progress and success, it often boosts their motivation to continue learning and striving for more achievements. They feel a sense of accomplishment and satisfaction, which can increase their enthusiasm for further learning. This motivation stems from the recognition that their efforts have been productive. With increased motivation, students are more likely to invest additional effort and time into their studies. They become more willing to deal with new challenges or take on new learning opportunities. OTHER FACTORS AFFECTING THE LEARNING PROCESS While a student's level of motivation plays a significant role in their learning journey, it's not the only factor at play. Learning is a multifaceted process influenced by various elements. These include the quality of instruction, the motivation of the instructor, the learning environment, available resources, the learner's prior knowledge, and their individual characteristics. In essence, effective learning arises from the interplay of several factors, with motivation being just one piece of the puzzle. While motivation is a crucial factor in the learning process, it's not an absolute prerequisite for all types of learning, and its role can vary among individuals.

Their reaction time to deviations from preselected values is also much shorter and their corrections are more accurate than human's. A machine is not able to have a qualitative approach to a problem solution, while humans do. Together, they’re an unbeatable duo.

content.question: Which of the following may be considered as an effect of stress on human behaviour?

options.A: Fast breathing
options.B: Unreliability
options.C: Headaches
options.D: Hormonal disorder

key_points: STRESS Stress disturbs the body’s homeostasis and enables you to adapt to encountered situations
it is the body’s response to a stressor, which is an internal or external stimulus that is interpreted as a threat to the body’s equilibrium, and prepares it for action
Stress is a very subjective matter – every individual is different and stress reactions as well as their magnitudes differ from person to person
learning.explanation: STRESS Stress disturbs the body’s homeostasis and enables you to adapt to encountered situations. it is the body’s response to a stressor, which is an internal or external stimulus that is interpreted as a threat to the body’s equilibrium, and prepares it for action. Stress is a very subjective matter – every individual is different and stress reactions as well as their magnitudes differ from person to person. Common effects of stress include: On your body On your mood On your behaviour Headache Anxiety Overeating or undereating Muscle tension or pain Restlessness Angry outbursts Chest pain Lack of motivation or focus Drug or alcohol misuse Fatigue Feeling overwhelmed Tobacco use Change in sex drive Irritability or anger Social withdrawal Stomach upset Sadness or depression Exercising less often To go through each option: "Fast breathing" Stress can indeed trigger the "fight or flight" response in the body, causing an increase in breathing rate, however, this is a bodily change, not a behavioural one. "Unreliability" Given recent feedback, this is correct. We think that it is tenuous to say that a direct behavioural effect of stress is unreliability, as unreliability occurs from a combination of factors, some of which are changed by stress, however, unreliability is a change to a person's behaviour, and the level of someone's unreliability is affected by stress levels, so we think it is an acceptable answer in the context. "Headaches" Stress can cause tension style headaches and migraines due to neurological processes and from the increased tension within muscles in the upper body, face and neck. It is debatable whether or not this could be considered a behavioural change at all though, whilst it could cause a change in behaviour, we think that it is not one itself. It was previously reported as correct, but we believe that was wrong or has changed since. "Hormonal disorder" Chronic stress can disrupt the balance of hormones in the body, leading to a range of disorders such as adrenal fatigue or thyroid dysfunction, but this is not a behavioural change (again, it could lead to behavioural changes, but is not one itself).

content.question: An aircraft is flying a long-haul North Atlantic flight. What is true about the pilots?

options.B: Stress and arousal are likely low, but vigilance must be maintained.
options.C: There is no stress but vigilance and arousal must be maintained high.

key_points: Arousal is “the measure of the human being’s readiness to respond”
Arousal can manifest in various ways, including increased heart rate, heightened awareness, increased muscle tension, and a heightened state of consciousness
High vigilance is a state of sustained attention, alertness, and watchfulness for the detection of specific events, stimuli, or changes in the environment
learning.explanation: Arousal is “the measure of the human being’s readiness to respond”. Arousal can manifest in various ways, including increased heart rate, heightened awareness, increased muscle tension, and a heightened state of consciousness. High vigilance is a state of sustained attention, alertness, and watchfulness for the detection of specific events, stimuli, or changes in the environment. It involves maintaining a heightened state of awareness over an extended period of time to identify and respond to rare or unexpected occurrences or potential threats. The state of vigilance is the degree of activation of the central nervous system. This can vary from deep sleep to extreme alertness and is controlled by the circadian cycle. A long-haul North Atlantic flight is generally calm and uneventful. During the cruise phase of such flights, when there are fewer critical tasks to perform, stress and arousal levels for pilots tend to be lower compared to more active phases like takeoff and landing. However, maintaining vigilance is crucial to monitor the aircraft systems, weather conditions, and any potential changes or emergencies that may occur during the flight.

Which of the following statements are correct with regard to the design of a check list?

3. Check lists must be designed in such a way that they can be lumped together with other tasks.

The combination of correct statements is:

options.A: 1, 2 and 5 are correct
options.B: 1, 3 and 5 are correct
options.C: 1, 2 and 3 are correct
options.D: 1, 4 and 5 are correct

key_points: CHECKLISTS Studies of human error rates during simple repetitive tasks have shown that errors can normally be expected on about 1 to 10 occasions
After methodical training, a rate of 1 to 100 is considered to be realistic and pretty good
A checklist can be used to reduce the effects of human memory and attention limitations by ensuring consistency and completeness
learning.explanation: CHECKLISTS Studies of human error rates during simple repetitive tasks have shown that errors can normally be expected on about 1 to 10 occasions. After methodical training, a rate of 1 to 100 is considered to be realistic and pretty good. A checklist can be used to reduce the effects of human memory and attention limitations by ensuring consistency and completeness. In order for a checklist to provide valuable assistance for crew members, certain design criteria should be observed: 1. The most critical items on the task-checklist should be listed as close as possible to the beginning of the task-checklist, in order to increase the likelihood of completing the item before interruptions may occur. 2. The more items a checklist has, the more likely one of them is forgotten. A long checklist should be subdivided to smaller task-checklists or chunks that can be associated with systems and functions within the cockpit. Division of pages should be obtained with protruding thumb locators. 3. Sequencing of checklist items should follow the “geographical” organization of the items in the cockpit, and be performed in a logical flow (panel scan sequence). We note that this guideline could conflict with Nos. 1 above. In most cases where this occurs, this guideline (No. 3) should take precedence. 4. The most critical items should be emphasized by use of colour, bold, italics or upper case. 5. Checklists should be designed in such a way that their execution will not be tightly coupled with other tasks - to ensure maximum attention is devoted to the checklist execution. 6. Check lists should be unambiguous and easy to read, presented in easily understood language.

Antidote – Follow the rules
learning.explanation: HAZARDOUS ATTITUDES Studies have identified five hazardous attitudes among pilots that can interfere with a pilot’s ability to make effective decisions. ANTI-AUTHORITY (“don’t tell me”) – You display this attitude if you resent having someone tell you what to do, or you regard rules and procedures as unnecessary. Antidote – Follow the rules. They are usually right. IMPULSIVITY (“do it quickly”) – If you feel the need to act immediately and do the first thing that comes to mind without considering the best solution to a problem, then you are exhibiting impulsivity. Antidote – Not so fast. Think first. INVULNERABILITY (“It won’t happen to me”) – You are more likely to take chances and increase risk if you think accidents will not happen to you. Antidote – It could happen to me. MACHO (“I can do it”) – If you have this attitude, you might take risks trying to prove that you are better than anyone else. Women are just as likely to have this characteristic as men. Pilots with a macho attitude are always trying to impress others and prove themselves by taking unnecessary risks. Both men and women are susceptible to a macho attitude, which leads to foolish and often dangerous behaviour. While pilots must have a high level of confidence in their abilities, it’s important to avoid becoming overconfident and adopting a macho attitude. Antidote – Taking chances is foolish. RESIGNATION (“What’s the use?”) – You are experiencing resignation if you feel that no matter what you do, it will have little effect on what happens to you. You may feel that when things go well, it is just good luck and when things go poorly, it is bad luck or someone else is responsible. This feeling can cause you to leave the action to others – for better or worse. Antidote – I am not helpless. I can make a difference.

content.question:
Which of the following statements about autoflight systems is/are correct?
1. Autoflight systems are designed to assist and reduce the workload of the pilot and possess the creativity to deal with unforeseen situations.
2. An autoflight system is, at its core, a computer, operated by logic, and is NOT capable of performing with the same personal motivation as a pilot, with regard to safety.

options.A: 1 and 2 are correct.
