options.C: 1 is correct and 2 is incorrect.
options.D: 1 is incorrect and 2 is correct.

key_points: Machines have a leg up on humans in more technical, repetitive, and scalable tasks, and they get to avoid the different behavioural inconsistencies that people often display
Computers are great at prolonged monitoring and detecting rare events, they perform these tasks much more precisely and reliably than humans
Their reaction time to deviations from preselected values is also much shorter and their corrections are more accurate than human's
learning.explanation: Machines have a leg up on humans in more technical, repetitive, and scalable tasks, and they get to avoid the different behavioural inconsistencies that people often display. Computers are great at prolonged monitoring and detecting rare events, they perform these tasks much more precisely and reliably than humans. Their reaction time to deviations from preselected values is also much shorter and their corrections are more accurate than human's. However, automated systems have one major drawback, which will make it hard for them to ever completely replace human pilots; and that is their incapability of coming up with solutions for new problems. Humans are unpredictable and fickle, but they are also more adept at handling unpredictability. They can be creative and innovative and use knowledge stored in their memory to solve a situation that they have never thought of before. A machine is not able to have a qualitative approach to a problem solution, while humans do. Together, they’re an unbeatable duo.

content.question: In flight a Commander encourages a relaxed communication atmosphere, and his/her primary aim is to please the Co-Pilot. During a weather-avoidance scenario in VMC when the Co-Pilot suggests an avoidance plan, the Commander remains passive, making NO judgements and letting the Co-Pilot make the decision. How is this described trans-cockpit authority gradient and leadership style known as?

options.A: Off-centred cockpit
options.B: Synergistic cockpit
options.C: Laissez-faire cockpit
options.D: Autocratic cockpit

key_points: The four types of Authority Gradient Cockpits are: The Autocratic Cockpit
The Laissez-faire Cockpit
The Self-centred Cockpit
learning.explanation: The four types of Authority Gradient Cockpits are: The Autocratic Cockpit. The Laissez-faire Cockpit. The Self-centred Cockpit. The Synergistic Cockpit (the ideal). Autocratic Cockpit: An autocratic cockpit is described by the captain’s excessive authority, considerably reducing communication and consequently synergy and cohesion of the crew. Consists of a management style wherein the captain controls all the decisions and takes very little inputs from the co-pilot. Autocratic captains make choices or decisions based on their own beliefs and do not involve other crew members for their suggestion or advice. Rarely delegates tasks. By the very nature of the way the cockpit is run, the Captain is normally overloaded in the event of a problem. Laissez-faire Cockpit: A laissez-faire cockpit exists when a passive approach by the captain allows decisions, choices and actions to be made by other crew members, with a major risk of an inversion of authority. Encourages a relaxed and laid-back atmosphere in the cockpit with communications leaning towards non-professional subjects. Has a primary aim to please the rest of the crew. Self-centred Cockpit: A self-centred cockpit is one where crew members tend to do their own thing without telling the others what is going on. Synergistic Cockpit: Decisions are taken by the captain with the help and participation of the other crew members. Captain motivates the crew and develops the skills of the crew. Supports team working and clearly communicates intentions and required standards.

content.question:
The crew of an Airbus A320 is flying towards an airport in severe thunderstorms and reported wind shear conditions. Due to several aircraft going around, delays are to be expected and the crew is cleared into a holding pattern. Preoccupied with the weather ahead of them, the crew fails to notice that they have accidentally pulled back the thrust levers too far, disabling the autothrottle. As airspeed drops, and aerodynamic buffet sets in, it is interpreted by the crew as entry into turbulence. When the aircraft actually stalls, the crew is convinced to have encountered wind shear and performs the appropriate escape manoeuvre. As the manoeuvre includes applying full thrust, the crew can successfully recover from the stall and land safely.
What is correct regarding the initial error?

options.A: It can be regarded as a violation, as approaches in wind shear are forbidden by most companies’ SOPs.
options.B: It is a latent error, because it could only manifest itself because of the wind shear conditions.
options.C: Applying the SHELL model, the error was due to environmental issues.
options.D: The error was due to internal factors.

key_points: This question describes a chain of errors
As far as we can tell, this chain initiated with the inadvertent disablement of autothrottle by the crew pulling back the thrust levers without realising it
From what we can read, this action is a result from the pilots being stressed and preoccupied with the adverse weather ahead
learning.explanation: This question describes a chain of errors. As far as we can tell, this chain initiated with the inadvertent disablement of autothrottle by the crew pulling back the thrust levers without realising it. From what we can read, this action is a result from the pilots being stressed and preoccupied with the adverse weather ahead. Thus we can conclude that the initial error was due to internal factors. Internal factors of error generation lie within the person making the error and can have physiological or psychological reasons.

content.question:
Which of the following factors are typical examples of the effects on flight crew of short-term, acute fatigue?
1. Tiredness and falling asleep for short periods without being aware that this happens.
2. Constant feeling of lethargy and lack of energy.
3. Reduced concentration and vigilance.
4. Increased error rate and slowed reaction times.
5. Increased mental and physiological health issues.
6. Increased irritability.

key_points: Fatigue is a feeling of constant tiredness or weakness and can be physical, mental or a combination of both
The two types of fatigue are acute and chronic: Acute fatigue – short-term, more intense which usually affects the body, and just needs a good nights’ sleep to sort things out
Chronic fatigue – arises from more long-term effects, like many episodes of acute fatigue
learning.explanation: Fatigue is a feeling of constant tiredness or weakness and can be physical, mental or a combination of both. The two types of fatigue are acute and chronic: Acute fatigue – short-term, more intense which usually affects the body, and just needs a good nights’ sleep to sort things out. Chronic fatigue – arises from more long-term effects, like many episodes of acute fatigue. In this case, normal or increased periods of sleep cannot restore the body's energy level and people do not even feel refreshed for a short time after a night's sleep. Fatigue affects physical and mental functions, and is accompanied by hypovigilance, thus also having an effect on work performance. Fatigue is usually accompanied by a noticeable lack of concentraction and memory. Other effects include reduced visual perception and hand-eye coordination and slower reaction times. The capacity to judge risk is also impaired. Fatigued people tend to be irritable and reduce communication with others. Fatigue can also result in micro sleep, short naps of up to 5 seconds. People are usually unaware of entering micro sleep, it cannot be consciously controlled and seriously jeopardises safety. In addition to the above, Chronic fatigue can cause serious health issues such as cardiovascular or gastro-intestinal disease, reduced fertility, diabetes, asthma and mental disorders like depression.

content.question: A non synergistic cockpit:

options.A: always results from an over-relaxed atmosphere
options.B: is characterised by a highly efficient crew, communicating appropriately with the outside
options.C: is characterised by withdrawn crew members and unclear communication
options.D: is not very dangerous as each person checks everything personally

key_points: SYNERGY Synergy describes a cooperation of creatures, matter or forces in terms of mutual support
In simple words, it is the state where the group performance exceeds the sum of the individual performances (“the whole is more than the sum of its parts”)

Synergy can be expressed as a simple mathematical statement: (considering a crew of two) 1 + 1 = > 2 When the group performance is less than the sum of individual performances, synergy is said to be poor and can be mathematically expressed as follows: 1 + 1 = < 2 The most critical moment for development of synergy among the crew is the pre-flight briefing
learning.explanation: SYNERGY Synergy describes a cooperation of creatures, matter or forces in terms of mutual support. In simple words, it is the state where the group performance exceeds the sum of the individual performances (“the whole is more than the sum of its parts”). Synergy can be expressed as a simple mathematical statement: (considering a crew of two) 1 + 1 = > 2 When the group performance is less than the sum of individual performances, synergy is said to be poor and can be mathematically expressed as follows: 1 + 1 = < 2 The most critical moment for development of synergy among the crew is the pre-flight briefing. The captain (the designated leader) should take the opportunity to emphasize that all crew members working on the aircraft form one crew. Synergy should then be maintained until the end of the duty period. A non-synergetic cockpit will most likely lead to unclear communication and crew members withdrawn.

content.question:
A student pilot has failed an important flight test and examination. With help from a positive instructor, the student eventually completes training and passes the flight test.
The effect of the experience on the student is:

options.A: The experience will heavily affect the student. He will have poor self-confidence afterwards and frequently require reassurance from others.
options.B: The experience will markedly boost the student’s self-confidence as he realises that he can achieve everything with sufficient training.
options.C: A student with a stable personality will be able to realise that sometimes things do not go perfectly and learn from the experience.
options.D: A student with a stable personality will have a lower self-confidence afterwards.

key_points: Failure can initially make one feel demoralized, helpless, hopeless, and anxious (both consciously and unconsciously)
However, a stable individual will most likely fight back and failing an exam just once will not have an impact on his/her self-confidence
A stable student will learn from his/her mistakes and will take it as an experience
learning.explanation: Failure can initially make one feel demoralized, helpless, hopeless, and anxious (both consciously and unconsciously). However, a stable individual will most likely fight back and failing an exam just once will not have an impact on his/her self-confidence. A stable student will learn from his/her mistakes and will take it as an experience.

content.question: What happens when arousal passes beyond the break point?

options.A: Arousal starts decreasing, whereas stress increases.
options.B: Both arousal and stress increase.
options.C: Arousal continues to increase but stress decreases.
options.D: Both arousal and stress decrease.

key_points: Arousal and Performance Arousal is the measure of the human being's readiness to respond
The relationship between arousal and performance is a symmetrical inverted U (performance being on the vertical axis and arousal on the horizontal axis)
Increases in arousal will result in the increase of performance, up to a point, called the break point, beyond which further arousal is dysfunctional to the outcome of performance
learning.explanation: Arousal and Performance Arousal is the measure of the human being's readiness to respond. The relationship between arousal and performance is a symmetrical inverted U (performance being on the vertical axis and arousal on the horizontal axis). Increases in arousal will result in the increase of performance, up to a point, called the break point, beyond which further arousal is dysfunctional to the outcome of performance. At the optimum arousal level, we are at our most efficient - optimum arousal happens just below the breakpoint. Regarding this question: Stress increases along with arousal. Initially, we experience eustress (positive stress) and then distress (negative stress). As previously mentioned, the point of highest performance (optimum arousal or stress) is just below the breakpoint. After this breakpoint, performance decreases as stress becomes overwhelming. However, arousal and stress will still increase.
